PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

All the Australians believe that the Keating Government should get on with the job of governing and direct its attention towards real issues such as the parlous state of the economy, the appalling level of unemployment, and our lack of international competitiveness.
The Australian national flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, who are Christian brethren in fellowship together, having their faith and trust in the Lord Jesus Christ and believe the Holy Bible to be the infallible, inspired Word of God as providing light and law on every principle and relationship, draws to your attention that abortion as generally carried out, is in conflict with the teachings of scripture. It is human intrusion into an area where God has right of way. It is life destroyed, a history with God aborted, murder and punishable by God. Genesis 9:6.
God's creatorial rights and power relate to:-

PETITION.PARA: 1. Conception, life, breath and body. Ruth 4:13, Job 33:4, Acts 17:24,25, 1 Corinthians 15:38.
2. What proceeds in the womb. Psalm 139:13-16, Psalm 127:3, Galatians 1:15.
3. Termination of life in this world. Daniel 5:23, Genesis 5:24, 2 Samuel 6:7.

PARA.TAB: It is submitted that by supporting abortion through Medicare funding, the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility to be a terror to an evil work and God's minister for good. Romans 13:1-4. For the Government to continue supporting this wickedness is to invite God's righteous indignation and judgment upon our nation.
Your petitioners therefore, as duty bound, pray and ask the Honourable House to legislate to cease funding of abortions through Medicare as soon as practically possible.

PARA.TAB: The undersigned citizens of Australia make this humble petition regarding the practice of abortion. We are all believers in the Lord Jesus Christ and have regard for the unerring guidance contained in the Holy Scriptures. We draw your attention to the following:

Ruth 4 v 13—"The Lord gave her conception and she bore a son"
2. Life is God given.
Acts 17 v 25—"He giveth to all life, and breath, and all things

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica: Huskies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is no scientific evidence which shows that huskies are:
1.A threat to Antarctica's fauna including seal and penguin colonies.
2.Linked to disease among other animals in the region.
3.Disease carriers because of a failure in the strict quarantine methods used when introducing a new dog.
4.Inferior to fuel driven vehicles in terms of efficiency of transport and impose greater damage on the environment compared to fuel driven vehicles.
Australia's signature on an international agreement will end a significant Australian tradition of using husky dogs in Antarctica by requiring the removal of all huskies presently in Antarctica.

Recognising that since 1898 huskies have supported Antarctic expeditions, have continued to be of value to scientists carrying out research and are an intrinsic part of the Australian presence in Antarctica your petitioners call upon the Government to reverse its decision concerning the huskies in Antarctica and allow them to remain in Antarctica.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: (1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of The Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia. Each signatory is seeking to walk with good conscience as before God. Hence each is a believer on the Lord Jesus Christ, and each fully accepts the authority of God's word as contained in the Holy Bible.

Your petitioners have been burdened for long years because the Family Law Act does not allow adultery as a ground of divorce. This is in direct contradiction to the words of the Lord Himself who said "Whosoever shall put away his wife except for fornication, and shall marry another, commits adultery and whosoever marrieth her which is put away committeth adultery" (Matthew Chapter 19 verse 9).

Your petitioners humbly pray that The House amend the Family Law Act so that adultery is included as a ground of divorce. In doing this The House will be fulfilling the Parliamentary Prayer "Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move that the following delegated legislation, a list of which I shall hand to the Clerk, be disallowed. Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement about the Committee's concerns with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of these instruments creates offences which may not provide the usual safeguards for those accused; another imposes fees for services by a public authority which are set at levels specifically designed to deter people from exercising their legal rights; while the third selectively withdraws financial concessions from users of a public service with no apparent recourse by those adversely affected. The Committee has asked for advice from the relevant Ministers. Mr President, as usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the Committee's concerns.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: EXPORT INSPECTION (CHARGES COLLECTION) REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)
STATUTORY RULES 1992 NO.251

These regulations make all attendances by Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service officers chargeable, authorise requests for payment in advance, prescribe payment offices, amend particulars to be provided in returns and delete provisions relating to refund of charges.

The Explanatory Statement advises that, with respect to payment of charges, payment in advance will be required from all but regular clients with a good record of payment on time. This may be reasonable in management terms, but it is a valuable financial concession and there is no reference in the Explanatory Statement as to whether there is a right of review of an administrative decision to the effect that a person does not have a good record of payment.

Secondly, a regulation is omitted with the impact, noted in the Explanatory Statement, that AQIS will not refund charges in the future. No explanation is offered for this change to the rights of clients.

Thirdly, there may be a problem with the drafting of the regulations. The Explanatory Statement, under the explanation of r.2B, advises that r.2B(2) provides that no refund of this charge is to be made regardless of the outcome of the application. However, there is no r.2B(2), nor is there any other provision to this effect. In addition, there is a regulation numbered r.2A(1) even though r.2A has only one subsection.
EXPORT INSPECTION (SERVICE CHARGE) REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)
STATUTORY RULES 1992 NO.249

Among other things, these regulations impose fees for applications for exemption from the Export Control Orders. The fees include a progressive increase in charges for services. Thus, a first service costs $75 a half hour or part thereof, with a minimum charge of $150; a second service costs $83.30 a half hour or part thereof, with a minimum charge of $250; and a third or subsequent service costs $83.30 a half hour or part thereof, with a minimum charge of $500.

The Explanatory Statement advises that the progressive nature of the charge reflects the high costs in processing the applications from frequent users of the exemption provision, and acts as a deterrent to such use. There is no indication of whether any of the three levels reflects the actual cost of processing the applications. In any event, the charges are at least partially intended to deter users from exercising a legal right. In other words, the regulations impose a penalty for making use of a provision of the legislation. The Committee has asked the Minister for advice on this use of delegated legislation, which may breach personal rights.
FEDERAL AIRPORTS (AMENDMENT) BY-LAWS No.1 1992
These amending By-laws prohibit smoking in airport terminal buildings and create associated offences.

The prohibition is largely enforced by smoking infringement notices. Anyone who is served with such a notice may elect either to pay an administrative fine within 14 days or else to have the matter dealt with by a court. However, one By-law provides that if an airport officer believes on reasonable grounds that a person has committed offences by not answering questions or complying with directions, then the officer may serve a smoking infringement fine upon that person. Upon being served with a smoking infringement fine a person must pay the fine immediately.

The Committee believes that the smoking infringement fines may breach personal liberties. In the context of airports and flying out of jurisdiction, it may be reasonable for such fines to be paid immediately. However, the provisions appear not to include such safeguards as specifying the consequences if a person is unable or unwilling to pay the fine. The Committee assumes that these matters are dealt with elsewhere in the Act or other delegated legislation, and has asked the Minister for advice.
LIST OF DELEGATED LEGISLATION
1.Export Inspection (Charges Collection) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 251 and made under the Export Inspection (Charges Collection) Act 1985
2.Export Inspection (Service Charge) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 249 and made under the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985
3.Federal Airports (Amendment) By-laws No. 1 1992 made under section 72 of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: I have great pleasure in introducing this Bill to the Senate. My particular pleasure derives from the fact that this Bill provides for further measures to assist frail older people in our community, and particularly their carers.

This Government's aged care policy pays particular attention to the needs of carers. The Home and Community Care Program lists carers as a special target group for the program. Our residential care program makes special provision for respite care to enable carers to have a break from time to time. This Budget proposes a package of assistance to carers amounting to $89 million over 4 years.
One of these measures concerns an increase to the Domiciliary Nursing Care Benefit (DNCB). This Bill contains provisions which, if passed, will enable implementation of that Budget announcement.

The DNCB provides financial assistance to carers of people over the age of sixteen who have been assessed as needing nursing home level of care. Part 5 of this Bill includes amendments to support three changes to DNCB to take effect from 6 January 1993.
The first amendment will increase the level of the Benefit by $10 to $52 per fortnight from 6 January 1993.
The second amendment provides for the Minister to vary this amount from time to time. It is the Government's intention to index the Benefit annually on the basis of CPI changes.
The third amendment will allow carers to continue to receive the benefit during periods of respite care of up to 42 days a year.

The significant increase of the Benefit by approximately 25% and its subsequent indexation, demonstrates the Government's commitment to the recognition and support for carers of frail older people and people with disabilities living in the community.

The continued payment of the Benefit while the person being cared for is in respite care will provide much needed support for carers and allow them to have short breaks from care without loss of benefit. This provision will bring DNCB into line with provisions applying to similar payments in the Social Security area. Respite care is the service most highly valued by carers. The Bill also contains amendments concerning funding for new and rebuilt nursing homes.

As a result of a decision in the 1991 Budget, the Government already provides additional recurrent funding for some nursing homes that are newly built or completely rebuilt. The aim of this initiative was to improve the quality of nursing home buildings, and hence to improve the quality of care.

The nursing home industry took the view that this initiative would not efficiently meet its objective, since a proprietor could only apply for the additional funding after building the new home. They said that a proprietor considering rebuilding his or her home needed an assurance of the additional funding before construction commenced. Otherwise, he or she would not be able to borrow the money to rebuild.
The proposed amendment overcomes this problem, and introduces a system of Approvals in Principle.

The recent Budget provided funding for Approvals in Principle for 1992-93 and 1993-94. However, it is possible that many proprietors who do not intend to rebuild their home in the near future will nevertheless apply for an Approval in Principle, just in case they change their minds, or in case the State Health Authorities force them to rebuild. There is therefore a risk that the available Approvals in Principle will be wasted. To avoid this possibility, this legislative amendment allows the Approval in Principle to be revoked if no progress is made towards the rebuilding. The Approvals in Principle will then be able to be re-allocated.
The Bill makes provision for a change in date of effect of reviews of resident classifications.

Under the current funding arrangements for nursing homes, the proprietor applies for a classification for a new resident, or for a current resident whose classification is about to expire. This classification is based on the Resident Classification Instrument (RCI) which measures a resident's need for nursing and personal care. These classifications are used to determine the amount of funding for nursing and personal care that a home receives.
In deciding whether to grant a classification, the Secretary of the Department is guided by Principles formulated by the Minister, known as the Nursing Home Classification Principles.

The Secretary of the Department may at any time review the classification of a resident. If, on the basis of this review, the Secretary decides that the resident has been wrongly classified, the Secretary may revoke the classification and substitute a higher or lower classification.

Currently, the Secretary is not required to have regard to the Nursing Home Classification Principles when reviewing a resident's classification. This is an anomaly, because the purpose of the Classification Principles is to ensure that all resident classifications are determined by classification principles which are universally applied, according to relative care need.
Therefore, this Bill proposes to amend the Act to require the Secretary to observe the Nursing Home Classification Principles, when reviewing a resident's classification.

There exists a further anomaly in regard to reviews of classifications. If the review classification is lower than the original classification, the review classification currently takes effect from the date of the review. This is despite the fact that the wrong classification has applied from the date of the original classification.
This Bill proposes to amend the period of effect of a review by the Secretary so that the review classification is for the same period as the original classification.

This also means a nursing home will not have as long to wait for a further review of the classification. At present, in the case of a reduced classification, the nursing home has to wait until the review classification has been in force for twelve months. This can be up to one year after the original classification would have expired and delays the opportunity for the nursing home to seek a further classification in cases where the resident's care needs have changed.

The proposed amendment will mean that the nursing home will receive a positive or negative adjustment to future funding depending on whether the review classification is higher or lower than the original assessment by the nursing home. This will ensure an appropriate level of funding for the entire twelve month classification period. The nursing home will be able to apply for a further annual classification at the end of that time.

The Bill ensures that the new arrangements applying to the period of effect of a review classification, if that review lowers a category, will apply only to classifications determined on or after the date of assent to the Bill.

The Bill also makes amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act designed to increase equity with regard to hostel subsidies by providing higher subsidies for Financially Disadvantaged Persons (FDPs).

The amendments provide for an increase in funding for each FDP hostel resident, offset by a reduction in funding for non-FDP hostel residents who have been assessed for Personal Care (PC). It is intended that at all levels of care within a hostel there will be a $3.20 a day subsidy difference between FDP and non-FDP residents. Hostels have a greater capacity to raise income from their non-FDP residents through avenues such as entry contributions and variable fees. These options are generally not available for hostels catering for FDPs. This can present problems in ensuring access for this group and viability problems for hostels catering predominantly for FDPs. Thus the amendments will benefit hostels accommodating Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and other disadvantaged groups.

The recently introduced hostel personal care arrangements are based on the assessment of the relative care need of each individual, not their financial status or capacity to pay—this principle is unchanged. Those with higher care needs will continue to get higher subsidies. However, the subsidy at each level will also reflect the financial status of the resident.
While some hostels will be disadvantaged in terms of subsidies available, the extent to which hostels will be affected will depend on the financial status of the residents.

As already indicated, hostels with high levels of non-FDPs have access to higher levels of resident charges. The real impact on the resident and the hostel should be minimal, as the changes, in combination with forthcoming real increases in pensioner income through pension and rental assistance increases, largely offset each other.
The overall impact is that the income available to hostels from subsidies and resident payments will be better targeted to support those in need.
In addition to amendments to the aged care area the Bill makes amendments to the arrangements regarding payment of Medicare Benefits in relation to R-Type Diagnostic Imaging Services.

The amendment of subsection 16B(11) of the Health Insurance Act provides for the extension by two years, to 1 January 1995, of the "sunset" provisions. Under the current "sunset" provision, from 1 January 1993, Medicare benefits will no longer be payable for diagnostic imaging services rendered by medical practitioners who were exempted by the "grandparent" provisions in the 1991 amendments dealing with "arms length" requesting of these services. An extension will allow for the continuation of the payment of Medicare benefits for R-type services in these circumstances.
The amendments proposed will provide more time for the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners to develop accreditation guidelines for general practitioners who provide radiology services.

The Bill also amends the Medicare Benefits referral arrangements by inserting a new section 20BA in the Health Insurance Act. The main purpose of the proposed amendment is to require that where a practitioner refers a patient, in writing, to a consultant physician or a specialist and where the physician or specialist renders a specialist medical service to that patient, the physician or specialist must retain the referral for a period of 18 months. The amendment also proposes that the physician or specialist be required, if requested by the Managing Director of the Health Insurance Commission, to produce to an officer of the Commission the referral or the patient's hospital records for verification of a referral.

Following discussions between the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services and the medical profession, agreement was reached on revised referral arrangements. This included placing onus of proof that a valid referral took place on the specialist or the consultant physician (ie the practitioner to whom the patient was referred) rather than the referring practitioner.

Precedents for the proposed amendment already exist in the Health Insurance Act in respect of requests for pathology and diagnostic imaging services including the requirement that the referral be retained for a period of 18 months.

The Bill rectifies an error in subsection 129AAA(3) of the Health Insurance Act. The amendment to the subsection omits the second occurrence of the word "pathology" before "practitioner" so that the subsection prohibits an Approved Pathology Practitioner from providing nursing and other staff not only at the premises of the practitioner but also at premises made available to the practitioner by a medical entrepreneur.

The Bill also reinserts subsection 79(5) in the National Health Act to allow for the cancellation of registration of organisations where the business of all health benefits funds conducted by them have been transferred, in accordance with an approval by the Minister, to funds conducted by other organisations. Subsection 79(5) of the National Health Act was inadvertently repealed by the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act 1989.

The proposed amendments of section 4 the National Health Act in Part five of this Bill relate to the payment of Medicare benefits for visits by participating optometrists to private patients in hospital and approved day hospital facilities. Currently where a visit is made by an optometrists to such patients the Medicare rebate is 75 per cent of the Schedule fee with the health insurance funds required to cover the remaining 25 per cent for insured patients.

While the 75 per cent benefit rebate is contained in the Health Insurance Act it is linked to the professional service rendered to patients who are receiving hospital treatment as provided for in the National Health Act.

When the Health Insurance Act was amended in 1987, to reduce the Medicare benefit for professional services rendered in a hospital, or approved day hospital facilities, to private patients from 85 per cent (maximum $20 gap) to 75 per cent flat, its unintended application to optometrical consultations was over looked.

Patients are not admitted to hospital for conditions requiring the services of an optometrist. An optometrist may visit a hospital as a social service to a patient who has broken his/her spectacles and requires a test for new spectacles. Such patients are most likely to be long stay nursing home type patients. The 75 per cent flat rate benefit provides a disincentive for optometrists to bulk bill such patients, the majority of whom would be aged persons. Currently some 87 per cent of optometrical services are direct billed.

The proposal in this Bill is to amend subsection 4(1) of the National Health Act to exclude optometrical consultations from the definition of professional service for the purpose of that section and as a consequence from the application of the 75 per cent Medicare benefit level provided for in Section 10 of the Health Insurance Act.

The Bill also closes a loophole which would enable a child, in respect of whom family allowance is not being paid because of the income or assets test, to be declared a disadvantaged person and thus be issued with a Health Care Card and receive pharmaceutical benefits at the concessional rate of patient contribution.
Finally, the Bill makes a number of minor changes and corrections to the legislation governing the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill seeks to remove sales tax exemption which was granted to certain recyclable papers in 1989. Some goods made of wholly recycled paper will now become subject to sales tax, while others will remain exempt.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that when the exemption was introduced in 1989 I warned that the legislation then was distorting it and that it went against an Industry Commission interim report which established that recycling was not automatically environmentally friendly and that there were not clear definitions or measures. Unfortunately, this is still the position.

Therefore, the coalition supports this Bill. In the Bill the Government acknowledges that the exemptions introduced by it in 1989 have failed to fulfil their stated purpose. I remind the Senate, as this is an appropriate occasion, that the Fightback proposal to abolish the wholesale sales tax and other taxes and replace it with a uniform goods and services tax also has the effect, as from 1 October 1994, of removing the exemption, because it will create a level playing field.

In 1989, when the exemption was granted, the Government actually chose to ignore the interim report, coalition warnings and the subsequent full Industry Commission report on paper recycling. The predictions have proved to be correct and we now see the Government seeking to address the problems which it created. The previous decision to exempt certain 100 per cent recycled paper products from sales tax was taken largely from misplaced environmentalist ideals with no prior consultation with the mainstream industry. Mr Baldwin, the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Following from the Industry Commission's report on recycling, the Government has decided that the sales tax exemption would remain but be narrowed to address the problems that have arisen and to direct better the measure to environmental concerns. For example high quality waste paper is used in the manufacture of tissues and paper bags which cannot be recycled again. This high quality waste paper could be used in other products such as writing papers, which can now be recycled several times.

This was the essence of the warning that we on this side of politics delivered in 1989 on the basis of the industry predictions in the interim report. But at the time the Government chose to ignore the interim report and has now fallen back on the full report which has come up with the same conclusion. The trouble is that, in the meantime, industries have actually grown up on the basis of the exemption which had existed. That is not surprising.

PARA.TAB: For these reasons, which I shall detail in a moment, the coalition, while supporting the removal of the exemption—because that was our original contention—also supports the introduction of a bounty which will compensate the industries which have developed on the basis that the exemption was going to ensure their viability.

Under the proposed legislation as it now stands, the following three items made from 100 per cent recyclable paper which were exempt will become subject to sales tax: books of blank, lined or graph paper used for writing or drawing; toilet tissue and facial tissue; and paper bags marketed for household purposes or for use in the marketing of goods sold by retail. However, the following products will remain exempt from sales tax—and I think it is important to note the distinction: writing and drawing paper, pads of writing and drawing paper, paper for use in accounting ledgers and journals, and envelopes. The removal of the exemption is expected to result in a gain to revenue of $11m in 1992-93 and $12m in the next year.

Approximately 900,000 tonnes of paper are recycled in Australia annually. This is a not insignificant figure. It amounts to just under 33 per cent of the paper used each year. The general recovery rate of paper products for recycling was just under 31 per cent. I think this exposes as myth the theory that recycling is new and only a small component of the total paper usage in this country.

The Industry Commission report indicated that, while no tissue products were recycled because there is not the length of fibre to give the required strength to the recyclable product, printing and writing papers made from recycled paper were often used again because of the strength of the tissue.

The executive director of the Pulp and Paper Manufacturers Federation of Australia is reported as stating that in 1990-91 nearly 45 per cent of the fibre materials used to make paper came from waste paper. This figure is expected to rise to 53 per cent by 1994-95. Australia's performance in recycling is good by world standards and will be rated very good as recycling in general increases when the recycling of more newspapers and magazines is carried out in the new de-inking plant at Albury and Shoalhaven, currently the subject of an environmental impact statement.

Australia's current recovery rate of waste paper is about 37 per cent; and it is expected to rise to 43 per cent in 1995 when the Albury plant is operating. For a country which has large imports of paper, this is a very good performance compared with countries such as the United States, Germany, the UK and Sweden.

A spokesman for the Australian Conservation Foundation has indicated that the use of recycled paper has increased since the introduction of the exemption from 3 per cent to 90 per cent in respect of exercise books and from one per cent to 9 per cent for toilet tissues. This must be seen as a good thing for our industry and our environment and it must not be taken away by changes in sales tax law.

No-one would deny the desirability of the efficient use of resources and protecting the environment or the desirability of the theoretically economic and environmentally friendly use of recyclable products. However, the situation that we have before us at the moment is not all that simple. The Democrats are assuming, quite naively as they sometimes do, that any recycling must really be best for the environment. Unfortunately, in terms of priority, the concerns of industry and jobs for Australians are placed well down the agenda.

We can understand how many people of goodwill believe that an exemption such as the one we have before us will lead to increased recycling of waste paper. While there has undoubtedly been an influence in that direction, the outcome for Australia has not been economically favourable. Also, it is not clear whether the outcome of the exemption, if pursued to its popularly desired conclusion—that is, more recycling—is always environmentally sound or friendly.

For example, the Government has discovered to its pain that it is not a simple matter of recycling paper and creating benefits for the environment, because there are some problems. A number of factors make some recycling economically and environmentally costly. The first of these, which is indicated in the Industry Commission report, is the de-inking process. This process itself creates salt problems, particularly in inland areas. Chemicals in waste paper become concentrated when recycled, and the process itself requires chemical usage. This matter of whether all recycling per se is ultimately best for the environment is an important consideration.

A second important consideration is what I refer to as cost efficiency in pure dollar terms. When considering both the environmental cost and the dollar cost, it must be noted that the recycling of paper is also not necessarily energy efficient. Each operation must actually be examined on its merits. Because of collection and sorting costs and the attendant energy requirements, it is in some cases more efficient to use virgin paper or fibres.

The Industry Commission report warned that the introduction of the discriminatory buying policies and tax concessions for recycling mandated targets purely to promote recycling would instead increase costs to traditional paper recyclers and increase imports of recycled paper to satisfy the regulations. This would be an unfortunate side effect. But that is exactly what has happened. For example, APM, which manufactures paper bags, used 40 per cent recyclable paper long before recycling became a trendy notion. But it has been undercut by imports which purport to be 100 per cent recycled paper to attract the sales tax exemption. The important words are `purport to be', because this is where the difficulty lies.

With respect to economics, the exemption has fostered a surge of imports of paper products claiming—this is difficult to identify because of the massive quantities of pulp—to be 100 per cent recycled. This is not necessarily the case. Unfortunately, the local production of some paper products has been adversely affected. The hard fact of life in this recessionary environment is that up to 400 jobs could be lost unless the Government's decision to remove the exemption is maintained. Naturally, we thank the Government for saving those jobs through this legislation.

To make matters worse, there is no known technical method of analysing the recyclable fibre content of paper and therefore no way of knowing whether these imports actually contain 100 per cent recyclable fibres. Even if they do, a principal outcome of the exemption has been to increase recycling in overseas countries and not in Australia. In the longer run, if regulation or taxing instruments force more recycling, the quality of many Australian-made paper products will decline because of the decreasing availability of good quality waste paper. This will lead to an even greater penetration of imports which are not similarly constrained.

In summary on this point, there is a very significant problem in that there is no way to substantiate the claims and it is doubtful in some cases whether all of the 100 per cent recyclable material is fibre. We have a situation where imports of dubious status have been able to undercut Australian products. That is just not on. An added problem is that there is an anomaly in the definition of recyclable paper, which allows paper made from all virgin fibres to be defined as recyclable paper because of the normal breaking down process used in paper manufacturing. Paper mill broke, the technical term for paper that does not meet quality standards and never leaves the mill but which is then pulped, can be counted as recyclable paper and can even attract the exemption, under the definition we have. There is a problem with the definition.

A final problem with the concept of the definition is that from an environmental perspective it is becoming clearer, as scientists examine the full environmental impact of recycling, that recycling for its own sake may not provide the best environmental outcome in terms of emissions of greenhouse gases. Recycling, like all other industrial processes, consumes non-renewable energy and generates carbon dioxide, both in its production and in the transport of waste paper to processing plants. The whole recycling process has to be compared with the production of paper from virgin fibres to determine which is the most favourable, taking into account life cycle considerations of all the environmental parameters.

For these sorts of reasons, the exemption should never have been introduced in the way it was. The products that will continue to attract exemption are those that can be repeatedly recycled with environmental and economic efficiency. The problem that now remains, having identified that the exemption never should have been allowed and that there are complications with it, is that paper manufacturers are divided as to the effects the changes will have on their operations. A primary consideration for the coalition was the concern that a number of companies had relied on the exemption in making investment and management decisions. For them, the Government's withdrawal of the exemption without giving those companies any time to adjust is quite unreasonable. Investments have been made and operations commenced on the basis of the exemption.

Perhaps the best illustrative point is to quote an operator, Austissue Pty Ltd in Western Australia, which could have stood to lose a great deal unless its particular problems were addressed. For example, Austissue, which commenced operations in September 1989, is the company that introduced tissue made from 100 per cent high grade waste paper in Australia. That is very commendable. Subsequently, other manufacturers have started producing recyclable tissue products, but I believe Austissue remains the only manufacturer exclusively producing 100 per cent recyclable tissue products. Austissue's operation involves four stages: waste paper collecting and sorting; paper manufacture of jumbo rolls; conversion of jumbo rolls to finished product; and sales and marketing of both jumbo rolls and finished product—for example, toilet rolls and facial tissues.

The particular needs of this company and any other in the same situation must be addressed with a great deal of consideration and care. In relation to the timetable for the granting of the exemption which is now to be removed, in July 1989 the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced that certain 100 per cent recycled paper products would be exempt from sales tax and the legislation was proclaimed in January 1990. Shortly after this time all State governments announced various measures in support of recycled products. In the main, these measures revolved around two key elements: firstly, the collection and re-manufacture of recyclables; and, secondly, government purchase of recycled products. Quite a number of the envelopes and pads used by senators in this Parliament come from recycled products.

Since that time, the Federal Government has made several pronouncements confirming its commitment to the environment and recycling. Recent examples were the Prime Minister's address at the launch of the waste minimisation and recycling strategy on 22 June 1992; the environment summit in Rio de Janeiro; and a letter from the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to the Australian Conservation Foundation in September 1991 stating that she would oppose an amendment of this nature. There was then what is known as the `Be Smart' recycling campaign.

The intention to lift the sales tax exemption on certain recycled products which has been set up on the basis of these moves is inconsistent with the Government's publicly stated position—unless there can be some additional measure, such as is proposed, to ensure continuing viability of these measures. The Government should continue to exempt, or in some way subsidise as we have proposed, all paper products made from 100 per cent recycled paper, providing it is post-consumer waste—that is, it has already been used for its primary purpose prior to being recycled.

Typically, the waste paper used by Austissue to manufacture tissue already had sales tax paid on it in its original life. In line with the Government's policy, the directors of Austissue have committed the company and all of its resources to pursuing exclusively the manufacture of 100 per cent recycled tissue products. The imposition of what is effectively a 20 per cent price increase on its product naturally has very serious consequences for its viability and its future.

When delivering his second reading speech, the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Mr Baldwin, whom I quoted earlier, was not technically correct in saying that each time paper is recycled the paper is partially degraded. The contention that paper can be viably recycled only `several times' is not quite correct, as a certain content of new long fibres which have not been shortened in the recycling processes is needed. In addition, approximately 40 per cent of the waste paper used by Austissue is not considered suitable for the manufacture of printing and writing paper. To date, the manufacturers of recycled printing and writing paper have been reluctant to take previously recycled paper for re-manufacture.

Part of the reason why the Government seeks to lift the exemption on toilet and facial tissues is its concern that recycled products are being imported into Australia and there are strong reasons to believe that most of those products do not conform to any reasonable definition of recycled. The production of tissue from recycled materials is in its infancy in Australia. It has been said by the Prime Minister on talkback radio that a window of opportunity was provided and now, after two years, it has given the industry adequate time to establish itself. It should be noted that a majority of businesses fail in the first three years and it takes five years to achieve any reasonable level of maturity. It is also a fact that at the same time the window of opportunity was opened, the economy entered the most severe recession in 60 years and interest rates reached abnormally high levels.

Part of the rationale for allowing the exemption, misplaced though it turned out to be, was to provide a domestic recycling industry and the attendant jobs and services it would require. Another significant reason was the Government's commitment to substantially reduce the amount of paper going to land-fill refuse sites.

Austissue has invested around $7m, or possibly more, to take advantage of the current sales tax exemption and claims it will lose that investment and need to lay off 40 staff in the event of the tax preferred arrangement being removed. Austissue and several other companies committed themselves only on the basis of the Government's policy of sales tax exemption for their products. These industries are not demanding subsidies but a set of rules which are predictable and workable under which they can operate, and that is not unreasonable. There will be a resultant increase in unemployment from the moving of the goalposts, and the coalition is recommending and supporting a bounty system which will encourage and enable the degree of recycling which is operative in these situations to continue and help to offset the effects of the rule change.

In response to indications that the coalition may oppose the legislation, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) approached the coalition suggesting that the Government could meet the concerns through a special purpose payment to the relevant State government—for passing on to the producer—equal to the estimated wholesales tax on the product of the producer in the year ending 30 June 1992 that would have been payable had it not been for the sales tax exemption. So it is expected that the Government will extend this arrangement to let it run down over a couple of years.

On the other hand, companies such as APM are requesting that the exemption be removed so that the 20 per cent tax on recycled brown paper bags will bring them into line with white paper production. The APM situation highlights the problems with the original legislation and demonstrates the need for the removal of the exemption. APM is the only manufacturer of these paper bags in Australia and contends that it is unable to manufacture 100 per cent white paper bags due to the technical properties of Australian white paper. APM has indicated that this business, amounting to $20m worth of sales per annum and involving the employment of between 44 and 60 Australians directly, has been put on hold pending the removal of the sales tax because of the so-called 100 per cent recycled paper bag imported from various overseas countries.

Within the 570,000-plus tonnes of post-consumer wastepaper which APM uses in the manufacture of paper products in Australia, a considerable volume is white recycled paper. This waste grade, regardless of the sales tax situation, is in short supply and is used for the manufacture of folding carton boards, white lined corrugated boxes, envelope paper, photography paper, forms and listing paper. The high content of short eucalypt fibres makes the wastepaper unsuitable to give the manufactured bag its necessary tear strength. This means that the Australian white wastepaper cannot be used in this process. This contention by APM has been confirmed by the CSIRO Division of Forest Products, and it has said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . mixed white wastepaper collected in Australia is not suitable for 100% recycling into bag papers. The strength results (in APM tests) are entirely reasonable, as mixed white wastepaper in Australia is dominated by writing and printing grades which have relatively low strength requirements.

The National Association of Forest Industries Ltd has expressed support for the Bill on the grounds that a number of Australian companies have lost a substantial share of the market for recycled paper products because of the surge of imports attracted by the sales tax exemption. This in turn has put at risk a number of jobs in the pulp and paper industry. Australian Paper Mills has indicated, as I mentioned previously, that it could shed up to 44 employees if the removal of the sales tax exemption as proposed in the Bill does not go ahead. But I believe that with the support of the Opposition it will now go ahead.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, the sales tax exemption on recycled paper should never have come into existence, and naturally must go. But the industries which have developed on the basis of the measures which were introduced should not suddenly have the rug pulled out from under them and should be given some consideration. It is for this reason that the coalition is suggesting that a bounty be offered to offset the cost of the sales tax exemption, to be gradually phased down as the industry naturally becomes more established.

The changes which the Government has introduced in this piece of legislation reflect its casting around for a mooring in the whole sales tax area. A climate of uncertainty and distortion has been created which will disappear, I remind the Senate, under the GST regime advocated by the coalition with the removal of a raft of taxes, including the notorious wholesale sales tax.

It is interesting to note that, although there will be no exemption for these industries under the GST, the firms affected have no problems with this because they are well aware of the offsetting benefits in the Fightback package. These benefits will solve the dilemma which exists in the different areas of paper manufacturing with respect to sales tax, because there will be a climate of security and prosperity for all sections of the industry and its employees. Unlike the Government's vacillating actions, which will have a cascading, retrospective effect, the Fightback package is on the table and the industries have been able to calculate the gains for Australians ahead of time. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have heard, this piece of legislation—the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1992—proposes to remove the sales tax exemption which currently exists for toilet and facial tissues, exercise books and some types of paper bags which are made from 100 per cent recycled paper. In removing that exemption, what it really means is that it will impose a 20 per cent tax on the wholesale value of these products.This will wipe out the advantages which consumers have enjoyed by being able to purchase these goods at competitive prices. Indeed, I would argue that in some cases it will wipe out the market for some of these products, but I will return to that later.

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators will recall, we have recently passed a reform package of Bills which streamlined—in fact, totally rewrote—the sales tax system. This system will come into effect on 1 January. After that package was released in May, this separate Bill appeared, I would say, completely out of the blue—no warning, no consultation with the industries which would be affected and, I believe, no attempt by this Government to assess the effect of this Bill on those industries.

The contents of the Bill arise from the efforts of the Industry Commission—the good old economic, rationalist Industry Commission—to remove what it calls the distortion of preferential taxation for recycling. The Industry Commission recommended that the total concession for recycled paper products should be removed.This Bill removes some of the exemptions—that is, those which do not benefit the major paper manufacturers—but it keeps in place the concession in respect of certain writing papers.

The Democrats support the other items remaining exempt. I simply make the point that this legislation is clearly favouring big manufacturers against smaller operators. I believe it has been tailor-made to fit the corporate objectives of some of the large firms.

Having said that, let us look at the environmental arguments the Government has used to justify this decision. There are two categories of items. First, the termination of the exemption for exercise books is inexplicable. Writing papers made from 100 per cent recycled paper will continue to be exempt, but if the same paper has a piece of cardboard stapled to it and is bent to form an exercise book shape, it—the same paper—will be taxable. There is no consistent policy thread for that decision. I can only conclude that the Government is willing to deliberately advantage some producers.

The second group of affected products is the so-called single use items—facial and toilet tissues and paper bags. The rationale we have been given for opposing tax concessions for these single use products, I think, is completely spurious. The argument is that it is a waste of recycled paper to use it in an item that can be used only once. The Government says that writing papers can be recycled many times, so it is only these kinds of products that should obtain concessions. But the argument is flawed. I point to the evidence by Mr Dunne of the Paper Converting Company that, whilst papers can be recycled four or five times, they cannot be recycled into writing papers that many times. The multiple recycling that people speak of with praise is basically for cardboard. It is not possible to recycle writing papers into writing papers many times over.

If it is a waste to use recycled paper, that is, paper which has previously been used at least once, on a single use item—and that is the justification the Industry Commission and the Government are giving us—then surely it must be a greater waste to use virgin fibre in a single use item. With recycled paper there has been at least one prior use. I think one could argue that, because of this particular Bill, there will be a switch to virgin fibre in these products. The Government says, `That's okay because we support sustainably managed plantation based virgin fibre production'. The Democrats also support sustainable paper production, but surely it is better to sustainably produce the paper, then use it once, then use it in a single use item, than simply to use it first in a non-recyclable, end of use product. The whole environmental argument mounted by the Government is plainly wrong—totally unconvincing.

The Government said the problem is that the concession is being abused by some falsely labelled imports. During the hearings of the Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation I asked a Tax Office official what the figures were for imports of recycled paper on which this assertion was based. I was told that the Government does not have any figures, that the figures are not actually disaggregated. What is the Government relying on? Is it relying on the claims of the major producers, those in competition with the small Australian owned producers in this case? If imports are the problem, why do we not look at the problem with imports? Why do we not introduce an accreditation scheme? It is possible to do that. It could be policed by Environmental Choice Australia. Why do we not do this to stop false advertising? We do not need to eliminate the concession. I do not believe the Government has explored this option seriously enough.

On the political side, one of the real problems with this legislation is the way in which it was introduced out of the blue, late at night on 25 June. The concession was withdrawn from midnight that night and many small Australian firms found their whole market had been significantly altered. There is some case for making sales tax changes apply from the date of announcement in the Budget context, and I know that is the usual practice. One can justify it because the matter is well publicised, so the views of non-government members can be publicly known and the matter is then usually dealt with by the Parliament fairly promptly. But in this case it has been a totally different matter.

This announcement was made, the Bill was introduced, just before the long winter recess. It has been in the Parliament for almost four months. For four months these small operators have been operating in a climate of total uncertainty. They have had a market significantly altered by this proposal. To wait four months is very bad public policy. The Democrats opposed this legislation from the start because we believe sales tax should have the ability to discriminate and to bring about socially and environmentally just objectives.

We successfully conducted some public hearings on this matter in the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax. Mr John Pedlar from Austissue, Mr Dunne from the Paper Converting Company and Mr Felderbaum from Packmore Merchandising gave evidence of the effects of this proposal on their small businesses. Their main complaint was the timing of this proposal—quite rightly pointing out that they had made investment decisions committing themselves to millions of dollars, in some cases, following the Government's publicised intention to maximise the extent of recycling in Australia. The impact on their sales in the July and August months has been quite devastating—and all of this because of a Bill which was not even law at the time.

The Opposition members on the Committee were, I think, quite persuaded by the evidence of these witnesses. I understood, and I am sure the Opposition members said, that they were going to oppose this Bill, and we were happy with that decision. We thought that the matter was over and so did the small business people. But then, of course, the lobbyists from the big companies went to work on the Opposition, not in the Senate but in the House of Representatives. And I am sorry to say that the Opposition crumbled.

Mr Reith went to see Mr Dawkins and then the Opposition made a deal—one of those things that, according to the Opposition, are done only between Democrats and the Government. Funny that, is it not? In this case the Opposition, I believe, sold out the interests of the Australian owned small businesses, and reversed its position completely. Although this did not get much publicity, it was certainly an education to the small businesses concerned. I know that they feel quite disillusioned about the Opposition's support for big business over small business.

The Democrats were in an isolated position in this. We had been confident that this legislation would be defeated. Suddenly these small producers were totally vulnerable again. So we, not the Opposition, negotiated a compensation package with the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). Our package involves a bounty type payment to affected Australian manufacturers for three financial years. I seek leave to have some correspondence on these matters incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 9 September 1992
Senator J Coulter
Leader of the Australian Democrats
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Coulter

Following our discussions yesterday evening, I write to propose transitional assistance for Australian producers of 100% recycled paper products affected by the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1992. One such producer is Austissue.

I propose that transitional assistance be provided for three years. That assistance would be effected by way of special purpose payments to the relevant State Governments, for passing on to the producers.

The first payments, to be made as soon as practicable, would be calculated on the basis of the estimated wholesale sales tax that would have been paid on the product of the producers in the year ending 30 June 1992 if that product had not been exempt from wholesale sales tax.

The second and third payments, to be made in July 1993 and July 1994, would be equal to three quarters and one half, respectively, of the first payments. Any continuation of these payments beyond July 1994 would be subject to a review by the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency.
I trust that these arrangements would be satisfactory.
I am sending a copy of this letter to Senator Kernot.
Yours sincerely
John Dawkins
9 September 1992
9 September 1992
Hon. John Dawkins
Treasurer
Parliament House
Canberra, ACT 2600
Dear Mr. Dawkins,

As discussed during my telephone conversation with your adviser Nigel Ray this afternoon, we are agreed on the following interpretation of the rates of bounty payments to Australian producers of 100% recycled paper products affected by the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classification) Amendment Bill 1992, as outlined in your letter to me of today's date.

The first payments, as you have said, would be calculated on the basis of the estimated wholesale sales tax that would have been paid on the product of the producers in the year ending 30 June 1992 if that product had not been exempt from wholesale sales tax.
The second payment, to be made in July 1993, would be equal to three quarters of the wholesale sales tax paid on the product of the producers in the year ending 30 June 1993.
The third payment, to be made in July 1994, would be equal to one half of the wholesale sales tax paid on the product of the producers in the year ending 30 June 1994.
This interpretation, we are agreed, takes into account the fact that production is likely to rise in the years ending in June 1993 and June 1994.
I hope that, finally, we have clarified our position.
Yours sincerely,
John R. Coulter

TALK.START.PARA: —Although we are the first to admit that this compensation is not an optimal arrangement, it is still a recognition that the initial announcement was unfair. I commend the Treasurer for at least recognising the difficulties caused to Australian owned small industry by the effects of this Bill, and I am pleased that the bounty payments will be reviewed by the Commonwealth Environmental Protection Agency in 1994. If there is a case to be made for their extension, I hope it can be made. If not, in the meantime these small Australian owned producers can continue to operate in a climate of certainty and continue to provide to Australian consumers the access to recycled products which they have shown they want.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The preceding speakers have quite clearly enunciated the business of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1992. If passed, it will remove the sales tax exemption previously applicable to certain paper products made from 100 per cent recycled paper. The proposal is that the sales tax be applied retrospectively from 26 June. The motivation behind the Government's decision to introduce this Bill has already received discussion, and there seem to be two factors driving the action which have already been raised.

PARA.TAB: First, there appears to have been extensive lobbying, principally by foreign owned multinationals, regarding the removal of this sales tax from those people engaged in producing certain paper products. This is an inappropriate reason for the change to this tax. The firms that are likely to be putting pressure on both the Government and the Opposition are, naturally enough, those engaged in establishing a sustainable timber industry and timber products. While the Greens would certainly support such an approach to sustainable timber production and believe this is the way to go forward, we see it as utterly undesirable that it should come at the cost of penalising small Australian businesses that are also endeavouring to work in an environmentally friendly way.

The second factor that has been stated as underlying this decision is a well-founded concern that allegedly recycled products are being imported, mainly from Asia, in increasing numbers. There is doubt that the majority of these products conform to any reasonable definition of recycled paper and certainly do not comprise post-consumer waste paper. As Senator Kernot pointed out very clearly, the way to address that is to introduce quality controls and accreditation processes and to look very carefully at our import procedures. It is not, I say again, to penalise local Australian businesses.

This Bill can be seen only as an entirely retrograde step. Two and a half years ago the Government sponsored the development of recycled paper manufacturers by removing sales tax from their products and now is about to wind down one sector of the industry and thereby reduce the competition. This is a small niche market that does not really threaten the big players. It can be carried out locally, and it is very worthwhile for small businesses to be encouraged to go into this kind of venture, thereby broadening the manufacturing base of Australian industry in an environmentally sound direction. The Government is negating its undertaking to those companies that set themselves to fill the market niche. It is simply not good enough for the Government to walk away from these people and expect them to accept graciously offers of compensation. This switch away from supporting that part of the industry and throwing titbits to those who are severely penalised by this Bill does not look at the issue of future encouragement for similar businesses and local manufacturing projects bases on recycling.As stated before, if the Government were serious about reducing the amount of allegedly recycled products that are being imported, it could use other methods of control.

When demand for high quality recycled waste for recycling into writing paper outstrips the supply, then the Government's decision to narrow the sales tax exemption will make sense. We are far from that at the present time. As the managing director of Austissue, a Western Australian-based company, said in a briefing note to me:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . approximately 40% of the waste paper used to make tissue is not considered suitable for manufacture of printing and writing paper and to date the manufacturers of recycled printing and writing paper have been reluctant to take recycled paper for re manufacture.

There is thus a vast amount that can be taken up that offers a very useful manufacturing base. Since Austissue commenced operation in September 1989, it has produced only 100 per cent recycled product from post-consumer waste paper. This equates to a saving of approximately 200,000 trees.

PARA.TAB: Part of the Government's objective in exempting 100 per cent recycled products from sales tax was to stimulate a local industry. What has happened to that expressed objective? Recent public actions, such as the Rio environment summit and the Be Smart recycling campaign, which has already been mentioned, are consistent with this theme. It is a double standard for the Government now to impose sales tax. It is a major contradictory signal being sent to businesses that are attempting to abide by the far-reaching aims and objectives of the environment summit.

At present it is not sensible to be shutting down a worthwhile sector of the industry, and I can only conclude that the Government is more interested in maintaining the domination of a few multinational companies. I applaud the moves made by Kimberly-Clark and others to shift to a fibre stock from plantation timber, and as a Green I would support any measures which add incentives to this. But penalising a small section of business is not the way to go.

The kind of rebalancing that seems to be holding weight with both the Government and Opposition is highly hypocritical. The availability of products which satisfy market demands while not relying on timber stock—rather, paper which would otherwise end up in landfill is used—must be seen as a positive step to making use of the oversupplied resource of once used paper. The process used is one that involves clean processes with little detrimental side effects. This is a shining example of the environmentally friendly and sound way in which employment can be created.

I feel very disappointed that this legislation, which severely penalises a section of Australian small business, is being supported by the Opposition. It puts the lie to the stance taken by members of the Opposition that they are supporting that sector. The Liberal Party in Western Australia indicated its support of this particular company, and the Opposition should be opposing this legislation. I can only express deep disappointment at the Opposition's support for the Government.

I am delighted that the Democrats are, appropriately, opposing this Government legislation. However, I am disappointed at the double standard shown by the Government in presenting this Bill, which I will be opposing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1992 seeks to remove the 20 per cent sales tax exemption on paper made from recycled fibre. I would remind the Senate that this approach to encourage recycling was initially made some years ago by the Democrats. When we first moved to remove that 20 per cent sales tax imposition on paper made from recycled fibre, we were opposed by both the Government and the Opposition. Only a short time afterwards the Government saw the political and electoral merit of supporting such a proposal, and it introduced legislation to differentiate between paper made from recycled fibre and paper made from virgin fibre.

PARA.TAB: As several speakers have already indicated, as a consequence of that differential several companies have established themselves in Australia. They have made very substantial investments, employ quite a considerable number of people and are making products made from recycled fibre. It is against that background that the Government has now chosen to introduce legislation to remove that differential with respect to certain products, and those products have already been enunciated.

Quite apart from what the legislation seeks to do, the way in which the Government has chosen to introduce this legislation is also reprehensible. Changes to sales tax law, for very good reasons, become effective once they have been introduced into the Parliament and before they are debated. Given that process, it would only be fair that legislation of this sort to change sales tax should be introduced early in a session so that it can be dealt with expeditiously, any objections can be properly rehearsed and a decision can be made.

In this case the Government chose to introduce this legislation into the House of Representatives on essentially the last day of sitting. We did not see the legislation in the Senate. As a consequence, the removal of this 20 per cent sales tax exemption has been imposed on companies for quite some considerable period. During that time there has been no opportunity whatsoever to debate the issues and seek either a change in the law, an amelioration of the application of the law or the sorts of solutions that have now been put in place in relation to a bounty.

Austissue in Western Australia, which employs some 40 people, has invested $7m—that is $7m of Australian investment—in making 100 per cent recycled tissue. There is also the paper converting company in Brisbane—again, making a large investment, employing people, and making a product everybody recognises as desirable. Those companies had that imposition placed upon them for a number of months before this legislation could be debated. Indeed, it is now October and we are now debating that legislation. I simply want to put on the record that if the Government is thinking in future of changing the sales tax laws in this way to severely embarrass and impact on companies that are operating in Australia, I ask it to do that early in a session so that the laws can be dealt with expeditiously and the matter sorted out once and for all.

Senator Watson made a considerable point about the increased percentage of recycling that has been going on in Australia. Some of that increased percentage is a direct consequence of the removal of that 20 per cent sales tax. That has been a significant inducement, particularly in the early days. I think everybody in this chamber will recall the considerable price differential, which discouraged even people of goodwill who wished to use recycled paper from using it because of the higher cost. The removal of the 20 per cent sales tax, which essentially brought recycled paper into line with paper made from virgin fibre, very significantly changed the pattern of use. As we all know, as increased amounts are used the unit costs come down, and that move, originally introduced by the Democrats, I believe has a lot to do with those increased percentages.

However, Senator Watson failed to mention that Australia, along with many other countries around the world, has very substantially increased its tonnage of paper used. Computers notoriously use enormous amounts of paper. So even though the percentage of fibre being recycled might be increasing, one needs to be aware of the absolute impact on forests, particularly native forests and old growth forests, an item Senator Chamarette referred to a few moments ago. That is where the point about ecologically sustainable development comes in. We simply cannot go on increasing indefinitely the impact in terms of tonnages. There is a point beyond which we cannot go, and that may equate with very high levels of recycling if the total tonnages become very large. One hopes that very shortly we will move in the other direction and will start reducing the tonnages as we get to the so-called paperless society.

The other point that bears very much on this issue is the importing of tissue paper, particularly from Asia, and that paper being claimed to be 100 per cent recycled when, as Senator Watson said when raising it, there are serious doubts about that paper being made from recycled fibre. There is a perfectly adequate mechanism that could have been used to counter that because, clearly, that is a case of dumping. If a product comes in and is being sold on the Australian market at a price below the proper price or where it is not the product it claims to be, we do have, through the Customs legislation, mechanisms for going into other countries and investigating whether those products are as claimed and whether the prices being charged on the Australian market are fair.

The Government chose not to invoke those mechanisms, so I believe that that is another black mark against it. It is prepared to do it in the commercial area, but it is evidently not prepared to do it for the protection of the environment.

Senator Watson was not quite correct when he talked about the difficulty of identifying whether fibre is recycled. My understanding is that it is simply impossible, for the reasons that Senator Watson mentioned, to satisfactorily make toilet tissue from totally recycled fibre unless there is sufficient fibre in the paper to give it the required strength, because the fibre tends to be short fibre.

As I also understand from Austissue in Western Australia, the toilet tissue which was being imported was of a weight—if I remember correctly, the figure is 9 grams per square metre—which would indicate that it simply could not have been 100 per cent recycled, because it would not have had the necessary burst strength. Austissue, with very modern technology—if I again recall the figure correctly—found it necessary to make toilet tissue of some 13 grams per square metre so that it would have the necessary strength. I certainly agree with Senator Chamarette in her claim that, in this respect also, there was very significant support for the larger multinational companies—Bowater Scott and Kimberly-Clark—whose profits substantially go overseas to the detriment of those smaller Australian companies that have really only recently entered the market as a direct consequence of the Government's legislation.

The amounts which were being put on the market by these companies were relatively small; we are really talking of less than 10,000 tonnes out of a total market of some 130,000 tonnes in the toilet tissue area. So neither of these companies, at least at this stage, could have seriously claimed that these Australian companies were a threat to their viability. Nonetheless, they sought through this Government a mechanism to seriously impede their development.

Senator Watson's next point related to an assessment of the total environmental impact of recycling. I can only agree entirely with what he said in this respect. In all aspects of industry, particularly in relation to recycling, we should be looking at the total environmental impacts. In detailing things like the transport costs involved in returning paper to factories, the de-inking process and the chemicals which are used, Senator Watson really told us only half the story. A comprehensive evaluation would look at the totality of paper making, paper use and paper recycling and would therefore have a very significant impact on the way in which paper is made in the first place, the sorts of products that are made and the sorts of inks that are used.

As the environmental imperative goes back into that initial manufacturing process under the incentive to reduce total impacts, one will see that the methods of manufacture in the first instance and the sorts of inks that are being used and so on will come under modification. I stress again that, in a comprehensive evaluation of total environmental impacts, we must bear in mind that there are limits on the total amount of paper that we can use, given the problems with the forests.

I want to pick up on a couple of other points. A point made by Senator Kernot needs stressing. We strongly defend the use of the sales tax mechanism as a policy instrument. One of the clear advantages of the sales tax mechanism over the Fightback GST proposal is that, in one case, one can vary the wholesale sales tax to achieve certain desirable objectives, be they environmental or social. In the other case, one simply has a 15 per cent tax across the board.

It simply does not wash, as Senator Watson tried to argue, that because there are other benefits associated with Fightback—we do not need to go into what those benefits are—there is no ability to differentiate between one product and another or one process and another so that we encourage one particular process and encourage industry to move in a particular direction. That is one of the fundamental defects of that across-the-board 15 per cent GST proposal.

We would argue very strongly that the wholesale sales tax regime, as complex as it is, is philosophically a far sounder way to go because it allows that differential. We believe that it should be used more widely. Honourable senators will recall, in relation to the reduction in sales tax on motor vehicles, that we argued very strongly that that reduction in sales tax again should be made dependent upon the fuel efficiency of the vehicles so that sales tax would become a very powerful instrument for moving our economy in desirable directions, whether that desirable direction is determined by environmental, social, economic or any other agreed objective.

The legislation before us removes this 20 per cent sales tax. We find it quite unsatisfactory. However, in view of the unwillingness of the Government to reverse its stance, as Senator Kernot has indicated, we negotiated with the Government. As a consequence, the Government has agreed—and the letter has already been tabled—that there remain in place a differential between paper made from recycled fibre and paper made from virgin fibre and that that differential be 20 per cent in the first year, 15 per cent in the second and 10 per cent in the third.
