In the meantime, there will be a review by the EPA in relation to the desirability of maintaining, in some more permanent way, some differential and, furthermore, that that bounty be paid to Australian companies.

While this process is less than satisfactory, nonetheless, in negotiating this agreement with the Government, we have achieved two desirable objectives. We have maintained that differential which will stay in place for at least three years during which there is a review and, at the same time, the bounty is targeted to Australian companies so that it overcomes the problem of the importation of paper claiming to be made from recycled fibre when there are very serious and legitimate doubts as to whether that is the case.

We see this as second best but we are arguing that it is better than nothing and it is the best that could be negotiated under the circumstances with a government that was not prepared to use the other mechanisms which we believe could have been used under Customs legislation to stop dumping and to give a more permanent support to recycling.

TALK.START.PARA: —And an opposition that was prepared to support the Government.

—As Senator Kernot has just quietly interjected behind me, in view of the fact that the Opposition collapsed in its opposition to this legislation and was prepared to support this legislation, under those circumstances, this was the best that could be negotiated. We simply put on the record that this proposal is second best but it is better than nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for very long. It is important for me to put on record my strong opposition to this extremely retrograde move by the Labor Government, a move which comes not so long after the progressive move that it made after pressure both from the Australian Democrats and from the environment movement to exempt in the first place recycled paper products from sales tax.

PARA.TAB: The debate has outlined the pressures which have been brought to bear—those pressures which are coming from major multinational oligopolists in the paper industry and also the excuses which have been given for this move. The issue of products dumped from overseas is not even an excuse which can be used across the board as being a bad thing for Australian industry. I want to put on the record a letter from Castrol Australia which, I gather from the introductory section, was sent to other members of the Senate quite early in the discussion of this legislation on 27 August. It was also sent to me and it asked that this legislation be opposed. It made the point that:

SPEECH.PARA: We introduced, albeit product imported from Sweden and Holland, "jumbo" toilet rolls and towels made from recycled paper, to the commercial and industrial markets in Australia. This initiative gave impetus to the development of the local industry, and now not only toilet rolls and hand wipes but industrial wipes made from recycled paper are providing significant benefits to all of Australia.
The point is that, initially, this company used the advantage of the exemption to import
product but that led and gave impetus to the development of small business in this country, as has been outlined elsewhere in this debate. So even that excuse falls down.

PARA.TAB: As has been pointed out, the Government had, and still has, other mechanisms available to it—mechanisms which it would have to use in the defence of these new Australian industries and environmentally sound small businesses which are providing products for an Australian community which wants to use them. It would have to use those mechanisms through trade and customs regulations and anti-dumping measures—and I would add labelling measures which are also necessary both for imported and Australian products—if indeed this legislation were to be defeated at this second reading stage, as I believe it should be.

The economic rationalism which we hear so often from the Industry Commission and which has been so rampant in this Parliament under this Government is with us again today in this iniquitous piece of legislation. If there is ever a level playing field—and that is probably the greatest myth of all—then it should be tilted in the interests of the survival of the planet. As Senator Coulter has said and as I have heard Senator McMullan, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, who is in charge here today, articulate very lucidly, one of the major advantages of the wholesale sales tax regime is the ability to tilt the playing field, whether it is level or not, in the interests of social, environmental or economic benefit to the community.

Certainly, the question of recycled paper products is one of those areas. I attended a meeting launching a recycled paper product at which Senator McMullan spoke, I think within a week of the release of the Fightback program. He made that point very strongly at that meeting and I wish he were making that point as strongly here today.

This area of recycling, whether it is of paper or other products, is one of those areas where we must tilt the playing field. We are tilting it back in the wrong direction here and, what is worse, it is in the interests of oligopolists; it is not in the interests of Australian small business and it is not in the interests of Australian consumers because, in the end, the people who want to use recycled products are the ones who will be caught in the grip of the oligopolists who can then have a strong market influence.

The initial measure to exempt recycled paper products across the board was one which we saw create a burgeoning industry; provide product for interested consumers; and generally have a positive benefit, except for those major companies. They have reared up on their hind legs, supported by the Industry Commission and, regrettably, by the Government and the Opposition. I am opposed to this legislation and I do not think it should even be given a second reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make two observations on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1992. The first is that this is a classic example of the Government's arrogant disregard for the proper processes of government so as to create a proper, predictable environment in which businesses can make proper commercial decisions. I think that it was originally Senator Puplick who proposed the abolition of the 20 per cent tax on recycled paper.
—I introduced that, Senator.

—The Democrats will claim that they had a prior mortgage on that view; I shall not debate that issue. Suffice to say that the Labor Government was last to come on board. Somebody once said, `It is better to be in the last carriage than not be on the train at all'. Having now come on board, the sales tax has been off, then on and now some wishy-washy compromise which, quite frankly, falls between two stools. The decision in the first place by the Government to take off the 20 per cent tax was driven by circumstances of political expediency in a climate where the economy was not perceived to be in such a terrible, diabolical mess as it is now. The Government understood that for its own survival it had to garner up the Green vote and attract their second preferences, and so it continued to do these spiffy deals in an attempt to maintain its survival.

PARA.TAB: Having done that and moved into a different environment, the Government has chosen now to change the rules. The sad thing about these decisions is that they totally disrupt business in Australia. When one talks about business, one is talking about the standard of living and jobs for ordinary workers—the people that the Government proclaims that it represents.

Austissue has been referred to today and it is perhaps the most eloquent example that I can give. It is a company that understood and knew in its own mind the ground rules. It is a company that decided to set up a discrete business exclusively on the basis of the tax regime at the time to produce a product from recycled paper and enter into a very competitive environment. As a result of that decision, it invested some $7m, $8m or $10m. It has a work force of some 40 people—a dedicated, efficient, effective and loyal group who are all good Western Australians. The company believed at the time that the ground rules would not be shifted.

We all know that when businesses make decisions about investment they make them on the basis of stability of government, probable stability of the economic environment and certainly of decisions. It was in that environment and on that basis no doubt that this business was set up only to find that the rules have now been changed.

As has been observed by somebody else, sales tax is already paid on the product that the business is producing. The net effect is that sales tax is being paid twice. It is not only the argument about the environment but also the argument about the equality of the tax. This operation would not have commenced if this company had known the rules were to change or had known it was to end up with this compromise.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly the sort of company we should not have.

—Of course it is the sort of company we ought to have in Australia. I will conclude on one other point, because I promised to speak for no more than five minutes, and that is to take up the point that somebody else has made that the argument that some of the products being imported into Australia allegedly as recycled products may not be can be tested in another way, as Senator Coulter has said.

PARA.TAB: The Government has chosen not to take that path and now we find that the sales tax has, in the long term, been re-imposed and businesses can only make decisions on the basis of what they believe will be the circumstances in the long term. In this case, this business, retrospectively, made a bad decision but in the circumstances at the time, with all the known facts, it appeared to be making the right decisions.

The sadness is that this Government thinks it can capriciously change the rules whenever it likes; that it can govern by fiat; and that a press statement put out by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), giving no more than basic rules, will allow businesses to understand the environment in which they have to work. If we are going to attract businesses into this country, there has to be certainty about one thing, and that is legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a certain amount of rewriting of history going on in the most recent part of this debate on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1992, and I would like to come back to comment on that before I conclude.Firstly, I will go to the questions of general principle that are involved in the debate about this legislation which some other senators have referred to also.

PARA.TAB: There are fundamentally two related questions that we need to answer. One is: should the tax system—and, in this case, the indirect tax system—be able to discriminate between products on the grounds of their environmental, social or other desirability? The second is: if the system has that capacity, should a government as a consequence be prepared to assess the merits of the matter and make a decision to exercise that right to discriminate?

My view is, clearly, that the answer is yes. That is why I oppose the goods and services tax which the Opposition is proposing to introduce, and the manner in which it is proposing to introduce it. That is why at least what Senator Watson said, with which I disagree, was consistent with the Opposition's policy, which is more than I can say for Senator Crichton-Browne. It is the case that the capacity to discriminate is an important distinction that the Australian people have before them in assessing the competing indirect tax systems that are being contemplated. It is a factor that they should take into account when they consider who they think should next govern.

The environment is not the only element in which discrimination should be possible, but it is one. The goods and services tax claims as a virtue that it does not discriminate. It claims as a virtue that it will put the relative price of solar panels up compared with all other sources of household heating, and that it will do away with the exemption on other environmentally desirable products, including those aspects of recycled paper that will remain wholesale sales tax exempt after this amendment is passed. There will still be a substantial amount of recycled paper that will be wholesale sales tax exempt and on which the goods and services tax would apply which, on Senator Crichton-Browne's criteria, is called changing the rules after companies have made investments.

I do not wish to debate that tangent. The substantial point is, yes, that right to discrimination should continue, and it does. That does not mean that every element that is put into a regime, on the basis of an assessment about what discrimination should exist, should be immutable.The particular discriminations need continually to be assessed to look at their impact. It is a question of social, environment and economic cost benefit. It is not just, `We thought that this was the most appropriate route, therefore, we should inexorably continue down it, even if the evidence tends to point to the fact that it is not achieving its purpose.'

The wholesale sales tax is not, in very many circumstances, the most effective measure for these sorts of discriminations. It is appropriate on some occasions and it is used and its capacity to be used is desirable. It is similar to income tax: it is not, in the normal course, the best manner of providing assistance to industry or to other socially desirable objectives, but sometimes it is and it needs to be used. There is no particular argument about that. All sides of the Parliament, to a greater or lesser extent, support the use of tax concessions in the income tax area to, for example, encourage research and development. But we need to be selective, considered and specific about where and how we use that discrimination—which we should retain but which the Opposition proposes, should it be elected, to abolish.

It is a question of social, environmental and economic cost-benefit. That therefore requires a very substantial targeting of the measures that are used. That is essentially what this amendment is about. It is about better directing the exemption to achieve the purposes for which the original exemption was put in place. The original broad exemption had no discernible effect on the recycling rates of Australian papers. There is nothing in the data that I have seen to indicate a major change in the rate of increase of utilisation, but it did divert waste paper from its previous uses into the manufacture of things such as tissues and toilet papers and it also led to a boom in imports of certain paper goods.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you could have done something about it.

—I am going to talk in a moment about what could be done about it. I do not want to divert to that very much, because it is a very secondary question. However, it is relevant and I want to say something about it. The Government has mentioned it as an issue and several senators, in speaking in the debate, have mentioned it. So I will refer to it, but I do not think it is the core issue. It is a matter of concern because the imports had some potential economic impact in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The other point that has been made which has been accepted fairly broadly—I do not know about universally—in the debate is that, while recycling is essentially desirable and it is appropriate that we should be taking action as governments and as citizens to encourage recycling, not every recycling action is environmentally beneficial. It is a question of judgment to say, `Is the recycling that is involved here going to use more resources in the process of recycling than might otherwise be used in the production of this particular output with some other mechanism for so producing it?'. It is a question of judgment.

We could recycle almost everything if we were prepared to use enough resources in the recycling process but, on a net basis, that may not be environmentally desirable. It is a flavour of the month issue, and that is desirable. It is very good that recycling is the flavour of the month issue, but it does not mean we should lower our rigorous standards of analysis about whether a particular initiative should be taken. That is why the Government is pursuing—which has been referred to by some senators—other recycling initiatives. There is a large number of them. I do not intend to recapitulate them because it diverts us from the debate. It is a matter on which I did quite a bit of speaking around Australia when I was on the back bench. It was an issue in which I had a particular concern and interest.

I reiterate that after this legislation passes there will be significant remaining discrimination in the wholesale sales tax in favour of environmentally desirable products, including significant amounts of recycled paper.

Let me talk briefly about the imports argument. The evidence is that imports of exercise books and paper bags had more than doubled, while imports of tissues had trebled over the period 1989-90 to 1990-91, which corresponds very closely with the period the sales tax exemption was available for these products. Over that time imports of paper products overall fell significantly. It is clear that there was an upsurge in imports of these products. It is not possible, as I understand it, to disaggregate and say, `This was claimed to be recycled and this was not'. Looking at the categories, however, there is a remarkable compatibility between them.

The primary purpose of the Government is not to introduce wholesale sales tax changes to encourage imports of papers so that those who are trying to set up recycling industries in Australia are subjected to substantial import competition. There was a problem with imports, although there is a lot of anecdotal debate about whether or not they were bona fide. I do not claim to have either the scientific knowledge to be able to assess it or the data to be able to reinforce it; that debate is being carried by others. But it is quite clear that there was a problem of substantial import competition, and we were creating a wholesale sales tax benefit the impact of which was to encourage recycling in other countries rather than here.

There was also some concern about the benefit that might have flowed to consumers from these reductions in wholesale sales tax. That is certainly what was intended because that is what changes the price signals and people's preparedness to buy different products. I do not want to put too much emphasis on this; I make the point for a reason which some honourable senators will understand: there is some concern—and it is one of the reasons why wholesale sales tax is not always the most effective mechanism—that there was no guarantee that the reduction in the tax was necessarily passed on to consumers. Some was, there is no doubt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like a GST.

—If Senator Kernot will allow me to make my own speech, I was intending to make a point not dissimilar to that. I was actually leading to that point. I thank Senator Kernot for her assistance. It is a problem when one tries to use tax mechanisms that they are often clumsy. It is possible for people to absorb the tax reductions, which are intended to flow on to consumers, as compensation perhaps for other measures or to increase their profitability, which sometimes has been under grave threat, particularly when we are emerging from a recession. There is some evidence about that problem here. It is a clear indication of another problem with Fightback that the so-called seven taxes that will be abolished, some of which have been abolished already, but they are going to abolish them again—
—It shows we are leading the agenda.

—Yes, leading it several years behind. There is certain poetry about people who led from the rear. May the Opposition continue to do so for many years. The concern is that there is no way of guaranteeing that the reduction proposed in payroll tax or wholesale sales tax or others—
—You say that every time.

—And it is always true. There is no way of guaranteeing that the reduction in payroll tax or wholesale sales tax would in any event be passed on to consumers. All the assessments of the inflation impact of Fightback—
—Tell us about the mauling you got in Osborne Park a few weeks ago by the business community.
—I had a very good time and I am delighted—
—Tell us about the absolute mauling you got.
—I am sorry about what they are putting in that water Senator Knowles is drinking that makes her hallucinate. I do worry about the honourable senator.
—You got an absolute mauling.

—I actually had a very pleasant time. I would recommend that Senator Knowles consult a medical practitioner quite quickly; it may be dangerous. The situation is quite simple: if payroll tax, wholesale sales tax and other things are not passed on, all the modelling about compensation packages goes out the window because the inflationary impact of the goods and services tax will not be compensated in the way in which the Opposition hopes.

PARA.TAB: That is a very heroic set of assumptions. They assume that every tax reduction will be passed on 100 per cent, except payroll tax which will be only 50 per cent passed on. The Opposition is trying to assume that it will have a jobs effect, but that nothing else will be absorbed by companies emerging from a recession. That is just another flaw which has been shown up by what has happened here.

I do not want to be diverted too much into the industry bounty issue. I think that is one issue around this Parliament where we are in some agreement. So to me there does not seem to be a lot of virtue in speaking about it at great length. Whatever people think about how we should have proceeded, there is a general view that, if this measure proceeds, there should be some compensating payment made. So a lengthy speech about that would be one of those heated agreement exercises which only takes up the time of the Parliament.

However, one part of the rewriting of history, as I am informed—this is not a matter of my direct personal information but it relates to information that has been made available to me—is that at least one of these companies, namely Austissue, set itself up to take advantage of the sales tax exemption announced by the Government. My understanding and advice is that Austissue was set up with a financial assistance grant of $200,000 from the Western Australian Government in 1988, and the sales tax exemption was announced in July of 1989. I do appreciate companies having foresight, but to make a decision 18 months before the Government had announced a policy on the basis that that policy would set up a desirable environment for the company to operate in is foresight above and beyond the call of duty; it is just not possible.

Let us not rewrite the history books and say that these people made a decision on the basis of announced government policy and therefore the change is grossly unfair. As I am advised, that is just not the case with regard to that particular example. That is not to say that taking away the exemption has no impact on that company. Obviously it does, and that is why there is some agreement about transitional measures—because Australians are employed there performing a socially desirable function in a way that we hope they can continue to do in an economically viable way.

That is why there are some compensatory measures. So, for as long as the system is driven by wholesale sales tax, there will be some exemptions for recycled paper—which is more than the Opposition can say. But where we are trying to target them more successfully and there are consequences to particular industries, these sorts of measures are available to facilitate the continuance of that operation—not on the basis that we have changed the goalposts from where they were when the companies affected started because that, on the advice I have, is clearly not the case; but on the basis that, nevertheless, they are adversely affected and there ought properly to be an examination of the consequences of that. Austissue is not necessarily the only company involved but it is the one about which people have been speaking at length.

I look forward to the passage of this legislation. I think it will more effectively target the proper discrimination in the wholesale sales tax system in favour of recycled paper; it will achieve the environmental purposes more effectively; and it will enable the Australian businesses that are proposing to set up major recycling operations, some of which are going ahead at this very time, to do so on a more successful economic basis.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 6, page 2, after subsection (1), insert the following subsection:
"(1A)Item 140 in Schedule 1 to the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end the following paragraphs:
`(e)the RSPCA Australia Inc;

TAB.TAB: (f)the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Victoria Inc;
(g)the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals New South Wales Inc;
(h)the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Queensland Inc;
(i)the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals South Australia Inc;
(j)the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Western Australia Inc;
(k)the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Tasmania Inc;
(l)the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Australian Capital Territory Inc;
(m)the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Northern Territory Inc.'."

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that, although I criticised the slow passage of this Bill, it has had one unintended beneficial side effect. I have had the chance to be informed of an anomaly, which I have attempted to rectify by way of this amendment. The amendment seeks to exempt the RSPCA, an Australian institution, from paying sales tax. Sales tax law has always recognised that public benevolent institutions, or PBIs, as they have come to be called, should be exempt. We know that those institutions provide valuable community service and we think it is proper that they are exempt from tax.

PARA.TAB: In our recent select committee hearings on the rewriting of the sales tax law we discovered that the original legislation would have impacted on the operations of traditional public benevolent institutions, and there was a legitimate outcry. I accept that the Government did not intend to tax the charities and other public hospitals in the way that would have happened under this Bill, and it withdrew its proposal.

At that time, I was not aware of the anomaly with respect to the RSPCA. It goes back to a decision in 1931 of the High Court which held that the term `public benevolent institution' is limited to those bodies which promote `the relief of poverty, suffering, distress or misfortune'. That test excludes the RSPCA because it does not include bodies that promote the relief of suffering and distress of animals, only humans. One could argue that that is a legal technicality and that at the time it involved a narrowing by the High Court of previous tax decisions concerning institutions that provide a public benefit.

The Queensland branch of the RSPCA recently decided to test this anomaly in the courts. Justice Shepherdson of the Supreme Court of Queensland, who heard the case, looked at the matter not in that narrow way but in the interests of the community in general and in the interests of justice. His Honour allowed the RSPCA's appeal. He held that the RSPCA was a public charity and that its object was to promote morality and to check man's innate tendency to cruelty. He said that the identity of the persons benefiting from the benevolence of the RSPCA was mankind generally. I agree with that; I think many of us would agree with it. Furthermore, he said that the legislature—that is, this Parliament—did not intend to penalise the RSPCA through sales tax because it specifically concerned animals. According to him, the RSPCA is a public benevolent institution and entitled to exemption from sales tax legislation.

The Australian Taxation Office appealed against this decision and the Full Court upheld the appeal. The outcome is that the RSPCA still has to pay sales tax on what I believe is a technicality, despite the fact that it provides wonderful community service and has done since before Australia became a sovereign nation. The RSPCA has a branch in every State and Territory in Australia. Its work is well known and supported. As I said, it is an Australian institution. It operates as separate State-based institutions—formed in 1872 in Tasmania and 1892 in Western Australia. I have listed the various State organisations in my amendment to ensure that they are all covered. The Society has been assisting the community since long before Australia became a country and this Parliament came into existence.

The combined budgets of the various State organisations of the RSPCA are approximately $10m. So the elimination of this tax burden by my amendment will provide an equivalent boost in resources of almost 10 per cent. Some State organisations are currently in debt, and having to pay this tax is worsening their situation. Because the RSPCA now has to pay sales tax, it cannot devote that portion of its money to its various programs. Its most well-known function is the animal shelters where stray pets are collected, nursed if necessary, and found a new home, if possible. I am told by the RSPCA that tight funding has meant that it has had to put down a lot more animals than would otherwise have been necessary.

The Society has been expanding its activities into the aged care arena. Everybody knows of the great love and companionship that aged people receive from their pets. Often that pet is the only `person' aged people talk to—and I call the pet a person because it becomes a person in people's lives. A lot of research is being done showing that pets can improve the emotional and physical health of aged people.

In addition, the RSPCA conducts education programs which involve visits to schools and other places to promote awareness in the community. The programs are very popular and the RSPCA is called upon to exercise this function frequently. However, the Victorian branch of the RSPCA had to close its education office recently because of funding pressures—pressures that are exacerbated by the imposition of sales tax. Paying sales tax reduces the resources available to employ more inspectors and to assist distressed animals. The combination of the rural recession and drought in some areas has led to severe deterioration in the health and treatment of some stock, especially sheep. Many honourable senators will have seen distressing footage of this on television.

One final area I would like to cover relates to the Society's work on behalf of native Australian wildlife. Each State has plans to establish wildlife sanctuaries to care for sick and injured native animals. Many thousands of these animals are hurt and maimed on our roads each year. I find it hard to understand or anticipate what sort of justification the Government and the Opposition will put forward to oppose the kinds of measures that I am proposing to be assisted by the removal of the sales tax. I think the Australian people will be very interested to hear this justification as well. Surely governments should be doing everything in their power to assist community organisations which achieve desirable goals, as the RSPCA clearly does. Removing the tax burden from the RSPCA will not cost money. It does not have to cost money. If we extend the benefit of what it does at the community level, I think we can still argue that it would save money in the long term.

But the Commonwealth is not the sole carrier of blame because most taxes are paid to State and local governments—namely, payroll tax and land tax. I am glad that Treasurer Dawkins has said that he will take the matter up with various State Treasurers on behalf of the Society, but that is not good enough. It is not good enough to see the merit of the case being argued at the State level and yet, when we have the opportunity to do something at the Federal level, oppose removing the annual sales tax bill of approximately $800,000.

I understand that Senator Brownhill is a patron of the RSPCA. On 7 October in this place he drew our attention, via a notice of motion, to the plight of the RSPCA with respect to having to pay that amount of sales tax. I am hoping that Senator Brownhill will vote for my amendment.

I understand that Mr Reith's office has been approached on this issue in the last couple of days by senior members of the RSPCA. I understand that the leadership of the Party has considered the issue and has decided to oppose this change. I think that is really regrettable. As I have said, it is very difficult to justify when in this place recently the Opposition voted for changes in classifications to assist the small Australian owned manufacturing company Voxson Sales Pty Ltd in Brisbane. I would like to understand its selectivity in these matters.

The coalition proposes to zero rate the RSPCA for GST purposes. I guess it thinks it can make a political point in showing how GST is fairer than wholesale sales tax. We have heard it all 100 times already. It concedes the point that it is wrong not to exempt the RSPCA—because it is going to zero rate it—but it says, `Heavens no, we can't take the opportunity to do it now because, first, the Democrats are proposing this amendment and, secondly, we never improve legislation; we wait until we get into government and then we will start again'.

The RSPCA touches so many Australians. They will not understand that fine philosophical distinction about how we should approach legislation. The coalition has no qualms about taxing food, weddings and funerals, but will it assist to free a great Australian institution from an anomalous tax burden? Unfortunately the answer is no but, as Senator Watson usually appeals to me during the course of debate, in the same courtesy I will appeal to him to judge the merit of this argument. Given that it is going to zero rate the RSPCA under a GST, what possible justification can the Opposition put forward for opposing my amendment which would achieve exactly the same outcome here and now?

TALK.START.PARA: —The genesis of the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats was the unsuccessful court action whereby it was sought to change the law in terms of seeking the status, under the sales tax provisions, of a public benevolent institution. That is the issue. I think it is appropriate that the Liberal-National Party coalition should place on record its public appreciation of the important community service work carried out by the RSPCA. In fact, under the coalition's Fightback proposals as enunciated in relation to the GST regime, the RSPCA would not carry a tax burden because it is deemed to be a non-profit organisation.

PARA.TAB: But whether it is a non-profit organisation is not the issue before us today. The issue before us today is not about profit, but about a public benevolent institution, which is quite different. Senator Kernot mentioned an aspect of courtesy and I would like to put on the record the blatant display of lack of courtesy on this occasion. Literally within minutes of the scheduled end of this debate, we were given a page of amendments in this chamber. This is not the usual way in which the Democrats deal with me in relation to tax matters. It amounts to the hijacking of a proposal—in other words, a blatant attempt to put the Democrats on a higher rung of the social welfare-type ladder, albeit temporarily.

When we win the next election this issue will not be a problem under the GST proposals. But the real issue is that the Senate did not provide the courtesy of giving adequate notice to all members of this chamber. As I have said, this is most unusual. The major parties in this chamber assess the merits of the matter and also examine the precedents which would flow from an amendment such as the Australian Democrats have introduced at the present time. This amendment would not go without notice by other similar bodies which are not currently recognised as benevolent institutions under this or any other Act.

In fact, the amendment was introduced without warning and distributed only minutes before the scheduled list of speakers was to conclude. So, prima facie, this has all of the hallmarks of a minority party's opportunistic approach to hijacking issues. It uses a technique which is known as `tacking'—adding completely unrelated issues to Bills which pass through the Senate to try to distract attention from one issue to another.

I remind you, Mr Chairman, that the major parties require a careful evaluation of amendments—involving the shadow ministry, back bench consultation and evaluation, and party room discussion—so that everybody within the parties has an opportunity to assess the merits and consequences of legislation. The Democrats, through the technique they have applied today, have denied both of the major parties that opportunity of evaluation and care. If we go down this track we are bound to get bad legislation, no matter how sincere and needy a cause may be. The framing words always need care, particularly in the case of tax legislation which is a very precise science.

The short notice is not only discourteous but also a cheap political point-scoring technique using a very respected organisation in society. It demeans the role and practices of the Senate—and that is unusual for the Democrats—and I hope it will not be seen as a precedent for further attacks in the Senate and misuse of the Senate procedures in the manner in which they have misused them today. Evaluation and cooperation are essential ingredients for the successful passage of such an amendment. The Democrats have to apply a more cooperative, reasoned and practical approach if they wish to have success with their amendments.

Senator Kernot drew attention to other amendments which the Opposition has agreed to. I put to Senator Kernot that consultation and evaluation were present on that occasion; they are missing on this. I hope Senator Kernot will set her house in order for future occasions. Because of the manner in which the amendment has been introduced, the lack of evaluation of the court's decision and other issues, I regret to say that on this occasion we will not be agreeing to the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard this argument about lack of sufficient time before. It was trotted out in the recycled paper debate many years ago before I was elected, although I was listening to the debate on the radio at the place where I was working. I cannot allow Senator Watson to use that argument in a way which distracts from the content of the amendment. If anybody has a right to complain, it is the Government—I will accept that criticism—because it has not had adequate notice. But in the case of the Opposition I understand that the RSPCA has had—

—No, not with Senator Watson because it knows what happens, I am sorry to say. The RSPCA knows the decision-making processes of the Opposition. It has been talking at length with Mr Reith's office, and I think either last night or the night before it was speaking to Senator Short's office. The RSPCA knows where the authority for the passage of this amendment will come from. I also suggested that the RSPCA should speak to Senator Watson, but it has not had time.

PARA.TAB: It is not simply a matter of a lack of time or a lack of courtesy. The Opposition has taken a decision on the facts placed before it by the RSPCA, not by me. The RSPCA has come to the Opposition seeking support. It is very disappointed that it did not get that support. That is why I am willing to move this amendment on its behalf.

The Opposition says that it needs time to consider the amendment. I know of Senator Watson's experience. I have been here for hours and hours watching him debate the fine details of every word in a piece of tax legislation. All my amendment says is, `Clause 6, page 2, after subsection (1), insert the following subsection', and then it lists the name of each RSPCA State organisation. I know that is not difficult for a man of Senator Watson's experience in this area.

If Senator Watson really believes that the RSPCA is such a wonderful and respected organisation, he should not wait until he thinks he might win the next election and then take however long it takes for him to impose his tax regime on Australia. He should seize the day and do something about it now. The opportunity is here and now to remove a $800,000 tax burden from the RSPCA and to free those resources for the wonderful community work which it does to the great benefit of the whole of Australian society. Even though not technically by definition, the RSPCA quite clearly is a body which relieves suffering, distress and misfortune; it just happens to be in this case to animals.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have an unfortunate reversion to a former type here by the Australian Democrats in their approach to this amendment to the wholesale sales tax legislation. In the first period in which I was representing the Government with regard to tax matters I was given, on a few occasions, to describe the Democrat approach to amendments—particularly to the wholesale sales tax, but also to income tax—as the bower bird theory. They just flew around picking up the shiny bits and dumping them into a heap because they looked attractive without any sense of the overall pattern or purpose of the approach. Recently, they have not been doing that, but I have to say that this is a bower bird classic.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot was articulating how easy it is to work out what this Bill does. The significant thing that people responsibly—either as a government or seriously aspiring to government—also have to consider is what the Bill does not do. This is picking an isolated organisation—not by category, like public benevolent institutions for which the court has developed over a long period of time a set of criteria, and everybody who meets those criteria get the same benefit—and saying, `We like this one'. Why? Because it has come to attention because it challenged the prevailing ruling in the court.

A lot of other very socially worthwhile organisations which pay wholesale sales tax on some or all of their goods have not challenged it, so they are not on the list. Apex does a lot of very good work in the society. It is a very worthwhile group of people who do a lot of good work, but they pay wholesale sales tax. They have not gone to court; they have not been in the newspapers; they have not been to see democrats so they do not qualify.

There are thousands of voluntary organisations in Australia that pay wholesale sales tax on some of their purchases. In fact, the RSPCA gets quite a lot of what it has to buy exempt from wholesale sales tax, and so it should. We have here an attempt just to pick the immediately controversial, the currently attractive, without any framework. What about all the other organisations that provide animal welfare assistance in Australia? What about them? What about a lot of organisations that provide other worthwhile social assistance? I get hundreds of letters, and Senator Watson must get hundreds of letters, from people seeking wholesale sales tax exemption, but they do not fit the category of public benevolent institutions.We have to consider each of these within the broader context of the framework of tax legislation.

Here we are, saying we are going to give an $800,000 donation of the taxpayers' money to the RSPCA. We are all going to be generous with somebody else's money. It is the taxpayers' money; it is not our money. It is not Senator Kernot's money; it is not Senator Watson's money; it is not my money. It is the taxpayers' money. We are saying, `We will give $800,000 to the RSPCA because we like them'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet if you asked them I know what answer you would get.
—I like the RSPCA, but what is the criterion that says it should be the RSPCA and not Apex; the RSPCA and not any of the veterans' organisations?
—Because of the definition.

—These people do not fit the definition either. Senator Kernot has just made up a new definition. That is what I am saying. There are a lot of bodies which do very worthwhile work which are not public benevolent institutions and which pay wholesale sales tax. If we are to say that they are not to do so, then we have to say where we are going to get the revenue from. What is it that the Government does with $800,000 that it is going to stop doing, or who else is going to pay the tax?

PARA.TAB: It is not really the $800,000. If one mentions the RSPCA, people will say, `What about the cat haven and all the other people who do the same sort of work around the community'—very worth while work—`and get a lot of assistance from government and individual citizens?'. The RSPCA, for example, gets a lot of assistance through the wholesale sales tax system. But let us be clear about something else because people who listen to or read this debate may misunderstand and think there has been some recent change to the wholesale sales tax situation with regard to the RSPCA. That is just not the case. The RSPCA has been operating under the wholesale sales tax legislation since it was introduced in the 1930s and the circumstances it faces now are the same as the circumstances it has always faced. This is not an attempt to relieve the RSPCA of some new burden.

There is nobody in Australia who would argue that the RSPCA is not a worthwhile body. There is nobody in Australia who would argue that it does not do very many socially desirable things here in Canberra and in every other city in Australia. I see it regularly and I have had some association with it. But that is not the point.

We all have our favourite organisations. Maybe we could have 76 blank spaces in which senators could indicate their favourite organisations; maybe we could give away $60m of taxpayers' money; maybe we could all give away a $800,000 tax exemption to our favourite organisation. But there is no intellectual rigour or tax system in that. It is just a bit of adhockery; a bit of reverting to the bad old days of the bower bird theory.

The RSPCA has been to see the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). It has had discussions about how assistance might be provided so that it can work more effectively. It is not my view that the sales tax is the appropriate mechanism by which to deal with this matter. It was not before the RSPCA came; it is even less so since it has been.

I accept Senator Kernot's apology for not giving us notice of the amendment. I did not even know about it until Senator Watson told me. I obtained a copy of the amendment from the clerk at the table. Until then I did not know—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was circulated yesterday.

—Not here, and I did not know about it. That is no longer my problem. I accept what Senator Kernot has said about very short notice being given. I can live with that; we can deal with it. I still do not support the amendment—not in a fit of pique because I did not get enough notice but because I do not agree with the underlying philosophy of the way in which we should go around distributing taxpayers' money at random.

—I accept some of those reflections on the Democrat approach in the past to sales tax legislation. I also accept the comment that it has been less frequent in recent times. Senator McMullan has asked why I have chosen the RSPCA. I have chosen it because it is inherently worthy in itself. There is nothing similar to the RSPCA in Australia. There is nothing of its size and nothing of its national scope. In any case, I would ask Senator McMullan to consider the view that laws should keep pace with community values. I would ask the Parliamentary Secretary to tell me how he could explain to Australians in 1992 that we should make a distinction between the alleviation of human suffering and the alleviation of animal suffering. I do not think the community accepts that technical distinction any more.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary made the point about wasting $800,000 of taxpayers' money. If taxpayers' had a chance, I think they would approve of us spending money in this way on something like the RSPCA. But in any case, I put this to the Parliamentary Secretary: how does he think taxpayers feel about subsidising the non-productive takeovers that took place in this country in the last decade under the Labor Government? I can be just as selective as Senator McMullan about what taxpayers might be happy or unhappy about the Government spending their money on. If I am given a choice between the RSPCA and non-productive speculative takeovers, then I will take the RSPCA any day. This amendment deserves the Government's support.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Kernot's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the appalling social wreckage of the Government's economic policies, which have left more than 1 1/2 million people in the situation where they are out of work, have given up looking for work or are seriously under-employed; as well as 700,000 children living in families without a breadwinner and some 200,000 young unemployed. In these circumstances, does the Minister have the gall to endorse the Prime Minister's arrogant assertions that the recession was over a long time ago and that this Government saved Australia? Given the doubts that the Minister expressed last Sunday about Australia achieving even a miserable 3 per cent growth rate, will he now give an assurance that, if necessary, the Government will hand down a further economic statement?

—I am not accepting many of the assumptions and figures with which Senator Alston prefaced his question. When he comes to the issue of the Prime Minister's remarks about the recession, I make this point: the Prime Minister said that the recession was over in terms of the technical definition of a recession. That is correct. The recession in Australia is over, as distinct from the recession in the United Kingdom, for example. The UK has had nine quarters of negative growth and we have now had several quarters of positive growth. The economy is growing at 2 1/2 per cent a year, on the best extrapolation of the existing figures.

PARA.TAB: There is a difference between saying that in relation to the technical definition of a recession and saying that the consequences of the recession are over. Everybody who knows anything about it knows that, in terms of a recovery in an economy such as this, employment is the last indicator and the last area in which recovery is demonstrated. That has always been so, and it is so in terms of this recession as well.

Because we recognised that the consequences of the recession were not over, we put in the Budget some very large expenditure on job creation programs, particularly in the hands of local and regional government. We recognised that the consequences of the recession in terms of employment were still very much present in Australia. Those opposite opposed that fiscal stimulus. Their Leader opposed it. Their Leader said we should not have that fiscal stimulus. When interest rates were being reduced, their Leader said that interest rates should not be reduced. In each of those cases—

TALK.START.PARA: —He said that what was needed was structural reform as well.

—Is that going to be what the Opposition hangs its hat on? Is structural reform a solution to the employment problem which Senator Alston refers to? I know how those in the Opposition create jobs. They invent them, as their shadow Minister did. He created 12,500 jobs in one fib. He gets a pimple on his tongue for that. In terms of the consequences of the recession, we acted on it in the Budget, and those opposite opposed it.
—You created it.

—Senator Macdonald interjects, `You created it'. That is all very well, but the fact is that we have taken action in respect of it which is consistent with the Prime Minister's view that the consequences of the recession are still there, and the Opposition opposed that action.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am grateful to the Minister for acknowledging that his Government did indeed cause the recession and is prepared to wear the blame for it. But I again refer to his statements of last Sunday, both early morning and late morning, the end result of which seems to be that he now expects the 3 per cent growth target to be met, but he also currently has doubts, given the figure for the last quarter. On that basis, if the figures do not pick up, is the Government prepared to deliver a further economic statement in order to try to pick up the pieces for those people who are suffering so much?

—I know Senator Alston very much enjoys asking questions because he likes the sound of his own voice. He does not listen to the answers because he asked me this very question two days ago, not about an economic statement but about the growth rate and its relationship to employment. I answered that question and now he asks me whether there will be a further economic statement. That is a matter for the Government to decide at any time it wants to.

—I refer to the comments made last night to the Senate by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade regarding the Prime Minister's report on his recent trip to Asia. In the light of those comments and in the light of a continued uncompromising attitude on the part of the Khmer Rouge, I ask the Minister whether there has been any further progress in the United Nations' consideration of the next steps which might be taken in the Cambodian peace process.

—Since I spoke in the Senate last night, the UN Security Council has adopted Resolution 783 on Cambodia, which is the product of a substantial series of talks which have taken place in New York over the last couple of weeks in which Australia has been very closely involved, first through myself a couple of weeks ago and subsequently with officials.

PARA.TAB: That UN resolution does a number of things. It confirms the existing timetable for the implementation of the peace settlement, including that elections be held no later than May 1993. It deplores the Khmer Rouge's non-compliance, and demands that they fulfil their obligations under the Paris agreements. It invites the governments of Japan and Thailand to continue the efforts in which they have been engaged for the last few weeks to find a formula for the question of the Khmer Rouge's non-compliance and to report back to the UN Secretary-General and the co-chairmen of the Paris conference by the end of this month on the success or otherwise of those efforts.

The resolution goes on to invite the UN Secretary-General to ask the Paris co-chairmen, that is to say, Indonesia and France, to then undertake consultations pursuant to, in effect, article 29 of the Paris settlement, and that is an important new step. It requests the Secretary-General to report back to the Security Council by 15 November, if the present difficulties have not been overcome by then, with the Security Council then to consider what further steps are necessary to ensure the realisation of the fundamental objectives of the Paris agreements.

The resolution does, I think, demonstrate the continuing very firm resolve of the international community to implement the settlement. It offers the Khmer Rouge in effect the full benefits of the settlement if they are ready to comply with it. But it denies them the power of veto by confirming that the implementation of the settlement should continue according to the agreed timetable.

The exercise under way by Japan and Thailand is one designed to secure the return of the Khmer Rouge to the peace process on the basis of the creation of a so-called administrative consultative body which would coordinate requests made by the various Cambodian factions on administrative matters relating to the Paris agreements. Whether or not that exercise is successful remains to be seen. But, if it is unsuccessful, it is likely that the Paris conference co-chairmen will convene a ministerial meeting, which I expect to be attending, in early November as part of that continuing consultative process.

A likely next step to emerge then, if it is still the case that the Khmer Rouge are not cooperating, would be, I guess, a formal decision to proceed with the election, with it being understood that it would remain open to the Khmer Rouge to rejoin the settlement at least within certain time constraints if they did finally decide to comply fully with the terms of the settlement. But it would be clearly understood that the Khmer Rouge, by their continued non-compliance, would be consciously excluding themselves from the settlement.

I do want to emphasise that, notwithstanding the continuing comments one is hearing from the egregious Mr Pilger and others of that ilk that the Paris settlement does in fact involve the vesting of some kind of veto power in the Khmer Rouge, it is not the mood in any way of the international community at the moment to allow the Khmer Rouge to exercise such a veto power.

We all continue to take the view that the comprehensive settlement, as negotiated and signed last November, remains far and away the best means of achieving a genuinely durable, lasting peace in Cambodia, with other solutions involving the quarantining or exclusion of them from that process being less satisfactory. Nonetheless, there is a belief that, in the prevailing situation and given the very substantial achievements of the UN forces so far, which I spelt out in more detail last night in the Senate, there is ground for optimism for believing that one way or another some kind of effective, durable peace can be secured and most, if not all, of the UN peace plan can be implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the New Zealand Parliamentary Committee on Finance and Expenditure. The purpose of the Committee's visit is to discuss ways of improving parliamentary accountability for public expenditure and administration. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming the Committee to the Senate and I trust that its visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: firstly, why did he categorically deny on five occasions that he had had no representations from car manufacturers on increasing four-wheel drive tariffs from 15 per cent to 35 per cent recently when in fact he has received no fewer than four letters from those people in the past few weeks; secondly, which companies wrote to him requesting an increase in tariffs and which of those companies opposed the rise; and, lastly, would Ford potentially gain from an increase in tariffs on four-wheel drive vehicles?
—I do not accept most of the chronology which Senator Campbell has given. I heard him speaking on this question in the Senate yesterday and misrepresenting the position which I made.
—Did you correct it?

—He has done that fairly successfully, and I will take the opportunity to correct it at some stage in the future. What I have said on a number of occasions is that the Government receives representations on these issues back and forth all the time and has done so for years, and usually with the same sort of people involved. What Senator Campbell is trying to construct here is a little conspiracy theory. That is why his question is couched in the way it is—that somehow the Government is going to yield to the representations which it has received in one way or another.
—You are a bit sensitive.

—I am not the least bit sensitive. The rumour is out and about, and I know who it has been put out and about by. The day before yesterday, from my recollection, the honourable senator's question related to correspondence I had received in the last six or seven weeks. I am sorry to disappoint Senator Campbell, but I have received letters as recently as 6 October which have gone to my Department; they were of the kind which we normally receive. That letter of 6 October was not from a manufacturer, as I told the honourable senator privately yesterday; it was from an importer. Prior to that, I had not, I think, received any letters supporting a change to the present tariff in the last six or seven weeks. Certainly, some have come in over the years. As I said to the honourable senator in my answer the other day, at the time the One Nation statement was put together we received representations about this from people in the automotive industry. That was ages ago, and we took no action in respect of those representations at that time.

PARA.TAB: In regard to revealing which companies wrote and what position they argued, as I said yesterday, I will not do that. If I, as Industry Minister, in answer to Senator Campbell's sorts of questions, revealed every letter I got and what their contents were, my correspondence would dry up very quickly, for very sensible reasons because, of course, Ministers have to keep these matters confidential. That is the proper way to conduct government and that is the way I will continue to do it.

I will not yield to those sorts of blandishments from the Opposition to reveal the sources and contents of correspondence. If Opposition senators propose to be in government and accept that as their standard, I warn them that they are in for big trouble. If that is the standard which the Opposition espouses, it is not the one which I espouse on these sorts of issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister sets his own bad standard by denying to the Senate on five occasions that he has received correspondence and then coming in here and saying yes, indeed, he had. The Minister seems to be revising his own admission in the Senate yesterday that he had received no correspondence from manufacturers recently. He has now said that he has received only one letter from an importer recently. I would like the Minister to again say that he has received no correspondence from manufacturers in the last couple of months specifically urging him to increase tariffs on four-wheel drive cars.

—Every time the honourable senator asks the question he changes the ball game. He began by asking whether I had received correspondence from manufacturers recently. Then he changed it to `from manufacturers in the last six weeks'; then it became `in the last seven weeks'; and now it has become `in the last few months'. Every time he changes the question and every time I give him the same sort of answer; that over the years we have received, and we will continue to receive, representations from people in industry about their particular interests.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell can go on trying to construct his little conspiracy theory in order to support the speech made by Hugh Morgan in Perth, which he alluded to the other day, on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You alluded to it.
—No, Senator Campbell did in his question the other day. The evidence is here. He said, `Mr Hugh Morgan said in a speech in Perth. . . '.
—You said, `Go and read it', you fool.

—I will get out the Hansard and read it right back to Senator Campbell if he wants. The fact is that in his question he did allude to that speech the other day. Senator Campbell is relatively new in this place, and if this is going to be his go, to get from the back bench to the front bench, he is on the wrong track, because it is just a silly series of questions.

PARA.TAB: The Government makes the policy on these issues. No amount of letters will affect the Government's decisions on these matters. We get them from all sides and the Government will not be influenced by correspondence of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What measures has the Government put in place to assist the Australian tourism industry? Is the Minister aware of concerns within the industry at proposals to impose new taxes on tourism in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Maguire for this question. It is very thoughtful. I am aware of concern about the possible imposition of new taxes on the tourist industry. Since the mid-1980s Australian tourism has gone ahead very successfully and in 1991 2.4 million people visited Australia, an increase of 156 per cent on the figures of eight years earlier.

PARA.TAB: This Government has worked closely with the tourist industry, as it does with all industries. It is not content to rely on economic models worked out by academics. It works with industries on these matters and it has worked with the tourist industry.

The strategy the Government has developed recognises the growth potential of the tourist industry and its high employment potential. I have to say, though, that some parts of the tourist industry are very concerned about, in what is a blue sky, the dark cloud of additional taxes being imposed on this industry if, for example, an alternative government were elected. For example, Mr John Dart, the President of the Australian Federation of Travel Agents, after examining a proposal for a consumption tax, a GST, said recently:

ANSWER.PARA: But with Fightback, there are no offsets. There are no offsets in terms of the Fightback package because there is no payroll tax offset, and in many cases there is nothing else. So in essence the price of their product is going up.

Many tourist operators would be hit hard, of course, by a 15 per cent GST, as would thousands of other small business people. The fact is that there are 700,000 businesses in Australia and only 100,000 of them pay payroll tax. Small tourist operators are not in that group that pays payroll tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have no idea how payroll tax cascades through the economy.

—Senator Short is interjecting. He understands the point very well because in the 1970s, when he was the member for Ballarat for a brief period, he argued very much against the abolition of a payroll tax because he understood the point in respect of small businesses. He did that very regularly, as did the Premier of Tasmania recently. In relation to the payroll tax issue he said that the abolition of payroll tax would not necessarily create jobs. His energy Minister, Mr Robin Gray, said that he believes the Hewson Fightback pledge to abolish payroll tax will not create employment in Tasmania. Senator Short, when he was the member for Ballarat, really understood the small business point. He said, `This is discriminatory against businesses in Ballarat which do not pay payroll tax'. Senator Short understands the message.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister accept that Arnotts Ltd is a profitable company with strong export prospects and that the proposed takeover by Campbell's Soup Company could therefore have a negative impact on the Australian economy as profits go off-shore? Secondly, will the Government introduce pro-Australian foreign investment controls to prevent takeovers which would result in a net loss to the national economy and, if not, why not?

—The question of the proposed takeover of Arnotts by Campbell's is one which has to be dealt with by the Foreign Investment Review Board. It will look at it in terms of net benefits to the Australian economy and so on. Arnotts has been a successful company, but one which predominantly has satisfied the domestic market in Australia. If Arnotts is to become a truly international company—that is to say, one exporting to the Asia-Pacific region, which it has the capacity to do—one of the things which would greatly help it in that process is international marketing strength, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. It is possible—I do not know, but it is possible—that that could well be supplied by a company such as Campbell's, if the takeover bid were successful.

PARA.TAB: It is not proper for me to comment on the merits of a takeover bid. I think that is a matter for the shareholders of Arnotts and, in so far as it involves government administration and policy, it is a matter for the Foreign Investment Review Board.

I conclude by saying that a large proportion of Australian industry in significant sectors is foreign owned. Ten years ago the issue of foreign ownership simply meant that many Australian companies that were subsidiaries of foreign companies operated with a branch office mentality in Australia. There are one or two that still do. The majority of Australian companies that are foreign owned are not operating with a branch office mentality any more and are significant contributors to exports from Australia. IBM is a classic example, exporting last year $360m worth of computers and associated equipment from Australia. A few years ago it had certainly not done that. There are many other companies in that category.
I do not necessarily accept the assumptions in Senator Coulter's question, but I cannot take it beyond that at present because it is a matter for the shareholders and the FIRB.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister accept that a company for which Campbell's is prepared to pay $8.80 a share must be fairly buoyant and well able to enter the Asian market without the intervention of foreign ownership? Secondly, can he assure me that the FIRB has the power to prevent this takeover?

—In relation to the second part of the question, it is a matter that is registrable in respect of FIRB; it has to consider it. I believe that if it were so inclined and regarded it as a takeover that was directly against the national interest, the FIRB has the power to prevent it. But that is a matter for its deliberation and determination.

PARA.TAB: As to whether Arnotts is a buoyant company, I have already answered that. It has been a successful company in the domestic market predominantly. Whether it becomes a successful company internationally may depend on some of the factors I adverted to in my earlier answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows his answer to Senator Maguire. Does the Minister stand by his comment in 1985 that `every effort should be made to reduce or eliminate payroll tax'?

—There is no particular dispute about that. It is desirable for Australian businesses that one reduce the incidence of taxation generally. The question is the way it is done. For starters, the Opposition will increase company tax by 3 per cent immediately—
—What were you telling Senator Short about that?

—I was talking about payroll tax, Ee-Eye. The fact of the matter is that the Opposition is proposing to impose a GST on the products of many businesses, which will affect consumer demand. Secondly, the Opposition will increase corporate tax by 3 per cent. That is the starting point in terms of considering the abolition of payroll tax.

PARA.TAB: The United States is a lovely model for those opposite. What is different in the United States is that employers pay $120 in respect of health services for their employees. It is the same in Germany and most European countries. So one will get back in one way or another some form of burden on industry in that genre.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Defence advise the Senate whether Australia will contribute military personnel to the UN operation in Somalia.

—The Government has decided that Australia will contribute a 30-person movement control unit to the United Nations operations in Somalia, known as UNOSOM. The UN operation in Somalia will provide a security force to assist the UN and its specialised agencies and non-governmental organisations in delivering humanitarian assistance to the people of Somalia. The security situation in Somalia, with armed gangs overrunning distribution points for food and looting supplies, has posed major difficulties for the effective delivery of humanitarian assistance. The Government's decision is in response to a formal request from the United Nations Secretary-General to contribute to the UN operation in Somalia.

PARA.TAB: The Australian contingent to UNOSOM will be drawn from each of the three Services. Elements will be deployed throughout Somalia to coordinate and control the deployment of stores and personnel involved in the UN operation. The movement control unit will be provided for a period of 12 months, with a rotation of personnel after six months. The timing of the deployment of Australian personnel will be discussed with the United Nations.

The situation in Somalia does entail risks for Australian personnel due to the widespread availability of arms and conflict between gangs and various factions. There has been a deterioration in the security situation in some parts of the country, with the factions attempting to expand or consolidate their control prior to the final deployment of the UNOSOM forces.

The Government hopes that the UN effort will achieve quick delivery of humanitarian aid to alleviate the vast dimensions of the human suffering in Somalia. It is to be hoped that the UN presence will also assist a political accommodation between the various factions and the restoration of basic government services in Somalia. The deployment of the movement control group to Somalia will take Australia's support for United Nations peacekeeping activities to its highest level ever.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. On 19 June and 8 October he told the Senate, in answer to my colleague Senator Boswell, that there had been no ministerial discussions on the issue of the importation of live pigs or genetic material imports from Denmark. Yet last week a memo was tabled from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, which clearly showed that Mr Crean had discussed the issue of pig meat and pig semen with the Danish Agriculture Minister. The memo stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The Danish Minister for Agriculture raised the matter of access for uncooked Danish pig meat and pig semen during discussions with Mr Crean in April 1992.
Why did the Minister mislead the Senate by saying that there were no ministerial discussions on the issue of genetic material imports when the evidence clearly indicates that there were?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should make one or two general comments about this issue because it illustrates the style of Opposition senators in this matter. Firstly, they came in here alleging that the Prime Minister had changed the foreign investment guidelines to suit his own business. That was demonstrably a lie and untrue. It was a grubby lie. That was their first allegation. In fact, the approval was much earlier than the change in the foreign investment guidelines. Secondly, they alleged that his company was trying to import live pigs. That was a demonstrable lie, and was nailed by everybody who knew anything about the business as a demonstrable lie.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, Senator Baume came in here with questions about the valuation of the company, based on the fact that an accountant had filed a return with a typographical error in it, as Senator Baume knows. That was the third allegation. With regard to the fourth allegation, the National Party, thinking, apparently, that pigs are its natural constituency, took up the issue on behalf of the coalition. Senator Boswell came in here a week or so ago, in the period which Senator Hill referred to, and tabled one page—he said, `I am tabling a document from AQIS'—and deleted the other three. That is the fourth misrepresentation that has been made on this issue by the Opposition while trying to make something of it.

Already on the record is the fact that at the meeting between Minister Crean and the Danish Minister the pig meat industry in general was discussed. There was no discussion in relation to live pigs or the importation of genetic material. If Senator Boswell had been honest enough to put in the whole four pages of the document, that would have been substantiated in the course of that disclosure.
An incident having occurred in the chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are great demonstrations here. On one day Senator Bishop hands me a sealed envelope across the table—are we on television today?—and now Senator Boswell has given us the benefit of doing what he should have done four days ago when he tried to make a misrepresentation to the Parliament on this issue.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill ought to know better. In terms of the AQIS document, let me make it quite clear: it is on the record in this place that the Ministers had no discussion in relation to live pigs or the importation of genetic material. This incident has been grubby from beginning to end in the hands of crass amateurs who do not know how to get a story going.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That was interesting theatre, but in my supplementary question I will read the relevant part of the memo, which the Minister has had for some time. It states:

QUESTION.PARA: The Danish Minister for Agriculture raised the matter of access for uncooked Danish pigmeat and pig semen during discussions with Mr Crean in April 1992.
How can the Minister get up yet again today and say that those discussions did not take place?

TALK.START.PARA: —I can get up and say that today because if the honourable senator had done his homework he would know that we have already had the benefit of debate in this place on a report of the Ministers' discussions. There was no discussion about live pig imports.
—This memo is wrong, is it?

—If the honourable senator knew anything about the debate in this place he would know that several memos have been proven to be wrong. If he reads the supplementary pages of the memo he will understand quite fully why Senator Boswell tabled only one page instead of three: it did not suit his grubby purpose at the time. That is why he did it.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Button has made a wholly unsatisfactory reference to the motives of Senator Boswell. He has said that his motives are `grubby'. That is quite unparliamentary and Senator Button knows that perfectly well. I suggest that you invite him to withdraw that wholly unsatisfactory remark right now.
—I heard Senator Button say that it was a grubby exercise. I take that to be just a plain debating point. I do not think it should be withdrawn.
