—Will the Minister for Justice advise the Senate of the level of cooperation between the Australian Federal Police and other law enforcement agencies, especially Customs, in relation to drug trafficking into Australia? What success are these agencies having, and has there been any recent change in the trend of the illicit drug trade into Australia?

—In fact, there is a success story to be told about the cooperation of the Federal Police and the Customs Service in trying to stem the flow of drugs being trafficked into Australia. Since January of this year, 29 kilograms of heroin have been seized, worth $35m on the streets of Australia; 200 kilograms of cocaine have been seized, worth some $160m; and 7 tonnes of cannabis resin have been seized, worth some $105m. One can see there that some $300m worth of drugs have been seized through the cooperative efforts of these agencies, depending very largely on intelligence gathering abroad by Customs contacts and by the Federal Police liaison officers in embassies such as Manila and Bangkok—in fact, in, I think, 12 embassies throughout the world.

PARA.TAB: This effort should be applauded. I believe it demonstrates the very high competence and integrity of those organisations. What it has done, of course, is stop the cash flow and criminal profits accruing to those criminal organisations—whether within Australia in the distribution of these drugs or in the remitting of funds to the overseas suppliers, who in Central America, for example, use the funds to pay their private armies and get their arms in order to fight against the governments of the countries they inhabit. So we have prevented $300m being made available to those organisations—criminal syndicates, and drug traffickers and collaborators within Australia—which would have been either laundered into legitimate business enterprises or perhaps used to foster more criminal activity. So the exercise has been extremely successful.

Senator Foreman asked whether any new trend was apparent. Quite clearly, the seizure of 200 kilograms of cocaine worth $160m is extremely worrying. It seems to indicate that what I prophesied some years ago—namely, that the drug barons and the warlords of Central America, having saturated the North American and European markets, would target Australia—is the case or, and perhaps additionally, that Australia is being used as a transit country from Central and South America across to Australia and then up into south-east and north Asia and perhaps even into Europe. If a cargo or passenger movement out of Australia is looked at by Customs in one of those countries, it thinks its origin is Australia and perhaps does not think in terms of cocaine.

I believe we are at a new stage. We have to make it very clear, as I believe these seizures do, to those involved in the trade in cocaine that they will not succeed in their attempts to flood the Australian market, and I believe that message must be getting through.

It must be said that 70 per cent of Australian police seizures of drugs now come from intelligence gathered abroad through our embassy network and through cooperation with overseas law enforcement agencies. That shows the great wisdom of this particular network being established. I believe honourable senators would wish to acknowledge how good that has been. The cooperation of the Customs Service particularly has led to very remarkable inroads into drug trafficking into Australia. It means that we can say that, whilst we may not have won entirely, as I said to Senator Reid yesterday, the law enforcement agencies are working well in their attempts to stop supply.

The other part of the story in Australia must be to convince young Australians, through education and other programs such as the drug offensive program and through using sports heroes as drug offensive ambassadors, not to indulge in drug abuse. That is the other part of the strategy of the Australian Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy. Health and police Ministers are all agreed in a way which is unique in the world and which gives us great strength in the fight against drug abuse.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the Prime Minister's multi-million dollar pig venture and his denial in the Age on 16 September that the joint venture had not been the subject of any ministerial talks and that he had no intention of importing any pigs or breeding material from anywhere. I ask how this can be so when a meeting was held on 8 April this year between Mr Crean and Danish Agricultural Minister Tornaes and the ministerial recall note read into Estimates Hansard by Senator Cook states:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Crean said he was pleased with the progress evident in pork joint ventures.

An AQIS memo tabled last week shows that at this meeting the two Ministers discussed access for pig meat and pig semen. Why did Mr Keating mislead the Australian public when he told the Age that the joint venture had not been the subject of any ministerial talks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is terribly important that Senator Boswell, in trying to develop a plot, understand his own plot. His own plot over many weeks has been to say, first, that the Prime Minister changed the foreign investment guidelines; secondly, that he tried to import live pigs; and, thirdly, that the value of the company had changed and it was now a multi-million dollar company. The latest issue is the tabling of the document.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell's original plot was to allege that there had been ministerial representations in support of the Prime Minister's business interests. That is what Senator Boswell was trying to establish. That is why he did not give me page 2 of this document. The first paragraph on page 2 says:

ANSWER.PARA: AQIS has received no requests or directions from any Minister, the Prime Minister or their staff to progress the issues of access to Australia for Danish pigmeat, live pigs or pig reproductive material.

That is the end of Senator Boswell's conspiracy. That is the end of the conspiracy Senator Boswell created. So he comes in here and puts in the first page of the document, which contradicts, I admit, the minutes which are already available to him of the ministerial meeting, and leaves out page 2, because page 2 spells the end of Senator Boswell's little plot. That is why I described his efforts as grubby.

PARA.TAB: As for Senator Boswell's allegation that this is a multi-million dollar business, this has been an effort by Senator Baume, amongst others, to make the point that the Prime Minister was a 50 per cent shareholder in a company called Euphron valued at $8.6m at 30 June 1991. The fact of the matter is that as at 30 June 1991 the company was owned by a number of shareholders, not just two as it now is. Under standing accounting practice, shareholders' equity, including the funds of all shareholders, was taken into account and a note in relation to subordinated capital was put into the accounts. Senator Baume understands these facts, but has chosen to ignore them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That is the most extraordinary non-answer that I have ever experienced in this Parliament. In my question I referred to the Age article which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Keating says the joint venture has not been the subject of any ministerial talks, nor has it been involved in. . . the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service .
I asked the Minister how the Prime Minister could make that accusation to the Age when it was clearly the subject of ministerial talks. Senator Cook read into the Hansard the following:
Mr Crean said he was pleased with the progress evident in the pork joint venture.

An AQIS memo tabled last week shows that the two Ministers—Minister Tornaes and Minister Crean—discussed access for pig meat and pig semen. There it is in black and white. There was a meeting. Will the Minister address the meeting and not every other irrelevant detail that has been brought up.

TALK.START.PARA: —The part that is in black and white—and bold type black and white—is the part which shoots down Senator Boswell's particular theory. That is the part he did not put in, and he deliberately did not put it in.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell knows, as he pretends to be an expert on this topic, that I tabled in this place the relevant section of the transcript of discussions between Mr Crean and the Danish Minister. That is before him, yet Senator Boswell still comes in here and says, `I refer to this document and at the bottom of the page it says, as an assertion from an official, that the Danish Minister for Agriculture raised the matter of uncooked pig meat with Mr Crean'.

Senator Boswell should understand why he is here. He is playing politics, and the burden of his politics is to say that the Prime Minister, or other Ministers, used influence to support a private activity of the Prime Minister. That is the allegation he is making. When he wants to substantiate that allegation, he does it by putting in half a document, not the document which is totally relevant to that allegation. I am not going to bother with Senator Boswell any more, because I am very disappointed with this selective tearing up of documents, and putting this sort of stuff in, in order to try to create arguments which do not exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister to table the document from which he quoted in his answer relating to the extent of Mr Keating's interest in this joint venture.
—I am not tabling anything. I do not have to table anything.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and relates to the $30 a week youth training allowance saga. I remind the Minister of his response to a question from me on 2 June this year when he assured me that payment would be made to all those who were entitled. I also draw his attention to a media release from the responsible Minister, Mr Baldwin, dated 31 July, with the headline `Government pays under 21 year olds backdated training assistance allowance'. Given that it is well over four months since the Minister's assurance, and two and a half months since Minister Baldwin's media release, why is it that there are still 300 or more applications from young unemployed South Australians waiting to be processed in Adelaide because of a lack of cooperation from the Department of Employment, Education and Training?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a brief which advises me on this subject that there are no applications outstanding that were current at either of the dates on which I gave the Senate an assurance, upon advice from the Department, or on the date on which Mr Baldwin issued his press release. They have all been dealt with. No applications received prior to 8 September are presently before the relevant unit within the Department of Employment, Education and Training for processing. As I understand this brief, all of the applications up until 8 September have been dealt with. Finally, all applications that have been received since 8 September, up until today, will be paid out on 21 October this year. I hope that resolves the question Senator Lees has raised.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I refer the Minister to recent press reports stating that the new AQIS charges are a serious impediment to trade. Why were these new higher inspection charges introduced at a time when the economy is still suffering from the devastating effects of the recession we had to have and when all encouragement should be given to the increase in exports? What is the justification for the daily inspection rate of $745 and the hourly rate of $172 when, for total cost recovery, applying a staff-expenditure multiplier of 1.92 gives an hourly rate of only $55.88? Can the Minister confirm that the $55.88 hourly rate would roughly equate to the New Zealand charge for these services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my understanding that AQIS is moving to a situation of full cost recovery in terms of the provision of its services and that this has been a phased move towards full cost recovery. The basis of establishing the principle of full cost recovery is that those who use the services of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service should pay for them and that all other taxpayers who do not use that service should not have to pay for them. In other words, there should be no cross-subsidisation and the users of the service should meet the cost of delivering the service.

PARA.TAB: The other principle here is that one of the reasons many Australian companies succeed in penetrating foreign markets with Australian exports of quarantinable materials is the very high standard that Australian products enjoy because of the work of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. If we had a lesser quality service our reputation abroad would be less impressive. We have a high quality service; our reputation abroad is good, and that is a very important selling point in marketing Australian products and produce abroad.

Senator Archer asked me about how the elements of the charge-out rate are composed and how that charge-out rate compares to that of another country—New Zealand. I do not have that information available to me. If I may, I will put that element of Senator Archer's question on notice and obtain an answer from the relevant Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald which reports on a Treasury analysis of the effects of a goods and services tax if workers believe they would be inadequately compensated for the inflationary effects of the tax? Is the Government considering introducing such a consumption tax? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the likely effects of such a tax on wages policy and the macro-economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —An article appeared on page 3 of today's Sydney Morning Herald headed, `GST may undermine economy'. The opening paragraph of the article states:

PARA.TAB: Economic growth would be retarded for a decade—down by as much as 4 per cent—and inflation would soar by 12 per cent if workers sought wage increases to offset the Opposition's GST, according to a Treasury analysis of the Fightback package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Treasury!

—I hear an interjection, `Treasury'. I might say that members of the coalition have used Treasury documents where it supports their case and have praised the impartiality of the Treasury analysis to support their contention. But when Treasury analysis does not support their contention they blackguard Treasury and accuse Treasury of being a servant of the Government.

PARA.TAB: These are the same Treasury officers who modelled the Fightback package to see what the wage effects of Fightback would be and who concluded, according to this summary, that inflation would soar by 12 per cent and growth would be down by 4 per cent. If one goes to the actual source document, one will see that unemployment will balloon out as well. That is the impact on wages policy of the Opposition's Fightback package.

We are not going to introduce a consumption tax which will impose on 70 per cent of households in this country a further cost increase and which will cause workers in this country to say that they require wage compensation for the impacts of a pernicious consumption tax. I think people in those 70 per cent of households would be justified in saying, `This is a tax the Government has imposed. We are entitled to some compensatory wage increases'.

What will happen in this economy is what we saw in the early 1980s and late 1970s—a wages explosion in Australia, an inflation explosion in Australia, with the real value of wages declining in the hands of workers and the outcome of living standards dropping even further. We got off that treadmill with the accord. We got moderate wage outcome, we got maintenance of disposable household income per capita, we got a managed restructuring of the economy and we got massive export growth in manufactured goods as the advantages of the accord structure worked their way through to promote the export of manufactured goods and services, particularly in this region of the world.

I remind the Senate of what happened when John Howard—now the shadow Minister for industrial relations—was the Treasurer in the Fraser Government. Under his policies at the time, wages growth in September 1982 was 18.8 per cent. The Treasury model shows that we would see those levels of inflation and wages explosion again were a consumption tax to be introduced.

The Opposition policy is a low wage policy—grind wages down, increase taxes, lower the skills and training opportunities of Australian workers and introduce massive confrontation and industrial dislocation in Australia. It is one of the reasons why Australians recognise that we handle industrial relations better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, under standing order 72, my question is addressed to Senator Short. The question relates to notice of motion 1028 in which Senator Short refers to taxation. Does Senator Short regard this as an urgent motion and, if so, does he intend bringing it forward for debate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is an urgent motion, and I do intend to try to bring it forward for debate. I thank Senator Kemp for his question. It has become particularly urgent in the light of Senator Cook's scurrilous reply to the question from Senator Devereux. It has become particularly important following the disclosure overnight of a Treasury document which the Government has deliberately attempted to conceal now for over five months and which has been flushed out only through an FOI request.

PARA.TAB: That old Treasury document examined the implications of the changes contained in the coalition's tax reform proposals. Those proposals, I remind the Senate, are to cut personal income tax by almost one-third; and to reduce massively the taxes on the costs of producing goods and services in Australia by abolishing seven major taxes, including wholesale sales tax, the payroll tax on jobs, and the tax on fuel. Instead of pouring cold water on the coalition's proposals, the Treasury document, on the contrary, severely embarrasses the Government, and that is why it has been kept under wraps. Despite every effort to put as bad a light as possible on the implications of the coalition's tax reform proposals, the best the Treasury could come up with was a heavily qualified paper that stressed:

ANSWER.PARA: Overall, we would strongly caution against placing too much weight on any particular model-based outcome of this nature.

They were words that the Treasury strongly underlined. The fact is that this Treasury document totally pulls the rug from under one of the Prime Minister's favourite scare campaign tactics about the effects of the coalition's proposal.

PARA.TAB: We know from a Treasury source that the Treasury produced this document under duress. It was forced by Treasurer Dawkins to incorporate in its modelling a quite false assumption. In its first analysis of the Fightback proposals, the Treasury had specifically dismissed this assumption because it knew it was an absolute nonsense. It agreed with the coalition's views that, if people were fully compensated for the introduction of the GST, as they will be, there would be no wages claim leading to a wage-price spiral and there would be benefit to every Australian.

The bottom line in this sorry political attempt at a hatchet job by the Government is that it has backfired very badly on the Government. It simply goes to show that putting rubbish into a model produces a rubbish result. Treasurer Dawkins should be absolutely ashamed of himself for forcing the Treasury to undertake such an appallingly unprofessional exercise. I am absolutely amazed that, even with the political pressure exerted on the Treasury by the Treasurer, the Treasury would have allowed itself to be party to such a document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Short: why does he think Senator Cook consistently misleads the Senate over the impact of our Fightback document, which will cut taxes?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. They cannot get away with this. Senator Kemp accused me of misleading the Senate. That is factually not true, it is unparliamentary as well, and it ought to be withdrawn. Mr President, I ask you to direct Senator Kemp, if he is not gracious enough himself to recognise the error of his ways, to withdraw that allegation.
—Order! If the point of order was that it is unparliamentary, I do not think it is.
—It was not a supplementary question.
—Order! I had not finished. I do not believe that it was a proper supplementary question.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I call Senator Button.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I seek your guidance: did you rule out that supplementary question?
—Yes, I did.
—May I ask on what grounds?
—It was not a proper supplementary question. It did not refer to the question that had been asked.
—Mr President, on the point order—
—Order! Senator Kemp, I made a ruling. The Leader of the Government asked that further questions be placed on notice, and I called him to answer a question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 October, Senator Bishop asked me a question about the Taxation Office allegedly being in possession of serious allegations of tax avoidance involving a Labor Party member, and so on. She asked whether I would inform the Senate whether or not the matter was being pursued with vigour, et cetera. The answer to Senator Bishop's question which I have obtained from the Treasury is as follows:Senator Bishop's allegations of political bias on the part of the Australian Taxation Office have been refuted by the Commissioner for Taxation in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry into the ATO. Senator Bishop, being a member of the Public Accounts Committee, is fully aware of the Commissioner's responses to her allegations of political bias.

PARA.TAB: As pointed out to the PAC, 87 politicians have been audited over the last three years. Thirty-seven of these are Labor members, 30 are Liberal, 14 National and six Independent or other parties. All cases have been treated in accordance with the ATO guidelines. It is not lawful for there to be external political involvement in ATO tax related decision making. As the Commissioner for Taxation stated to the PAC:

ANSWER.PARA: There should be none, there has been none, there is none.

Allegations of tax avoidance by taxpayers are followed up by the ATO, irrespective of political standing. Naturally, secrecy provisions do not allow specific comments about a taxpayer's affairs. However, the envelope provided by Senator Bishop has been referred to the ATO, which undoubtedly will pursue the matter in its usual professional way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator O'Chee asked me a question concerning the Civil Aviation Authority and the inquiry by the Hon. Ian Macphee into the advanced air traffic control system. I have obtained some further advice to add to the answer I gave yesterday.

PARA.TAB: Martin-Marietta is a United States company whose involvement in air traffic control includes providing system engineering and integration support to the FAA for its capital investment programs and projects. Martin-Marietta was included in Thomson's TAATS bid to provide support to Thomson in the area of project management. It is not providing equipment or systems in the Thomson bid, only services.

Thomson advised the CAA informally during June that it was having some problems in its business relationship with Martin-Marietta. This applied not only to the TAATS project, but also to its partnership bidding for other projects. Martin-Marietta wrote to the CAA on 11 August advising that it would be unlikely to be included in the Thomson CSF TAATS team. As I stated yesterday in response to Senator O'Chee's question, the CAA's discussions and negotiations with Thomson on TAATS were suspended on 10 July and a tender process is on hold pending the outcome of the Macphee review.
Therefore, I say it is unreasonable, as Senator O'Chee's question seems to conclude, that Martin-Marietta pulled out as a consequence of the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Pursuant to standing order 168, I request that the Minister table the document from which he was quoting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) this day, in response to a question asked by Senator Bishop on 12 October 1992, relating to certain allegations of tax avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: On many occasions senators have risen and, under the provisions of chapter 11 of the Standing Orders and standing order 193, have taken objection to a question or an answer. Mr President, you have said, in my view quite properly, that if you were to apply that chapter and that standing order, very few questions would be admissible and many answers would similarly not be admissible.

PARA.TAB: That chapter and that rule were put into the Standing Orders, I think very sensibly, by our predecessors in this place. When one looks at these orders one realises just how sensible our predecessors were. These standing orders have the purpose of ensuring that questions are asked in an orderly manner and that some sense of fairness is brought into debates—fairness not only to senators but also to others.

I submit to you, Mr President, that there is a high risk that the question that was asked of Senator Button greatly ridiculed and brought into contempt the Taxation Office and members of the parliamentary Labor Party in New South Wales. It is not the first time that that sort of question has been asked; it is not the first time that an answer has been elicited and matters have been addressed. Senator Watson is in the chamber. He is a man of, I think, high repute who exemplifies to a great degree the sorts of people we have in this chamber. But at times matters are put forward that I think bring us all into disgrace.

The High Court has recently brought down a judgment in the political advertisements case. There has been much discussion about that decision. In the course of that discussion the point was made that Parliament does not conduct itself as it should, that it does not protect the liberties of people as it should, and that it does not do what it ought to do. I think there is much merit in those propositions. The only way we are going to rid ourselves of that reputation and the only way we are going to get around to acting as we ought is, given the general thrust that goes on in debate, to be fair and reasonable in the sorts of questions we ask and to be fair and reasonable in how we go about denigrating other people.

The question asked by Senator Bishop is, unfortunately, an example of what I am talking about. The question was handled with great drama. It was brought across in an envelope. I must say that I thought there was great concern to be felt about what was in that envelope; that there was great concern to be entertained in terms of the parliamentary Labor Party in New South Wales; and that there was great concern to be entertained in terms of members of the Tax Office. It appears from the answer that Senator Button gave today that there is just no merit in that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you recognised Senator Cooney before you recognised me. I was intending to move to take note of the same answer because I found it utterly unacceptable, as indeed I found the letter from the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, yesterday, which I tabled and of which presumably Senator Button has a copy but which he failed to table.

PARA.TAB: I am interested today that Senator Button chose to quote from the gratuitous information the Commissioner of Taxation set out in a submission to the Public Accounts Committee dealing with a particular class of taxpayers whom he has chosen to investigate. He gratuitously did that. Mr President, I put to you that the Commissioner of Taxation has created an enormous precedent for himself and one we will be pursuing with regard to other categories. Whereas he admitted to investigating a large number of parliamentarians, what Senator Button failed to point out was that only three of those parliamentarians have been prosecuted, and—surprise, surprise!—they are all Liberal Party people.

The next surprise is this: I have placed on the record from time to time—and I have been assiduous in saying it—my concern about matters that are on the public record. The only things we have on the public record are the preferential treatment the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) received when he failed to lodge not one but two tax returns, and when he got a nice letter saying, `Please, would you mind awfully dropping it in'. There was no threat of legal proceedings; no threats at all, just a nice pleasant letter. Mr Keating is the man who was the Commissioner's boss. There were 10,781 Australians prosecuted last year for not lodging a tax return, but not the Prime Minister.

I compare that with what happened to Mr Phillip Smiles, done for political purposes. The transcripts of the judgment are now on the record and can be dealt with without breaching the sub judice rule. We will go through that judgment later line by line. Mr Smiles was hounded, and he was prosecuted under the Crimes Act instead of under the Taxation Administration Act, which, on the Australian Taxation Office's own admission, is the normal way it is done. It is the first time it has ever done that, the reason being that Mr Smiles will lose his seat.

I compared the two cases and asked a question, in full knowledge of the fact that the Commissioner is investigating this Labor Party politician. I have a copy of the record of interview of three witnesses—not one, not two, but three—which has been in existence for six months. Furthermore, three months ago it was put on the public record. Further, I want to compare the time that was taken in the investigation and prosecution of Mr Smiles and the time taken in dealing with this case.

My concern is that we have fair and even-handed actions. We have seen evidence of politicisation of the Public Service. We saw it again today with the use of this Treasury report, which the Government tried to heavy the Treasury into preparing. It then tried to hide it, until the Sydney Morning Herald got it out under an FOI. Senator Short brought that to the attention of the Senate today. Again and again and again there are examples of the politicisation of the Public Service and duress on behalf of people who sit on that side of the Parliament. It has to come to an end.

I have received a letter from a little lady at Bass Hill, who said, `Thank you for the stand you're taking against the injustice of the Taxation Office'. She set outs her case about how she was hounded for $298.11 and threatened with action. We need some justice in this system. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is yet another example of Senator Bishop's overweening self-regard and ambition. Along with Senator Baume, she is the arch smearer and slanderer of the Australian Senate. She would say anything—
—Order! Withdraw that, Senator Faulkner.

—I withdraw it, Mr President. Her aspirations to the Ministry have fortunately been thwarted at every turn by the parliamentary Liberal Party. While I have very little in common with Dr Hewson, one good thing he has done is to give Senator Bishop the royal order of the boot to the back bench—precisely where she belongs—for this sort of tactic, this smearing of individuals.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I draw your attention to the blatant disregard for relevancy and ask you to ask Senator Faulkner to direct himself to the motion and the substance of it.
—Senator Faulkner, I think you ought to be more relevant to the question before the Chair.

—I will, Mr President. I am addressing myself to this low-life stunt—handing over an envelope during Question Time which, in effect, smears every single Labor member of the New South Wales Parliament. That is what she is about.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I point out that at the end of Question Time you imposed a fairly strict interpretation on a particular matter I raised in relation to the nature of a supplementary question. If you are imposing a strict interpretation of Standing Orders, it is very clear that Senator Faulkner is way outside those Standing Orders at the moment.
—I asked Senator Faulkner to be more relevant and I am sure he will be.

—I am pointing out that the handing over of an envelope containing a media transcript is the same sort of low tactic that we saw from Senator Bishop prior to the last election over the Castlereagh by-election; the same sort of thing that happened when senior Foreign Affairs bureaucrats were attacked.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Sit down, Faulkner.
—Order! I will tell people whether they should sit down or not.

—Mr President, I put it to you that Senator Faulkner is blatantly disregarding your ruling and I ask you to bring him back to the relevance of the matter under debate. He is clearly flouting your ruling.

—I wish to speak to the point of order, Mr President. Apart from the obvious sensitivity of people on the other side, it is quite clear that Senator Faulkner is saying that this answer responds to a question which is part of a series of actions which are of a consistent pattern. It is quite clear and relevant to be able to say that these are the events which put this question within the context of a pattern of behaviour. It is absolutely in order. —I asked Senator Faulkner to relate his remarks to the issue that was before the Chair. On the last occasion he hardly got a word out before another point of order was taken, but I will ask him to do that.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am making the point as strongly as I can that in this overriding attempt from Senator Bishop that we see literally day after day in the Senate chamber for no purpose other than self-publicity, promoting herself—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. You will understand that I will stand on my feet every time Senator Faulkner defies your ruling. —Order! Earlier in the debate, Senator Faulkner made remarks which were unparliamentary. I asked him to withdraw them and he did. At this stage, I do not think he has made further unparliamentary remarks.

—This is part of a pattern which we have seen from Senator Bishop over a long period. Who can forget the totally outrageous and completely unfounded attacks that were made by her in relation to the Castlereagh by-election? It is part of a pattern. Who can forget the attacks on senior—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I rise again on the same point of relevancy.
—Yes, I really cannot see how the Castlereagh by-election has anything to do with the case which is before us today.
—Said in the sleazebag mentality of the Right of the ALP.
—Order!
—Are you going to withdraw that?
—Order!

PARA.TAB: On this occasion, there was an attempt to dramatise the situation by handing to Senator Button across the table of this Senate a press extract smearing every Labor member of the New South Wales Parliament. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a short statement.

—If somebody else wants to speak I will resume my seat.

—I listened with some interest to the matters which Senator Cooney raised in moving that the Senate take note of the answer. TALK.START.PARA: —I join with Senator Macdonald in supporting Senator Cooney's remarks because I have a very serious concern also about the way this Parliament is being misused. However, I want to refer particularly to the matter that was responded to on this occasion by Senator Button, the question and the answer which it elicited. PARA.TAB: It is true that the 87 audits to which Senator Bishop referred have led to only three prosecutions of Liberals. The decision to prosecute those people was made by the Director of Public Prosecutions, who has already pointed out in a letter to Senator Bishop—which she apparently has not made apparent to her colleagues, who still think she is getting the facts right about the Smiles case—that the Crimes Act charge was laid in the Smiles case because no equivalent offence exists under the Taxation Administration Act. Senator Bishop has said that this is the first time someone has been charged with an apportionment matter under the Crimes Act.

The fact of the matter is that he has not been charged with an apportionment offence; he has been charged with offences to do with making false statements, keeping false records and encouraging others to make false statements. The reason that he has been charged under the Crimes Act is that they are breaches of the Crimes Act. They are very serious offences with which he has been charged. They are not the equivalent of making a late return, about which many people have had letters, and Senator Bishop knows—

—I have said all that I need to say about the Smiles case. Any concern that has been expressed about prejudicing a fair hearing has been expressed by others about Senator Bishop's behaviour. PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in response to a question asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to foreign investment in Australia and the possible takeover of Arnotts Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: In his reply to my supplementary question, Senator Button indicated that the Foreign Investment Review Board had power to adjudicate on this matter. I have before me the functions of the Board. The first reads:

PARA.TAB: to examine proposals by foreign interests for investment in Australia and—

SPEECH.PARA: this is the significant qualifying thing—
against the background of the Government's foreign investment policy to make recommendations to the Government on these proposals.

So Senator Button's reply was a complete tautology. I asked him what the Government's policy was with respect to this and he said that the Foreign Investment Review Board has the jurisdiction. Clearly, the Foreign Investment Review Board must be guided by that policy, which Senator Button in his churlishness, or coyness, is not prepared to disclose.

PARA.TAB: So the question still stands against Senator Button and the Government: what is the Government's position in relation to these purchases of Australian industry by foreign interests—in this case a business that has shown itself to be highly profitable and one which, by all accounts, could move into the Asian market without the intervention of foreign interests, to which a large proportion—presumably well over 50 per cent—of the profits would then flow.

The other functions of the Board are to advise the Government, to foster an awareness and to provide guidance. None of these things gives the Foreign Investment Review Board the sorts of powers Senator Button was claiming. I believe that Senator Button in his supplementary reply was misleading the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to explore some of the assumptions in Senator Button's answer to Senator Coulter about the benefits to Australia from foreign investment. Senator Button seemed to assume that international takeovers lead to some sort of better management. I ask: where is the evidence? In the case of Arnotts, it is a buoyant, well managed Australian company. What does Senator Button know about what new management will do to improve its situation? He has said previously that we can benefit from technology transfer. I think Iced Vo Vos are a very good indication of the merits of maintaining a traditional recipe and a traditional process. I do not think we can look to much technology transfer in biscuit making.

PARA.TAB: This takeover of Arnotts is really about using Australia as a bridge to Asia. We have to ask what economic benefit Australia will get out of it. The Foreign Investment Review Board report of 1991 showed that, although Australia made $2.3 billion from overseas equity in 1990, foreigners made $6 billion from their Australian equity—three times as much. It begs the question: what sort of fair exchange is this? The truth of the matter is that the foreign investment policy of this Labor Government has been very one-sided. It has been, `Come in; take what you want on your terms. We are really desperate here for a bit of cash. We don't want to set any rules. We don't want to discourage you, goodness me no'.

When we decide that we need foreign investment, we must ensure that it benefits Australia and we must accept that investment on our terms. For far too long it has been `Come in. Take what you want', with absolutely no opposition proposed by that rubber stamp called the Foreign Investment Review Board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not in the chamber, but I was in my office with the Senate monitor on when Senator Bishop was making a few remarks about my activities as a senator and my interest in human rights issues.

PARA.TAB: I want to put the record straight in regard to the accusation that I am not often in the chamber. That is true. I, like all senators, have many commitments outside this chamber with committees and so on. Particularly, as chairman of the human rights subcommittee of the Australian Parliament, I have commitments to meet people, not only from within Australia but from overseas, who wish to see me to raise human rights issues.

This means that I am not in the chamber perhaps as often as Senator Bishop or some other senators are. But I believe it is part of my function as chairman of that subcommittee, as well as Chairman of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee, to meet those people who have requested an appointment to raise issues of concern.

The honourable senator also made some remarks about my being more interested in the collective than the individual. I must say that on every parliamentary delegation I have been involved in representing this Parliament overseas, and on private visits to various countries overseas, I have, almost without exception, raised individual human rights on behalf of individual cases that I am aware of. Names are supplied by Amnesty International, Asia Watch and the human rights section of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and other names are raised by members of the Australian community.

In the next month I will be leading a parliamentary delegation to Indonesia. Already preparations are being made so that when we are in Indonesia we can raise human rights issues, both collectively and on an individual basis, with people in Indonesia. In November I will be leading the second human rights delegation to China, and again we will be raising human rights issues relating both to individuals and to collective human rights issues. Those names have been given to me, the committee and the delegation by Australian citizens.

I also wish to point out to Senator Bishop that by the end of this year the first annual report of the human rights subcommittee on Australia's efforts to promote human rights will be tabled in this Parliament. It will deal not only with human rights overseas but also with Australia's obligations domestically in promoting human rights. Obviously, I do not have access to the drafting of that report, but when Senator Bishop sees that report she will realise that her remarks that I am not interested in human rights within Australia, whether collectively or individually, are wrong.

I welcome this opportunity to explain to Senator Bishop and others that, while my attendance in the Senate may not be 100 per cent, I have absolutely legitimate reasons for meeting people as part of my obligations in chairing parliamentary committees.

The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Student Assistance Amendment Bill seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973. The Act provides the statutory basis for the AUSTUDY scheme, which since its introduction in 1987 has been a purely grants-based scheme. It also provides a debt management regime for ABSTUDY and the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme.
Australia has one of the world's best student financial support schemes, which is one reason we have one of the world's most equitable higher education systems.
Since 1983
the number of secondary students in receipt of income support has increased by 350%
the number of tertiary recipients has increased by 125%
the real value of maximum benefits has increased by 11% for tertiary students and 115% for secondary students.
The Government is committed to building on these achievements.
This Bill, and other improvements announced in the Budget, will make a good scheme even better.
AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY Supplement
The major provision in the Bill is to provide for the introduction in 1993 of a Supplement to AUSTUDY and ABSTUDY which will give students greater flexibility in meeting their financial needs.
The Supplement will be repayable under very favourable conditions, which I will describe shortly.

As announced by the Treasurer in his Budget speech, the Supplement will be available to tertiary students who are eligible for grants through AUSTUDY or ABSTUDY. The Supplement will not be available to secondary students. Students will gain access to the Supplement by "trading in" $1 of their grant to secure $2 of the Supplement. In each year, the amount of Supplement available to a student will be between $500 and $4000.

The Supplement will also extend to tertiary students who would otherwise be eligible for a grant except that their parental income is too high, where that income is less than $50 000. This group of students will need to satisfy all other eligibility criteria for either AUSTUDY or ABSTUDY, and will have access to between $500 and $2000 each year.
Voluntary nature of the Supplement

A major point to note about the Supplement is that it is voluntary. The Bill provides that the real value of grants under AUSTUDY will be maintained by the continuation of indexation of maximum living allowances. The Supplement will, therefore, provide an opportunity for students to gain access to additional financial resources if they so choose.

The Government is aware that students' financial needs vary considerably. For example, rents in Sydney are far higher than in many parts of Australia; the availability of part-time or vacation work differs significantly from one region to another; some courses have significantly higher costs for books and materials than others; parents with the same incomes may differ in their willingness and ability to support their student children.
It is not possible to design a grant scheme which takes into account all these significant differences. The Supplement will give students access to more resources at their own choice.
Provision of the Supplement

The Bill provides for the Government to undertake a competitive process for the Supplement to be provided to eligible students by the private financial sector. It is envisaged that an initial contract will be signed with a financial corporation for a five-year period.
The Commonwealth will pay interest on each Supplement for five years. At the end of five years, the Commonwealth will assume responsibility for un-repaid Supplements from the financial institution.

The Department of Employment, Education and Training will continue to assess students' eligibility for AUSTUDY or ABSTUDY, and will provide students with an Application for Supplement Form if they are eligible. Students can then enter an agreement with the financial institution if they wish to take up the Supplement.
The Supplement will be paid to students on a fortnightly basis, in tandem with their AUSTUDY or ABSTUDY grants where these are also being received.
Repayment conditions

Supplement recipients will be able to choose to make repayments during the five year period leading up to the Commonwealth taking over outstanding amounts. Such repayments will attract a discount of 15%.

After the Commonwealth has taken over the liability, former recipients of the Supplement will be required to make repayments through the Australian Taxation Office in a similar manner to the repayment of Higher Education Contributions (HECS) through the taxation system.

For example, in the 1992-93 income year repayments are set at 2% of taxable income from $27 748 to $31 532, 3% of taxable income from $31 533 to $44 146 and 4% of taxable income of $44 147 or more. Those taxable income thresholds are indexed annually to movements in the Consumer Price Index so that, when the first Supplement repayments are made through the taxation system in 1997-98, the Supplement repayment thresholds will be the same as for HECS. Appropriate amendments are being made to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
A Supplement recipient whose taxable income does not reach the first threshold in a particular year will not be required to make a repayment in that year.
No interest on repayments

Recipients of the Supplement will not be charged a real interest rate. Outstanding balances will, however, be indexed on an annual basis to movements in the Consumer Price Index to maintain their real value. Even taking into account the up-front cost to those students required to trade-in all or part of their grant to gain access to the Supplement, these conditions compare very favourably with commercial loans.

Given the likely earnings of students after they complete their studies, and taking into account the 15% discount offered for repayments in the first five years, the Supplement will be an attractive proposition for many students. In most cases, it will be much more favourable than any commercial loan available to students.
Indexation provisions

Student groups who have demonstrated against the introduction of student loans have not been able to put forward any convincing argument against the details of the Supplement which the Government is to introduce. However, there is genuine concern among students that the introduction of the Supplement could be used to subsequently reduce access to student grants.
For this reason, the Bill seeks to legislate the indexation procedures which have been followed since the introduction of AUSTUDY in 1987.
To achieve this, the Bill includes provision to index maximum allowances under AUSTUDY to movements in the Consumer Price Index.
Data-Matching

Under the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990, student assistance is included in the Data Matching Program. The Bill will amend the Data-Matching Act to include the AUSTUDY/ ABSTUDY Supplement in the student assistance provisions covered by that Act.
Financial impact
The Government expects that more than 100,000 students will take up the Supplement in 1993, rising to about 150,000 in 1994 and more than 180,000 in 1995.

The only early-year Commonwealth outlays will be contractual obligations, primarily comprising interest payments to the financial institution and compensation to that institution for discounts provided for early repayments. Significant savings will be generated to the Budget as students "trade in" all or part of their AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY grant to gain access to the Supplement.

In real terms, the Supplement is estimated to produce Budget savings in all years except for a short period following the commencement of the Commonwealth purchase of outstanding amounts. Savings will rise to over $150 million per year by 2002-03, as repayments through the taxation system increase.
Budget savings are estimated to be $42 million in 1992-93, rising to almost $115 million in 1993-94 and $138 million in 1994-95.
Conclusion
This Bill introduces major reforms to financial assistance for students in Australia. Students' access to financial support at the time it is needed will be greatly enhanced.

I note that two other enhancements to AUSTUDY were announced in the Budget speech, and will be introduced by way of amendments to the AUSTUDY Regulations. These are, firstly, a progressive reduction in the age of independence—that is, the age at which the parental income test no longer applies—from 25 now to 22 in 1995. The second enhancement is an increase in the personal income test threshold from $5000 now to $6000 in 1993.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill, which gives additional details.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Devereux, and on behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present report No. 9 Belconnen, ACT—Office Construction at Section 45, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate a statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: TABLING STATEMENT—PRESENTATION OF COMMITTEE REPORT—SENATOR JOHN DEVEREUX
OFFICE CONSTRUCTION AT SECTION 45, BELCONNEN, ACT

The Committee's Ninth report for 1992 deals with the construction of a five-storey office building in the Canberra suburb of Belconnen. The building will be occupied by the ACT regional office of the Australian Taxation Office.
It will have a gross floor area of 22,000 square metres of which 14,100 square metres will be for offices.
The ground floor of the building will contain public access areas and an automatic document dispatch centre. The four upper storeys will contain office areas and staff amenities.
The estimated completed cost of the building will not exceed $40.9 million.

The report recommends that the work should proceed, and also recommends a number of features being incorporated in the design. These involve the installation of a gas cogeneration plant to provide electrical power to the building, the installation of a dimmed lighting, as opposed to a switched control lighting system, the removal of fill from the site and landscaping.

A number of arguments were advanced which purported to demonstrated that the use of a gas cogeneration plant in the building would not be practical or economic. The Committee remains unconvinced about the weight of these arguments and has recommended that a gas cogeneration plant be installed. A gas cogeneration plant has a number of environmental benefits and its installation in a building owned by the Commonwealth will be a reflection of the Government's commitment to energy conservation and to reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

The Committee has recommended that the building be provided with an automatic light dimming system. The system adjusts light levels automatically to compensate for the amount of daylight reaching the inside of the building. On bright sunny days, the lights are automatically dimmed, and on overcast days or during darkness, the light intensity is automatically increased. The Committee believes this method of lighting control is far superior to a switched control system.

The site contains a large amount of fill which will need to be removed before excavation can commence. The Committee has recommended that the contract for the removal of the fill should not preclude its sale by the successful tenderer. Nevertheless, the final destination of the fill should be determined and if it is offered for sale, the cost of its removal should be adjusted accordingly.
The Committee questioned the extent and cost of landscaping proposed and has recommended that the scope of landscaping be reduced.

In view of its current heavy workload, the Committee has decided to table a short report recommending that the work proceed and enabling Australian Estate Management to adhere to its construction timetable.
It must nevertheless be made clear that the Committee is seriously concerned about being placed in this situation.
I make the following points in this regard lest there is any subsequent comment about the Committee's processes causing delays to the commencement of public works.

In late January Australian Estate Management requested the Committee to approve the commencement of design and documentation and preliminary tender negotiations. The Committee agreed with this in late February. AEM was hoping for an early hearing into the proposal and for the Committee's report to be tabled before the winter recess.
The proposal was not referred to the Committee until 25 June too late for the Committee to conduct its public hearing and present its report before the winter adjournment.

On 15 July Australian Estate Management sought the Committee's approval to call tenders for the excavation and foundation works in advance of the report being tabled in Parliament. The Committee's approval to do this was given on 28 July. The Committee at this time was optimistic that its report could be tabled by mid-October.

However, because of the large number of references which had been received by the Committee in the intervening months, which tended to rearrange the timetable of hearings and report preparation, and over which the Committee has very little control, the Committee was unable to meet this deadline.

On 28 September Australian Estate Management sought the Committee's approval to award the earth works contract in advance of the tabling of the Committee's report. The provisions of the Public Works Committee Act do not permit this course of action being followed.

This highlights the need for all departments and agencies to adhere closely to planned milestones during the development of a proposal. In this instance, AEM was planning proceeded on the basis of a favourable report from the Committee before the winter adjournment.

The Committee believes the time has come to give the strongest possible signal to all departments and agencies that, in future, it will not have imposed on it unreasonable and unrealistic schedules which presuppose peremptory inquiries and approval of works.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a couple of words about this report. As a member of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I would like to make the point that over the last few weeks—in fact over the last couple of months—there has been a tremendous amount of pressure on the Public Works Committee to push through projects that have been in the pipeline for some time. No doubt government departments and the like want to clear the decks before the election next year, and I wish to pay a compliment to the staff who have gone out of their way to accommodate the extra pressures that have been put on them.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, the matter of the Belconnen Tax Office should have come before us earlier. It is through no fault of the Public Works Committee that we have had to go out of our way to approve this building. We have had sittings outside normal times and do all sorts of things that we normally do not do in order to accommodate the Tax Office. This interim report, if it can be called that, had to be rushed through to allow work to start on this building.

There have been quite a few reservations about certain parts of the building. My colleague Senator Devereux has raised matters relating to the electrical aspects of the building; Senator Burns has raised questions about the tremendous cost of landscaping.

A fair amount of evidence—I think Senator Reid would be interested in this, although she is not in the chamber—was given to us by the national planning body and the ACT planning body with regard to some concerns about whether Belconnen was the right location for the ACT Tax Office. They suggested that it might have been more appropriate to put the national Tax Office in Belconnen and the ACT Tax Office in Civic. One would have thought that the headquarters of a Tax Office that is providing a service to the ACT would be located in what is acknowledged as the centre of the ACT, that is, Civic, rather than all the way out at Belconnen. But the powers that be decided that that was where it was to go. They even went to the trouble of conducting a poll to justify their locating this particular building at Belconnen.

The point was made by both planning authorities that the only people who had not been considered in this particular proposal were the people of Canberra. I suppose that, further down the track, if the national office gets bigger or vice versa they could swap buildings, but it just seems to me that there has been an awful rush and tear to get this particular building approved. I do not believe that a lot of the matters have been looked at possibly as well as they could have been.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills we are now debating, the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1992-93, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1992-93 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1992-93, comprise the Government's Budget Bills for the current financial year. We have had considerable debate on policy issues and the matters of detail flowing from the Budget decisions until now, but this is the first time the Senate has commenced debating the Appropriation Bills which comprise the Budget.

PARA.TAB: These Bills should be renamed the Bankcard Bills because they are Bills that seek to spend now and pay later. It is a clear indication of the way in which the Government sees the operation of fiscal policy. This Government has worked continually over recent years to attempt to buy our way out of trouble. Of course, the opposite will actually happen because one cannot buy one's way out of trouble. By attempting to do that, one simply buys one's way into still deeper problems.

These Bills constitute no more than an election bribe. These Bills were formulated on the basis that the Government may wish to run to an early election before Christmas this year. But even if that were not the case, it would engage in a big spending binge that would continue through the year and which, in the Government's own analysis, would attempt to pork barrel and pump prime the economy to try to get, at least temporarily, some of the one million unemployed Australians off the official lists and attempt to make the economy look vastly better than it is. We all know, as history has shown, that that leads to more and more intractable problems and a more difficult set of circumstances for our nation to try to work its way out of.

These Bills signal the misguided use of fiscal policy which, as I said, has been the hallmark of recent Labor Budgets. The only thing we can breathe easy about with this Budget by this Labor Government is that it will be its last.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) knows that this is a false and totally wrong use of fiscal policy. Just look at what he said in earlier Budget Speeches when he was the Treasurer. In his Budget Speech in 1986-87 he stated:
. . . we must save for the future rather than spend for the present.

PARA.TAB: The Government can help this process directly by spending less and borrowing less, thereby improving the climate for lower interest rates and for private sector investments.

SPEECH.PARA: In the following year, in the 1987-88 Budget, the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister Keating, said:

PARA.TAB: This Budget also lays the foundations for sound budgets over the life of this Parliament.
The savings are ongoing.

SPEECH.PARA: What a joke those statements have proved to be. What absolute falsehoods they have proved to be, because the Government has never at any time followed the edicts that are implied in those Budget Speeches. Those sentiments, very proper sentiments, very correct sentiments, sentiments of fiscal responsibility and prudence in government management, were never intended by this Government to be followed by performance. Instead, they have been thrown out of the window. It has all become far too hard.

PARA.TAB: This Government has run out of steam. This Government is in disarray. This Government does not know where it is going on policy, and that has been reflected in the latest Budget—in the Bills we are debating now—and it has been all too evident over the last couple of years. That is why, two days before the 1990 election just 2 1/2 years ago, the then Treasurer Keating and then Prime Minister Hawke both said to the Australian people, `There won't be a recession'. Indeed, the then Treasurer said, `We will not let there be a recession'.

Less than nine months after that, we were plunged into a very deep recession indeed. It was a recession that, for a long period of time, Mr Keating, as Treasurer, refused to acknowledge. He kept trying to talk the economy up at a time when the economy was obviously plunging down very rapidly. At the end of several months he was forced to say, because reality dictated that he could not do otherwise, that, yes, we did have a recession, yes, it was a recession we had to have and, `yes, it was a recession that I, Paul Keating, engineered'. But, he said, `I pulled the levers that got this nation into the recession. I'll pull the levers and we'll pull the nation out of recession'.

Two years later we are still in a very deep recession. Prime Minister Keating tried to tell us last week that the recession was long gone. That is absolute nonsense, as he well knows. If the one million unemployed people and the further one million Australians who are either underemployed or who have simply dropped out of the work force in despair at ever finding a job are asked whether this recession is long behind us and long gone, they will tell the truth. They will say that of course that is not true.

Of course, jobs are still being lost and unemployment is still as high as it ever was. Employment is continuing to fall, as are the living standards of all Australians. We now have 700,000 children who live in families where neither parent has a job. Last night I heard Julian Disney say on ABC's Lateline—honourable senators may have heard it—that to have a full time job in Australia today is to be a privileged Australian. No more stark indictment than that statement could be made of the policies of the Hawke and Keating Labor governments.

It should not be a privilege to have a full time job in Australia; it should be a right. We have the talents, resources, skills and geographic location in the world—we have everything going for us that we need to be a vibrant, growing, healthy nation where unemployment is not a scourge at all. Yet we are amongst those countries in the Western world with the highest unemployment rate, and that has been the case now for almost two years. We still have almost the highest real interest rates in the Western world. We also have the slowest and worst growth performance of virtually any country in the Western world—indeed, for much of the last couple of years we have had negative growth—let alone all those other countries that are newly developing, such as the tigers of Asia and elsewhere, where the growth rates outstrip those in our nation several times over.

We are still almost at the bottom of the list in terms of the increase in productivity of our work force and resources as a whole. While we are in that situation we continue to become increasingly uncompetitive internationally. The longer we remain uncompetitive internationally, the more intractable our problems become. Yet we have a government which knows that the path to international competitiveness can only be the path of massive and major change in this country—of great reform of our institutions and of the way that we go about doing things.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button—the third most senior Minister in the Government—said recently that the amount of micro-economic reform that has been achieved by this Government is such that there is a limit to the further capacity of the Australian people to cope with or to absorb further reform. What absolute nonsense! What a cruel joke that is on the people of Australia, particularly those two million people who, as I said before, are officially unemployed, underemployed or who have dropped out of the work force in despair.

As has been said by many commentators, the way out of our problems is not to try to pump up the economy through wild spending increases for which there is not the money to pay. That is what the Government has done in this Budget and that is what these appropriation Bills are about. Although they deal only with the expenditure side of government, equally, they can only be looked at alongside the measures to raise revenue. The bottom line is that, this year, the Government is proposing to spend $13.4 billion more than it is able to raise. That is more than it forecasts it is able to raise. Even that revenue estimate relies on a rate of growth of the economy as a whole that most commentators would say is very unlikely to be achieved.

We have had admissions to this effect from Senator Button and others in recent days. Senator Button's classic, honest admission on the Sunday program on Channel 9 last Sunday was that the prospect of achieving the growth forecasts for this year is not all that bright. No matter how he has tried to use weasel words to change what he really said last Sunday, there is no way that he can get out of that admission. And he is quite right. If he is correct in the outcome and growth for this year is less than is forecast in the Budget, revenue will be even less than is forecast and the Budget deficit of $13.4 billion will be even greater.

That deficit, which is the published deficit, is absolutely huge. Being a published deficit, it really understates the true deficit, because it is struck after taking account of certain one-off, unusual, extraordinary items. Those items, such as the proceeds of asset sales, are increasingly, day by day, unlikely to be realised. If the proceeds of assets sales, the extraordinary profits that the Reserve Bank has made on foreign exchange and other dealings and a couple of other similar one-off items are set aside, the true Budget deficit this year, on the Government's own figures, is not $13.4 billion but $20.5 billion.

That means that, to meet the hole in its Budget this year, the Government will have to borrow something in the order of $25,000m. That is an enormous amount of money that has to be found. If the Government follows its pattern of the most recent years and attempts to find that money on the domestic capital markets, it will simply crowd out all the other private sector borrowers who, hopefully, might be looking for some funds in the course of 1992-93 if and when there is any recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's when interest will take off.

—As my friend Senator Panizza points out, interest rates will have to rise. Anyone who really thinks that interest rates will stay low this financial year, given the Budget and the likely flowthrough of its impact, is, I believe, sadly misguided—unless the recession continues even deeper than it is now and for a much longer time than the Government is prepared to admit, which is a possibility.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, there is no sign of light at the end of the tunnel as far as the economy is concerned. Labour shedding continues in large degree and investment continues to fall, particularly private sector productive investment. Consumer demand is very flat, as we have seen from recent retail sales figures. In the economies of the major nations—the United States, Japan and some of the European nations—the outlook economically is very bleak. The OECD is in the process of revising downwards its forecast of economic growth in the world economy over the next 12 months.

When we look at all the factors—our increasingly low level of productivity, the Government having given up completely on micro-economic reform and the fiscal irresponsibility contained in this Budget—we would have to say that the prospects of any discernible recovery in the Australian economy over this financial year are very bleak indeed. One cannot pump prime and expect to get results. Max Walsh very correctly pointed out recently:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the harder we try to pump up the economy, the more it droops. We cannot rely on discredited Keynesian pump priming techniques to grow faster than the rest of the world.

That is a hard lesson which Treasurer Dawkins has not yet learnt. Senator Button, in his recent admissions on growth, is closer to the mark, but nobody in the Government wants to hear the truth about their failed policies. The Government cannot ignore the signals from the market forever.

PARA.TAB: I have already mentioned some of the indicators of the state of the economy. Foreign investors, for example, have marked down the dollar since the Budget. Since the 1991 Budget, just 14 months ago, the Australian dollar has been marked down by a massive 14 per cent. As I said before, long term interest rates are at the highest real level in the OECD. Recently reported survey results show that many private and academic economists are slicing their economic growth forecasts and taking Senator Button's view that growth could undercut Federal Government predictions, with all the consequences that I have already outlined for revenue, the Government's borrowing requirements and the like.

Despite every indication to the contrary, the Government is trying to make the best of its fiscal ineptitude by sweeping such unpleasant signals under the carpet. The Prime Minister is interested only in the populist route until the next election. Gone are the days when he is even prepared to say that he is going to govern responsibly and that he is prepared to try to outline policies which demonstrate a possibility and a capacity to govern and show leadership. In the past all those fond words have been swept away in the actuality of performance. There has always been the rhetoric, but the performance has never followed through. Now even the rhetoric is starting to look as tattered as it rightly should.

When we look at the real problems and the real circumstances facing Australia, the need for a whole new budgetary fiscal policy is undeniable. The Prime Minister underestimates the extent to which people can see through the bribe smokescreen contained in this Budget. One of the biggest bribes was made in grants to local governments this year, with Victoria, my own State, getting over 40 per cent of the total of those grants to local governments in 1992-93. There was only one reason why it got a proportion of that magnitude. It was a desperate attempt by the Keating Government to try to save the Kirner Government in Victoria. But the Kirner Government was totally unsavable. The election results in Victoria were as clear an indication as one could get of how people are not hoodwinked by such shonky politicking and the rest of Australia is unlikely to be impressed by being asked to fund the policy errors of the Kirner Government.

Let us look at some of the startlingly irresponsible facts of the present financial position in Australia. As I said before, if we look at the Budget outcome after adjustments for all the one-off fiddles so that comparisons can be made on a comparable basis, we see that the underlying Budget deficit this year is in excess of $20,000m. That is 5 per cent or more of our total national income. That figure, as a proportion of our national income—that deficit, that hole in the Budget—is twice as large as the deficit that was there at the start of the Labor years. It even exceeds the figure in the worst of the Whitlam years. The Senate may recall that the financial sins of the Whitlam years caused many of the problems with which Australia is still grappling today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we're in the twentieth year of the Whitlam Government.

—As Senator Panizza says, one can argue that we are in the twentieth year of the Whitlam Government. The point I want to make is that we thought the Whitlam Government was a highly profligate government. In fact, when it comes to looking at these figures, the Keating Government is the most profligate government in the history of this nation. In many respects, it makes the Whitlam Government look positively good.

PARA.TAB: As I have said before, as a result of this gross mismanagement and policy failures, we have a financing requirement which will involve the largest bond issuing program in Australia's history. That represents a massive drain on national savings because it means that the Government is putting its sticky fingers in the cookie jar of Australia's savings and drawing those savings out for its own use because of its own irresponsibilities and leaving that jar of savings so much more depleted for the private sector—the productive sector, the job creating sector—to draw from. That will put a major upward thrust on interest rates and a millstone around taxpayers' necks for years and years through the increase that that causes in the interest bill on our public debt. That millstone would continue to grow if Labor was around long enough to implement its multitude of unfunded promises which were a purely political attempt to match the fully funded, very responsibly financed promises and commitments contained in the coalition's package of policy reforms and proposals collectively known as Fightback.

The essential difference between the policy proposals of the coalition and those of the Government are that all of our proposals involve some major tax cuts. They involve a 30 per cent reduction in personal income tax and the abolition of seven major taxes on the cost of producing goods and services in this nation. Wholesale sales tax in particular will be abolished under the coalition's proposals. Payroll tax, which is no more than a tax on jobs, will be totally abolished. The tax on fuel will be totally abolished. That means that businesses will pay 25c a litre less for their fuel and private motorists will pay 19c a litre less for their fuel. When people fill up the family car on the weekend they will be paying about $11.50 less for a tankful of petrol than they are now.

When we take all of those major tax cuts into account, to be funded, very responsibly, by the most equitable form of indirect tax system that has yet been introduced around the world—that is, a goods and services tax which will replace the wholesale sales tax, which will be totally abolished because the wholesale sales tax is a very inequitable tax, an unfair tax, a very discriminatory tax and very costly to administer, particularly for small business—they contrast starkly with the proposals of the Government as outlined in the Budget and, before that, in its so-called One Nation statement of February this year.
