That is a document which has sunk without trace. It was not a statement about one nation; it was really a statement about one job. That was the Prime Minister's desperate attempt to buy the Australian public's support to keep him in his job as Prime Minister. That is a task which I believe is beyond the wit of all Australians and I am sure it will not happen.

The proposals in those documents are very costly for the Australian community now and will be very costly for future generations—particularly for our children and grandchildren who will suffer the legacy of the huge debt burden which is involved. When one compares the coalition's set of proposals—carefully funded and crafted, highly equitable, and designed to create more jobs, more growth, higher incomes and higher living standards for all Australians—with the Government's proposals, which will inevitably lead to higher and higher interest rates, higher and higher taxes, and fewer and fewer jobs, the contrast between the two could not be more stark and the policy choices facing the Australian electorate at the next election could not be more stark.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget has blown up before we could even debate it.

—As Senator Knowles said, the Budget has blown up even before we could debate it in this place. The Keating Government has a $50,000m funding hole in its finances for the next four to five years—and that is without a single cent in tax reduction for those people on the lowest incomes.

PARA.TAB: We need policy in Australia which is directed toward eliminating the structural deficit that we have in our Budget and eliminating the structural problems which prevent us using our natural talents and abilities to make this nation grow, to create more jobs and to make ourselves the vibrant and internationally competitive nation that we once were. The pool of local savings is being taken away to pay for election gimmicks when it should be used for productive investment. The Government's track record creates no confidence at all that any of its forecasts can be treated seriously. Even if those forecasts were correct, the Government would still be in almighty difficulties so far as its policies are concerned.

History will judge this Budget as a total sham—as a phoney attempt by Labor to show compassion for those whom it has consigned to the unemployment queues for ever increasing periods. There is no expenditure included in these Bills which will help to solve the difficulties with which Labor has burdened Australia. Indeed, the whole thrust and impact of these Bills will be to worsen the hardship and the cruelty which the policies of this Government have imposed on so many Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bills for this year. As Senator Short pointed out a minute ago, this Budget was blown out of the water before we started to debate it. That is certainly correct, because the Government could not even write the Budget Bills which came into the Parliament properly. Incidentally, we were supposed to debate these Bills yesterday. Why are we debating them today? It is because the Government could not even put them down properly in black and white. This is an example of sloppy drafting on the part of the Government and it shows the disarray the Government is in.

PARA.TAB: I refer to what the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) in the other place used as an excuse. Mr Rocher told the House of Representatives that there had been a complete stuff-up in what was the most important legislation introduced into Parliament in any one year—the Government could not even get the Budget Papers right. By way of explanation, the Minister said that Appropriation Bill (No. 1) was meant to authorise expenditure from Consolidated Revenue of $14,761m and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) was meant to appropriate about $6 billion. In defending the situation, Mr Brown said that the Department of Finance had advised that the amount to be appropriated in the Supply Bills Nos 3 and 4 had been `inadvertently transposed'. In other words, the figure of one was confused with the figure of the other.

Mr Brown went on to say, `I should emphasise that these amendments are of a technical nature'. The Government mistook $14 billion for $6 billion and then the Minister said that the amendments were of a `technical nature'. That is how this Government is operating these days. It is in total disarray and its Budget is in total disarray. I am interpreting your smile, Mr Acting Deputy President, as accentuating what I am saying.

When the Budget comes down in any year, the first thing I look for is how it treats rural and remote areas and what is in it for those people. Even more importantly, I look at what is not in the Budget for those people. I am afraid that this year I have not found very much of importance for them. This year, with farm viability at probably its lowest level ever, I thought that the Budget would contain some measures which would improve viability, employment and the quality of life of country people so that they could enjoy the same quality of life which is expected and demanded anywhere else in Australia.

However, we find that, especially in the eastern States, we have come through the worst financial year ever. In the eastern States, broad acre farms have had a net loss of some $44,000 in the financial year just ended. An improvement is expected in this financial year when we will hopefully get over the drought in the eastern States which has so badly affected western New South Wales and some parts of Queensland. But even allowing for that improvement, the average broad acre farm, in the eastern States at least, has a longstanding debt of $400,000. That is unbearable.

On the western side of the continent, at least, we have had a far better season. In fact, it is probably the best season we have experienced for 30 years. But of course the glow from that is diminished by other things. At present, there is nothing in this Budget for those rural and remote areas and there is very little for the mining sector, which I will come to a little later in my remarks.

Last year we had a Budget deficit of $9.9 billion, after an estimate of $4.7 billion. This year we have an estimated deficit of $13.4 billion—and this Bill will fund that. But if last year's effort and government mismanagement bears fruit—that is hardly a good term to use—again this year, the deficit will blow out to $21 billion.

However, there is very little in this Budget for primary industry. It has been the worst year on record for the eastern States. Expenditure on the primary industry part of the Budget is down by $97.8m. If one has a cursory read of the primary industry section of the Budget, one will see that spending of some $1.76 billion has been allocated to that area, but $774m of that is farmers' own research levies which have been recirculated.

The other $438m, which is the diesel fuel rebate, is considered by the Government to be a handout to primary industry. It is forgone receipts. The point is that the excise on diesel fuel is for fuel used on roads. If fuel is used on a farm, the excise is not collected. How can anyone sit there and say that this is an allocation to primary industry? It is not; so it should not be considered.

Putting that aside—that is not an allocation to primary industry—what is allocated out of the Government Budget is $551.7m which is, as I said, down $97.8m on last year. We are hopefully looking at a better future for primary industry. I think there is a better future for primary industry around the corner, especially if we get into government because we will be able to lower costs.

Some 200 million more kilos of wool have been sold out of the stockpile this year than was expected. We are starting to get the stockpile down. The price, especially of the broader wools, is starting to go up. I can see a future there. I can also see a better future for the beef industry and for horticulture, especially with the expanded output. We are presently having problems with the GATT Round, or the failure of the GATT Round, and with the activities of the European Community and the United States, leading up to the election, concerning the trade subsidies that have been put on wheat and other grain products which are depressing the price.

Fortunately, I suppose, for Australian growers—very unfortunately for Canadian and European growers of grain—there has been one of the worst finishes to the season in most of Europe, including Britain, and in Canada caused by late rains. The damage has caused a reduction in a lot of their better quality wheat, although their better quality wheat is not as good as our feed wheat. That will enable Australian wheat growers to receive a better price than was expected when the European and United States subsidies came into full effect. The election in the United States will be over before very long and things will settle down and President Bush's $US1.5 billion will have been expended, at which time I hope the wheat industry will turn around.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) announced the other day that the Australian Wheat Board is to remain as it is until 1999. I never quite knew where Mr Crean was going with the Wheat Board. I did not know whether he had an agenda to destroy the Wheat Board or the Grains Council of Australia, which is supposed to represent the wheat growers of Australia. I did not know what sort of agenda its peak body had. The Export Grains Association of Australia and the Export Grain Sellers of Australia in the private sector certainly did have an agenda. But Mr Crean, to his credit, has seen the problems being experienced with the trade subsidy around the world and has decided to leave the Wheat Board as it is until 1999.

There is confusion in the other place as to exactly how the Wheat Board is structured. This Government is continually looking to create diversions to get away from its own ineptitude in running the country. It is trying to create divisions between the Liberal and National parties.

A back bench dorothy dix question was asked by the honourable member for Page, Mr Harry Woods, to Mr Crean regarding the coalition's policy on wheat trade. Mr Crean claimed that there was a split. Nothing could be further from the truth. There is no split between the Liberal and National parties. Mr Crean accused the coalition of a sham policy on wheat, saying that wheat would receive special treatment. There is no special treatment. The deal with the coalition, supported by both parties, is exactly the same as that which the Government has decided upon.

The confusion seems to be that Mr Crean and Mr Harry Woods do not know the difference between price underwriting and guaranteed minimum price. Mr Crean said, `We on this side have rejected the underwriting approach'. He rejected the underwriting approach, yet the Government has agreed to underwrite the wheat borrowings. However, he says there is division in the Opposition because we are trying to bring in a guaranteed minimum price. We are not doing anything of the sort. Our policy is exactly that which the Government decided, except for the level of underwriting.

There is no move in the Budget to cut the cost of meat inspection or the inspection of any other agricultural products that are exported from Australia. AQIS remains a thorn in the side of rural industry on costs. The Government is not doing anything to make it more streamlined or to cut down on the employment of meat inspectors.

The mining sector, along with the agricultural sector, is the only industry in Australia helping to keep Australia afloat with export income. There is no incentive in this Budget for the mining industry. The only thing the mining industry has been getting is obstacles being put in its way. Although a couple of those obstacles have been removed—that is, at Marandoo and Yakabindie—the obstacles remain in other places.

I was in the Kimberleys for a full week the other week. The same obstacles are being placed in the way of any new mining venture that is trying to get off the ground in the Kimberleys, for the same reasons as in the Pilbara. This Government and some Labor State governments around Australia are looking at the endangered species legislation. No doubt the legislation will be supported by radical groups. In legislation such as taxation legislation, there is what is called a catch-all clause; that is, if part of the legislation does not catch someone there is a catch-all clause. I am afraid that is what will happen with this endangered species legislation. If the mining industry cannot develop some deposit of gold or iron ore, that clause will be used. We had the charade at Marandoo. That project was held up for two years. That was supposed to be in a national park. That was as appealing as a national park as is the Sahara Desert.

Last night in the adjournment debate, Senator Reynolds gave us her agenda for Aboriginal self-government in North Queensland. She told us exactly what was to happen. I do not know whether she was hoping it would work out that way. I suppose she is proposing this in order to round up a few votes to keep the one or two seats in the Senate that the Government has in Queensland. She told us everything about how self-government was going to work, but she did not tell us how it was to be funded, although I have a fair idea.

One of the positive sides of the Budget for mining is the allocation of $1m towards the feasibility of Compact Steel in Western Australia. All of a sudden, Senator Coulter has become an ardent supporter of this particular project. He had an introduction to it in Perth last week when Compact Steel got together with him and pointed out the advantage of value adding iron. All of a sudden, after this briefing, he has been converted. In fact, he asked me whether I was going to support it. I have been supporting it for five years, since they got the idea going. Obviously, he did not find the endangered species down there that he has been trying to find everywhere else.

I appreciate the $1m that the Government has allocated for Compact Steel. Not only will it provide export income from a million tonnes of steel to South East Asia, but it will also provide 300 to 500 permanent jobs a year in the long term. There is Italian involvement in it, German involvement and Chinese, and there will probably be others by the time it is finished. I commend the Government for that.

I now move to land transport. The basic budget has always been from this Government, static as it may be, about $1.4 billion. The One Nation package added another $600m which, of course, will not be repeated next year in the unlikely event that this Government is around. We are really looking at an ongoing situation of around that figure until it is improved by our Government.

The sum of $7 billion is dragged from road transport in fuel levies, as I have said before, yet road funding is stagnant while the collection from levies is always increasing. At the same time, the road system all around Australia is deteriorating, not only in New South Wales and Victoria, although New South Wales, to its credit, has at least been holding with the 3x3 program and tending to improve.It is certainly time that more attention was given to roads. On my side of the continent, unfortunately, we see that the death toll on the roads is rising. It is rising not because drivers are getting worse, but because the roads are getting worse.

I will now turn to the other side of land transport, and that is the National Rail Corporation. In the Budget last year $40m was allocated. Rail is a mode of transport that has tended to be neglected and it has to get back on the rails, if I may say so. What does the Government do? It allocated $40m and only $8.9m was spent. That was because of the late start of the National Rail Corporation because the Government and the unions could not get their act together. They reckoned they were going to get it together later and get it moving. This year there was an allocation of $162m. I am wondering how it will be spent and whether it is just put in the Budget as a figure that can be used somewhere else with the excuse, again, that the National Rail Corporation, because of union problems between union members, cannot really get going.

This year, in the One Nation package, the Government allocated an extra $454m to be spent on rail on upgrading rail from Sydney to Brisbane, the Melbourne-Adelaide standardisation, improvement of the standard gauge from Kwinana to Kalgoorlie and creating a link from Kwinana to Bunbury. But the cry that comes from Western Australia is, `Okay, this money has been allocated, but where is it?'.Rail can do with improvement. The money is needed to create jobs, but it is just not forthcoming. Very little has been done, from what I can see.

One would expect there would be incentives in this Budget for small business. After all, small business is the biggest employer of labour in Australia. I cannot see any whatsoever, unless one sees deferral of income tax for two months for anyone with a tax bill of under $400,000 as a great advantage.Also in the Budget was an increase in capital gains tax exemption from 20 per cent to 50 per cent, and a doubling of the eligibility ceiling from $1m to $2m net business interest. Those are the only slight incentives that I can see.

This Budget has certainly done nothing for small business. The only thing small business has is plenty of disincentives. Anyone in small business who employs labour knows what has to be done and that by the time you do your PAYE, by the time you do your FBT and by the time you do all those other statutory things you have to, free on behalf of the Government, there is very little time for everything else.

What has been foisted on business this year through legislation in this place are things like the contractors legislation, and the superannuation levy legislation which brought everyone under an umbrella at 3 per cent, 4 per cent and later 5 per cent of wages. There is the training levy that has to be adhered to. Incidentally, most of that training levy is spent on travelling rather than training. It may be very well for businesses in the city to send people off to be trained, but when they are sent off from the country most of the money goes on accommodation and travelling.

The contractors legislation is very interesting. It was imposed on subcontractors to drag them into the Industrial Relations Commission. This has affected the cottage construction industry. Senator Cook probably knows what the agenda was to get everyone in, like the high rise construction industry. There has been very little activity by the unions on cottage building sites. It surprised me, because I thought they would be in there the next day.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were misled by the propaganda.

—No, I was not misled by the propaganda; I was amazed that they were not. But now I realise—I was told only last week, and perhaps I should have worked it out for myself—that there is an election coming next year.
—You are still being misled by the propaganda.

—It was not the public that I got that information from; it was someone closer to Senator Cook's union movement. I suppose whoever it was, he is a member of the public too. These are the things that have been thrown around. The Government did put finance out to try to improve employment around Australia for the year. We had the local government capital grants, which I have been a supporter of, as long as they are even-handed.

PARA.TAB: In Western Australia there were allocations that seemed to me to be more to protect certain marginal seats. If one goes further, one can look at State seats. The City of Stirling I thought did pretty well; it got $7.189m. That is a marginal seat held by this Government. Mandurah got $2m—probably to try to take the State seat back off us. The Shire of Murray got $277,000—a very well run shire, if I may say so. The Government is probably trying to hold it in the State election. Bunbury got $957,000, probably to help Labor in the State election. Harvey got $456,000. I think the Government aimed to hold Brand in the next election. Augusta-Margaret River got $215,000, probably to help in the State election also. Albany got $593,000, probably to help in the next State election.

I am very happy for the shires that did get some of these allocations. Geraldton got $971,000. The State Government lost that seat trying to get it back. But Wanneroo, the most expanding local government area in Australia, received nil. My own shire of Yilgan—a progressive shire, with agriculture and gold production—received nil. Kalgoorlie, the gold producing area, received nil. One can see how the funds were distributed. I do not decry the ones who did get funds, but I thought the Government might have allocated them a bit better.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know it was allocated on the basis of levels of unemployment.

—I agree with that, but there are ways of unemployment going up. Augusta-Margaret River is a very good place to be unemployed, whereas in Kalgoorlie there is generally full employment. If one were unemployed I do not think one would set up there just because of the weather or something like that. Those considerations should have been noted by the Government.

PARA.TAB: Finally, all of a sudden this Government has discovered Asia. It is flogging the Opposition by saying that we did not do anything about improving trade with Asia or looking for trade with Asia. That cannot be further from the truth. Asia has always been there; the fact is that we are dealing with it more, it is just the flux of time. Asia's economies have improved and Australia has been in a good geographical position to take up further trade. Let not the Government think that it found Asia.

The recession is supposed to be over. I ask the Government: why is the Stock Exchange where it is? If the recession is over it should have more confidence. Why are there still 1.7 million people under-employed? Why is consumer spending at an all time low? That is the crunch. The Government should have brought down a Budget to address all these matters. Obviously, it has not, and we will be addressing them in the next Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bills, I intend to do so in four parts: firstly, to take a quick overview of the framing, strategy and philosophy behind the Budget; secondly, to look at the Budget forecasts; thirdly, to look at the Budget outcome; and lastly, to look at the subsequent statement that came down on 16 September, barely a month later, dealing with a statement on tax policy. This, of course, arose because the Government tried to fudge the fact in the Budget Papers that it was actually planning to tax the socks off the Australian people with new taxes, thinking it had hidden them in the body of the tax documentation. Of course, the Government was sprung, so there was frantic activity and we eventually saw the tax statement accompanied by something interestingly called the `Australian Taxation Office Income Tax Compliance—Enforcement Strategy'.

PARA.TAB: The `taxing Budget' is a good name because it foreshadows that taxing the Australian people, raiding Australian savings, and not planning for any sort of true recovery or sustained attack on our international debt is what this Budget was all about. It has pretty well been universally discredited. In fact, one could almost say that John Dawkins has made John Kerin look pretty good. A most important comment was contained in the Budget in a brief statement on the second to last page where Mr Dawkins said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the fiscal position nearer to the time—
is not stronger than is now projected, the Government will consider and implement a number of tax changes to maintain the revenue structure.

That was the trigger phrase that caused people to look further into the Budget documents to see just where those new taxes—hidden taxes—were to be found. Thus the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) abandoned what he called the two principles of his Budget: jobs now and more jobs in the years ahead. He has just gone back to a strategy like that used in the Whitlam years, with the big spending and big taxing budgets of old.

PARA.TAB: Without announcing the precise measures, the Budget nominated several possibilities for the new tax structure. These were the introduction of a new interest withholding tax, an expansion of the prescribed payments system in industries dominated by contractors, and measures to make the fringe benefits tax neutral with income tax. What the Budget did not mention at that stage—but which we saw in the later document I just referred to—is the fact that somehow we were magically going to have better compliance. I will deal with that later. We were told that those several taxes that I just mentioned could yield between $2 billion and $3 billion, but that we would have to wait for the detail.

As to the forecast itself, something dramatic happened between February when we got the One Nation statement and the amazing claim that this year we were going to have growth in the order of 4.75 per cent, and August when in the Budget growth was recast at about 3 per cent. Then we had the truth outbreak from John Button on the Sunday program last week when he told us we were not going to make that either.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has denied that.

—He was pressured into putting out a statement subsequently, having reaffirmed his position on Channel Ten, but we have traversed this in this chamber before. He has not had a good week. He should have stayed in bed all week.
—But he did deny it and he didn't say he was pressured.

—To the contrary. If Senator Cook reads the Hansard, he will see that Senator Button was pressured well and truly. The fact of the matter is that John Button has become famous for his outbreak of truth and parting from the Government line when he knows it to be false. Even leaving the growth figure at 3 per cent, if we translated that into an employment forecast, it meant that the Government had admitted that it had hopes only to achieve, at best, a marginal improvement in the unemployment figure, to bring it down from 11.2 per cent to 10.5 per cent at the end of the current financial year.

PARA.TAB: Yet, this is the same economy about which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said the other day, `The recession is at an end and has been for some time'. The 10.5 per cent of the Australian work force who are out of a job simply do not believe that statement. It exacerbates the cynicism with which they regard this Prime Minister. It also throws light on the predictions by the Government that a growth rate of at least 3 per cent is needed to stabilise the level of youth unemployment, let alone bring about a systematic reduction across the board in the unemployment market. In his speech to the National Press Club in February, Mr Keating perhaps gave his own eulogy. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If we can't do four per cent, we ought to pack it in, the lot of us. What sort of country do we want to live in? You need about three per cent a year just to take the school leavers up.

What a statement: `If we can't do 4 per cent we ought to pack it in'. I would invite the Government to do so. Give a go to people who have a plan to see the economy turn around, to see individual Australians prosper again and to see our international debt stabilised. Give us a go. One of the reasons that Mr Keating has been trying to talk up the growth forecasts after the Budget—and why Senator Button obviously had pangs of guilt and came out with the truth—is that he has to some how substantiate that statement he made back in February.

PARA.TAB: One could say that the growth predictions that this Government has come out with since One Nation, the Budget and subsequent statements by Ministers, is probably the shortest life of any financial forecasting we have ever seen. It is truly amazing to see that between February and August the Government, of its own volition, read down its forecasts from 4.75 per cent to 3 per cent. I repeat the Prime Minister's comments: `What sort of a country do we want to live in? If we can't do 4 per cent we ought to pack it in'.

Let us go on to look at the outcome. Mr Dawkins's Budget made no genuine attempt to face up to Australia's real economic problems such as unemployment, an inefficient tax system, low levels of national savings and poor productivity. Instead, this Budget has been a crude exercise in Keynesian pump-priming in the hope that an expansion in government expenditure will hide a few unemployment statistics.

According to the Budget Papers, the Government has anticipated a Budget deficit of $13.4 billion. For weeks the Government was trying to prepare the market for such a figure, but even this number fails to accurately represent the true Budget deficit. Presumably the $1.6 billion in proceeds from asset sales included the sale of shares in AIDC Ltd. Again, within two weeks of being announced in the Budget, Senator Button denied that the sale would take place simply because AIDC Ltd made a $99m loss. In addition to that, there is $1.1 billion in abnormal profits of the Reserve Bank. So, the published $13.4 billion deficit inflates, probably, to an underlying deficit of around $16.1 billion.

The Government has abandoned its previous commitments to return the Budget to surplus by the end of the decade. Even with indications of increased taxation, the Budget will remain in deficit by 1995-96 and total deficits for 1991-92 to 1995-96 will be over $50 billion, compared to the One Nation estimate of $18 billion for deficits over that period.

Either the Government in February in the One Nation statement lied to us, and deliberately did so, or it was so incompetent that Mr Keating ought to heed his words that he gave at the Press Club, `We ought to pack it in'. Quite clearly, the choice is that the Government is either lying or incompetent. Either option is not very attractive and does not give any comfort to the one million unemployed.

The turnaround in the Budget deficit in the last two years is bigger than the disastrous Budgets of the Whitlam years and double that during the last recession in 1982-83. This turnaround could prove to be even larger if the Government's estimates of assets sales prove to be unrealistic, and I have already cited one example.

But the Government has consistently failed to meet its privatisation targets. Since 1988-89, the Government has made shortfalls on its privatisation targets ranging from $132m to $927m in the last financial year. And not only that, it has managed to screw up the legal rights of Australian citizens along the way, and we remember the pipeline case. This year, the Treasury anticipates $1.6 billion in proceeds from the sale of assets but that includes the sale of Qantas and Australian Airlines. And we have yet to see any evidence of those targets being met.

The Government has spent an additional $9 billion this year. This represents a 6 per cent increase in expenditure and signals a massive unfunded spending binge which will have a negligible impact on the one million unemployed. So we are having pain and no gain.

The Budget is designed to engineer an artificial reduction in unemployment in time for an election. Its aim is not to find jobs for the unemployed but to hide them from the official statistics. It will spend $3.5 billion to create 27,000 jobs and it will hide 43,000 unemployed in training places. Training for what? What is the expectation that this Government offers? One could say it will mean that Australia will have the best trained dole queues in the world. The Government has forecast that the unemployment figure will fall to 10.5 per cent by July 1993 but at a cost of over $3 billion in additional spending, and we have no guarantee that that figure will be met in any event.

If returned, Labor would have to impose a massive increase in government taxes and charges to pay for this year's and last year's unfunded spending, not to mention what is in the pipeline. Instead of a sound fiscal blueprint, the Budget is founded upon debt. The gross Commonwealth public debt interest increased by 26 per cent in 1992-93 and 33 per cent in the following year. The interest on public debt will rise by $1 billion this financial year and about $1.5 billion in the following year.

Public debt interest will be the largest contributor to the real growth in Budget outlays between now and 1995-96. What a foundation—debt! This will inevitably lead to a raid on private savings, meagre as they are, and it will not be too long before interest rates will be on the rise so as to further depress investment activity and frustrate any chance of sustainable recovery.

The announced tax increases are only a fraction of what will be required to fund the spending spree and will have little or no effect until 1993-94. The increase in the Medicare levy will yield $300m. Car parking benefits provided to employees will become taxable as fringe benefits from 1 April 1993 and will yield a whole $120m.

The immediate increase in excise on tobacco products of $5 a kilogram translates into a rise of 15c to 20c on a packet of cigarettes and provides a whole $80m for the Government in this financial year. New measures for the collection of tax on royalty payments to non-residents will raise $50m in 1993-94; while $115m in the same year will be gained from limiting research and development tax concessions to tax exempt syndicates. These figures are puny. They are puny when contrasted with the Government's spending binge and have caused the need for the announcement of future taxes.

I certainly question the timing of the rise of excise on tobacco products. Within days of that announcement retrenchments by Rothmans in Sydney were announced. The Government does not seem to care about the impact its policies will have on job losses in industry. We saw another example of this in the imposition of the compulsory superannuation levy where we saw jobs disappear immediately. And, of course, subsequently it has had to revise some of the impositions it made with regard to contractors and its tax rulings in that area, realising that all the things that we said in the debate about how unworkable it was and how unfair it was were quite true.

I want to turn to the statement on tax policy which flowed from that Budget and flowed from the exposure by the Opposition that the Government was planning an implementation of new taxes. So I turn to this statement on tax policy and some of the really fascinating things that it says. Accompanying that statement was the Australian Taxation Office income tax compliance enforcement strategy. There was also a so-called confidential minute that accompanied those documents signed by the Commissioner of Taxation. I think what it says is worth putting on the record. It is dated 15 September 1992 and it is to the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). It says:
You have asked for my advice about the extent to which there might be an enhancement or improvement in measures to achieve better compliance with the income tax laws.

As you know, the income tax system is founded on voluntary compliance principles and is administered on a self assessment basis. Supporting mechanisms are found in systematic approaches (principally the PAYE and TFN systems), and a variety of help and enforcement techniques.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well to point out that over 50 per cent of all taxation revenue collected by the Taxation Office is in fact personal income tax. The minute continues:

PARA.TAB: Earlier this year, when addressing the question of a domestic withholding tax on interest I made the general point that it is a tenet of income tax administration that the most efficient and effective means of gathering tax is to have it deducted at source. I indicated that in moving from the general to the particular a range of matters would need to be worked through. Solutions to them involve varying degrees of difficulty, of administration and otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note on the question of withholding tax that, in giving evidence to a hearing of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts in Brisbane in the last several weeks, there was an admission by the Taxation Office that a concession given for the payment of withholding tax in respect of people who are bringing in capital for development purposes was simply unenforceable by the Taxation Office and so it did not bother about it.

PARA.TAB: The Tax Office does bother, however, to persecute—and I mean persecute—ordinary small insignificant Australians who have no power to fight back. The Commissioner went on to say:

I now do not recommend any extension of deduction-at-source systems, either by way of a domestic interest withholding tax or extension of the prescribed payments system. Alternative information reporting procedures, such as the highly successful TFN arrangements, can be very valuable in securing compliance and can obviate the need for further deduction-at-source arrangements. I therefore am recommending some extension of TFN reporting processes.

My report on the situation and my recommendations for action, including also our estimates of the resulting gains in revenue, additional to what has been factored into current estimates of revenue receipts, is attached.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the interesting figures that Mr Boucher advised upon, and which the Government has acted upon, is the provision of a so-called $114m to $115m for more staff to bring about greater compliance. The only problem with that statement is that the Taxation Commissioner entered into an agreement with the Public Sector Union—an agreement which precludes anyone being sacked, with nobody becoming redundant. This is despite the fact that the Tax Office entered into an agreement with the Department of Finance that it would in fact require 3,000 fewer people to collect the revenue once the modernisation system went in. Despite that agreement with the Finance Department, the Commissioner entered into an agreement with the Public Sector Union which says, `Nobody can be made redundant'.

PARA.TAB: So, to start with, we have the spectacle of the 1,000 people who are now no longer needed to collect the revenue being transferred to do PR work for the Tax Office. The Tax Office needs that $115m not to employ extra people to do extra audits to get in that little extra bit of tax but to pay the salaries of the people who, under the agreement with the Department of Finance, were to be declared redundant. But under the Public Sector Union agreement, they cannot be made redundant. So the taxpayer is being fooled. The taxpayer is being told that an extra $115m is going to be made available to enable the Tax Office to put on more staff to collect more revenue when, in fact, it is a fudge to pay for the union agreement.

I referred that agreement to the Department of Finance to have it costed. Among other things, this agreement—a marvellous looking, very glossy document that is registered under section 115—provides that a trade union advisory unit will be established; that the unit has to have researchers that are funded by the Tax Office; that it has to be provided with a budget for travel and consultants; and that it has to be independent. It also provides that the Taxation Commissioner may not question people on how they spend their time. If they spend all day every day doing union business, they are not allowed to be disciplined or, indeed, queried. Every branch of the Tax Office has to have an office set aside for the union with a locked filing cabinet and a telephone with no bar on it, including ISD for overseas phone calls.

I have had a preliminary costing back from the Department of Finance which, quite frankly, I find unacceptable. No figure has been put against clause after clause after clause because the Department says it cannot ascertain how much this will cost the taxpayer. But the preliminary finding is that the Commissioner of Taxation has handed over to the Public Sector Union $2 1/2m of taxpayers' money—and that is for starters.

This is the same Tax Commissioner who wrote to the lady I talked about earlier in the day whose husband had died. He could not tell her or her solicitors what money was owing for the purposes of putting in a return. But the Tax Office was going to sue her for $290. She said, `All I have got in the bank is $2,000 and I cannot even pay for my own funeral'. The same man who writes to ordinary Australians like that has given to the Public Sector Union at least a minimum of $2 1/2m of taxpayers' money. One could say that he wants to get blood out of a stone.

We have to understand that the Labor Party is merely the political wing of the trade union movement and that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is a good trade union supporter. The Minister who was responsible for getting this document registered still wears the hat of a member of the BWIU and is a former trade union executive member. I can understand why those opposite think it is fine that the trade union movement should be given taxpayers' money and that ordinary Australians should be penalised.

This just highlights, does it not, the ends to which this Government has politicised the Public Service. We have the Commissioner recommending and saying that this money will be made available for additional staff to recoup $1.7 billion worth of additional revenue—and, quite frankly, if they can identify it now, why are they not collecting it now—when in fact this is money that is needed to pay the salaries of people who should have been made redundant but will not be because of this Public Sector Union agreement. How can we believe any of the statistics that come from this Government?

As I said right at the beginning of my speech, this Budget has been `discredited'—and that is a kind word. This Budget has been declared probably inoperative. It had a very short future to begin with. Any analysis of the polling that has been done on the effect that this Budget has had will show, quite frankly, that it has not assisted anybody. It is a fudge.

On the other hand, when we look at the Fightback document we see that here is a plan to bring hope back into the Australian community. When I argue about the reforms that this country needs, I argue from a basis of a belief in free enterprise—free enterprise which guarantees individuals freedom and prosperity. Three of the imperatives that we need to ensure that are, firstly, a stimulus to encourage indigenous savings so that we can pay for our own development; secondly, incentive to become more productive; and, thirdly, reward for effort. Those are the sorts of things that the Fightback package will allow to occur.

But, for me, the fundamental reason I came to this place was to ensure that future generations will enjoy the freedom and the prosperity that I was able to enjoy as I grew up in the Menzies years. I want to ensure that the next generation does not have to grow up under the austerity, the duplicity and this con trick Budget, which is typical of the policies that this Government has brought down.

What is the bottom line of the 10 years of government that those opposite have had? It is one million unemployed, the worst recession in 60 years, and a lot of Australians who no longer have hope. That is the legacy of this Budget and that is indicative of the policies that have been consistently introduced by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for this opportunity during the Appropriation Bills debate to establish the facts about this present Government's funding of sport and the Opposition's approach to sport—and I speak as the shadow Minister for sport and the next Minister for sport after the Hewson Government is elected. The Government has run a campaign of deception and dishonesty, which is just quite unacceptable, to convert into an increase what is in fact a cut in sports funding. The Government is trying to pretend that its cut in sports funding over the next three years is somehow magically an increase.

PARA.TAB: I have been listening to speeches made in the debate on this legislation in the other place and have heard the most incredible nonsense from people such as Mr Johns, the temporary member for Petrie, and Mr Steve Martin, the member for Macarthur, who has abandoned his electorate in order to stand for the much safer Labor seat of Cunningham. I suppose that is very wise of him, in view of the fact that the seat of Macarthur will hopefully and properly be won by the coalition at the next election.

These people have been making the incredible allegation that there is a large increase in Federal funding under this Government for sport over the next three years, when the simple reality is that there is a considerable fall. While doing so, they were also creating absolutely false fears about the impact of a GST on sport.
Both those matters really have to be addressed. It is vital that the people of Australia understand the extent to which this Govern-

SPEECH.PARA: ment will go to deceive them about such a clear cut matter as sport. As a result, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table from the recent publication Maintaining the Momentum of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) which deals with the Australian Government sports policy in the years to 1996.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

TAB.EMPHASIS: [TABLE OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 1829]
TAB.TAB: Senator MICHAEL BAUME—This document reveals that in this financial year, 1992-93, there will in fact be $82.9m spent in the current budget on sport. Next year that will fall to $74.7m. The year after that it will fall to $71.5m and the year after that it will fall to $63.8m under the Government's official program. That is what the Government is intending to do. It does not take a great deal of skill to work out that $63.8m is a lot less than $82.9m, about $19m less. In fact, over the next three years this totals a very considerable cut, something like $40m in sports funding.

PARA.TAB: If that is the right and proper thing do, I have no objection to the Government's doing it. My objection is to the Government's dressing it up as a 35 per cent increase by some fiddling or creative accounting. Of course, the Government has done this by saying that current year's $82.9m should be included with all the future years, so the result would be a very exciting looking figure.

I will tell honourable senators about the current year's increase, that is, from the previous year's $67.8m to this year's $82.9m. Let us see how phoney this present figure is. This so-called increase of $13.3m in the current financial year will not go to any sporting organisations, or indeed to the Australian Sports Commission. In fact, the funding of the Australian Sports Commission—and this is the body that funds Australian sport—will go up by $300,000. It will go up from $59.3m to $59.6m which, after one accounts for inflation, represents a fall in real terms. A $300,000 rise from $59.3m is a fall in real terms.

That fall in real terms is hidden in this substantial increase in the Department's own expenditures, which jumped from $6m to $14m. The real reason for this big increase in the Department's expenditure is very simple. As I said, none of this money will go to the Australian Sports Commission or to Australian sporting organisations, whose funding will have to be cut. In fact, it will spread over additional programs announced by the Minister, because $7.8m of this one-off increase this year is only a carry-over of unspent funds from last year's political stunt, which was called the facilities program. That program does not relate entirely to sport. Quite an amount of that program relates to facilities of a totally different nature. This facilities program is awarded mainly to Labor marginal seats, without reference to the Sports Commission or national sporting organisations. In fact, this is allocated out of the Minister's office on the basis of the nature of the electorate to which it relates.

I have seen—and I must admit it was by accident, because it was sent to me accidentally by fax—what these allocations look like. At the top of the page is clearly stated what the electorate is, who the member is and what the nature of the electorate is—that is, safe Labor, marginal Labor or so on.

This political stunt is the element in this year's sporting allocations which shows this once-off jump. We know why—because this is an election year and the Government is looking after its marginal seat holders. I was intrigued to see that Mr Johns, when defending the Government's sports policies in the other House, was proud to say that he got lots of money in his marginal seat and he was very grateful for it. Of course he got lots of money! He is in a marginal Labor seat and this political stunt is diverting money that should be going to national sporting organisations.

On top of that, there is a once-off $5m for the Sydney Olympic bid, and certainly New South Wales senators are glad to see that the Federal Government is providing support for that bid. We hope it is successful. Another $300,000 is to pay the legal costs of the Australian Sports Drug Agency, particularly in the Martin Vinnicombe affair. Mr Acting Deputy President, you are well aware of the extraordinary way the Australian taxpayer has had to suffer in financial terms—and Australian sport has had to suffer in financial terms—because Mr Vinnicombe, who was caught cheating by taking performance enhancing drugs and who admitted to taking these drugs, has been able to maintain a continual legal pressure because of some legal technicalities relating to the nature of the drug testing by the Canadian authorities.

That is where this big so-called increase has occurred in sports funding—none of it going to Australian sporting organisations. This is simply the base point from which we find this dishonest attack on the coalition. We see these claims, for example, that we will massively cut funding. I notice that Mr Johns, from the depths of his ignorance about sport, says how ridiculous it is for us to be talking about reducing some of the bureaucracy at the Australian Sports Commission and cutting out some of its remarkable increase in capital spending. He says how ridiculous it is that we are talking about limiting this capital spending by $3m when in fact the capital expenditure in 1992-93 is estimated to be just $1.2m.

I have news for him. In fact, the Senate Estimates hearing held last week revealed that in 1992-93 the total for capital works and services for the Australian Sports Commission for the current financial year is $2.3m. What the coalition will cut it from—and we said this clearly in the Fightback! document—was the 1991-92 base which was $4.2m. Obviously the Government agrees with us, because it has cut almost $2m off this capital expansion which has been very rapid indeed in recent times.

Basically, there is no difference between the thrust of the coalition and the Government in saying, `Look this capital expansion at the Australian Institute of Sport has to slow down'. We are saying it should slow down a bit faster than the Government says it should slow down, but both of us are saying it. For Mr Johns to pretend that that is not happening is simply ludicrous and part of a Labor Party campaign of clear deception about the sports policy of the coalition.

It is unfortunate that sport is now being dragged into the Keating Government's political campaign against the coalition's Fightback plan to rescue Australia from the recession Mr Keating said we had to have. The Keating Government's strategy is to mount a campaign of fear and falsehood against Fightback, even issuing dishonest ministerial documents, paid for by taxpayers, that contain totally untrue allegations about what the coalition's policy is and what its effect on sport and sports funding would be. This then gets repeated by such people as Mr Martin and Mr Johns in the other place.
It is incredible. We hear Mr Johns, for example, making this sort of totally false statement. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: All sorts of sporting equipment . . . are things that are not currently taxed and they will suffer the imposition of a 15 per cent goods and services tax.

I have news for him. This Government imposes a 20 per cent sales tax on sporting equipment, and that is to be wiped out under the Fightback policy. But Mr Johns does not have the decency to mention that. In fact, he says exactly the opposite in what can only be either gross ignorance or gross deception. There is no excuse for him not knowing what is in it because he refers to it repeatedly. He can make his choice about which it is, but the facts on funding under a coalition government are that, contrary to Government propaganda,there will be no cuts whatsoever in the total of Federal funding through the Australian Sports Commission to Australian sporting organisations. As Fightback clearly states, funding will be maintained in real terms. This, of course, is in contrast to the Keating Government's cut in real terms to the Sports Commission's program funds in the latest Budget. As I said, the minute increase of $300,000 in its total funding in fact means a reduction in real terms. The Government is actually cutting the Sports Commission's real funding while we of course will not do so.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge that the coalition does plan cuts to the blatantly political $10m a year community recreation sporting facilities program, which is administered by the Minister herself, on the basis of the political status of the electorate involved without reference to or advice from the Sports Commission or national sporting bodies. And, as I said earlier, much of the resources under that program are now going to things other than sporting facilities. It is true that we will also be cutting further ASC capital works. Such works will not be undertaken after the completion of the present capital works program until the economy improves sufficiently to afford it. I then added an important element which the Government never acknowledges: `or unless private fundraising provides for it'.

This Government has been monumentally incompetent in getting private sector support for the Australian Sports Commission apart from a few ads. One can see exactly what the revenue situation is. The forecast for this year is about $4.9m overall; last year $4.4m was raised. One would have thought that after such a successful Olympics there would have been many organisations wishing to be associated with the Australian Institute of Sport to provide considerable increases in the private sector funding. Under a coalition government, we would be seeking to encourage exactly that so that there could be capital expenditure which would proceed without diminishing the funds available to other elements of the sporting program.

We are talking also about reducing by $4m what was then classified as the $27m running costs of the Australian Sports Commission Institute of Sport either by improved cost recoveries or reducing the booming $10m salaries bill. The number of employees has soared by 40 per cent, from 167 to 234, in the last three years. As I mentioned earlier, $4m in revenue was a good achievement, but it is not nearly what should be able to be earned through cost recoveries.

Contrary to the Government's dishonest claim that very few sporting organisations will benefit from the taxes to be removed by the Opposition in the Fightback package, wiping out these seven taxes will considerably reduce the cost of running sporting organisations. Under Fightback, for example, the present 20 per cent sales tax on sporting goods will be wiped out.

Sales tax costs sports people $240m a year. This Government taxes sport by $240m a year, but one would never know that from looking at any Government documents; one would never know that from listening to any Government speeches—because it is deceptively swept under the carpet. I do not expect it to be admitted here by any member of the Government today. Why should they today? They have never done it before. In other words, this Government collects $240m out of sport and gives back about one-third, a proportion which will be diminishing over the next three years under the Government's forward sports program.

As I said, under the coalition's plan, sales tax will be totally removed and any 15 per cent GST that replaces this 20 per cent sales tax will be fully refunded to any sporting club or deducted from whatever GST the clubs themselves may collect. So it will in fact be cheaper to run sporting clubs, but, in some instances, it may be dearer to belong to them. Let us get this exactly, honestly right. Sporting clubs, for example, buying advertising space will have whatever GST they pay fully refunded to them. If they sell advertising, media or catering rights or accept sponsorships there will be no net cost difference at all as the GST they charge will be totally refunded to the buyer or the sponsor. So sponsorships will not be adversely affected by the GST, but that is not what the Government tells people. The Government has simply been spreading falsehoods to try to terrorise sports people about the alleged disastrous impact of the Fightback package on sport when the facts are that the Fightback package reduces the costs of running sporting organisations.

In addition, the cut of 26c a litre in fuel prices to sporting clubs and transport companies, along with the 19c a litre price cut to private motorists, will mean a major reduction in costs of attending competition for clubs, members and spectators. Any GST on accommodation or transport that is paid for by a sporting club will be totally refundable to that club, and the Government knows it. Government members knew that when they got up and said exactly the opposite in the other place. It is just a disgrace that there can be such deliberate distortion of what the facts really are.

This 20 per cent sales tax that the Government imposes on sporting equipment is not only on clear sporting equipment such as hockey sticks and so on but also on paper, printing and so on involved in sporting programs. Soaps that sports people use after their games, detergents, antiseptics, Dencorub, sponges, buckets, toilet paper, writing and wrapping paper, mowers and tractors are all subject to 20 per cent sales tax under this Government. All of that sales tax will be removed and any GST that is imposed will be refundable to the sporting club.

I guess most sporting clubs do not realise that, at the moment, this Government collects a sales tax of 10 per cent on soft drink, fruit juices, ice cream and snack foods at their canteens. By the way, there is also a sales tax on sports trophies. But this Government does not admit that. It is going around saying that a new tax that has never existed before will hit all these items. That is simply and deliberately false, deceptive and dishonest.

There is no doubt that all sporting clubs which have to meet any of these costs will have their GST refunded and any sales tax that exists now will be totally wiped out. They will be cheaper to run because these sales taxes will be removed. The costs of many things that do not appear to have a sales tax directly on them will be reduced because of the removal of those seven taxes. Even items that do not have a sales tax on them at the moment, such as sports uniforms, involve the payment of all those seven taxes, including payroll tax, in their production and transportation. For example, transport costs include a fuel excise at 26c a litre, a 20 per cent tax on spare parts and tyres and a tax on trucks, et cetera. All of that massive infrastructure of taxes is to be wiped out under the Fightback program.

It is a shame that so many Australians do not realise the hidden level of tax this Government has imposed on them—and has inherited, I must say, as well—particularly in areas like sport and food, which have a massive impact on the cost of living. Those who say, `It is a bit of a worry that the Opposition has a GST as part of the Fightback campaign' appear to have forgotten that the Fightback campaign wipes out all of these massive taxes—for example, these 20 per cent taxes on sporting equipment and the 10 per cent taxes on soft drinks, fruit juices and so on at sporting canteens.

Overall, there will be some increases in the costs of participating in or watching sport. As I said, while it will be cheaper to run sporting organisations, memberships will carry a GST and being a spectator will involve paying a GST. However, if there are any net increases in that cost—remembering all the things that have offset the cost; the removal of all those other taxes—any such increased cost will be massively compensated by the 30 per cent cut in Australians' income taxes and the 8 per cent rise in pensions.

The whole reason for introducing the GST is to get rid of those taxes and to reduce income tax so that people can make their own decisions about how to spend their money. So it is clear that sport will prosper under a Hewson government, particularly as the generation of two million extra jobs under the Hewson Fightback program will provide significantly increased opportunities for those Australians who are presently too hobbled by unemployment and the recession to participate in the sport of their choice.

Many people are saying, `This is terrible because it will be hard to handle it. How will sporting clubs' treasurers handle it?'. The fact is that it will take no greater administrative burden than already exists. A treasurer already has to keep records of how much money is spent and how much money is brought in. All that would happen is that, instead of once a year having to add up the total, he or she will have to do it every six months and will then be able to deduct whatever GST the club has paid from whatever GST it has received and send in the difference to the Australian Taxation Office. These sporting clubs or organisations will be able to keep in their hands for six months whatever tax they have collected to either reduce their overdraft or put on deposit to earn income for the benefit of the club.

Sporting organisations with an annual turnover of less than $50,000—and most will probably be in this category—need not even register under the GST, collect GST or put GST on anything they do. Many such clubs may choose to be in the GST system in order to obtain the benefits of refunds on their purchases, such as on sports equipment and so on. Only clubs that have a turnover of between $50,000 and $250,000 will have to register with the Tax Office. They will then have to put in returns only once every six months. Clubs with higher turnovers, of up to $2m, need make returns only every three months. Any really big clubs, such as major football clubs, will put in monthly returns. They will also get the benefit of having the use of the surplus funds they get in GST before they have to pay it.

GST will have to be collected by a club on gate money and other receipts, including playing fees, membership and affiliation fees and merchandising, but not on donations or government grants. Many clubs survive very heavily on donations, government grants or sponsorships from the private sector. As I said, sponsorships will not be adversely affected whatsoever by the GST arrangements.

There seems to me to have been a deliberate and disgraceful campaign again the GST to try to terrorise sports people. I draw attention to those sports people who travel large distances to participate in their sport. Obviously the abolition of fuel excise, which adds 26c a litre to petrol prices, will be of major benefit to people who drive many kilometres, particularly those in the bush, to get in a game of cricket, football, netball or whatever sport it is that they play. Fuel for the average car will be about $11 a tankful cheaper.

Bus and charter companies will also be able to charge less because of their lower fuel costs and lower operating costs caused by the abolition of the other taxes, such as the removal of the sales tax on vehicles which seat less than 12 passengers, the removal of the tax of 20 per cent on parts and the end of payroll tax. Any GST that a sporting company has to pay a bus company will be totally refunded to that club.

I will now deal with the question of how much extra work sporting organisations would have to face. Research in New Zealand, which introduced a GST not so long ago, has indicated that there is little extra work for club treasurers as the return is a simple, one-page form. I mention by way of comparison that businesses in New Zealand with an annual turnover of around $2m have indicated in surveys that their returns each two months involve a maximum of 10 to 15 minutes extra work. That means that, for most clubs, all that will be needed is for the treasurer to maintain exactly the same sorts of records of revenue and expenditure as now but to add up the total once every six months rather than once every 12 months in order to establish the GST paid.

This campaign of dishonesty deserves to fail. It is an absolute nonsense. I restate that the coalition intends to maintain real funding to Australian sporting organisations through the Australian Sports Commission. We are committed to that under Fightback. By the way, we will make certain that there is much fairer allocation under that program than presently exists, whereby special elite sports funding is limited only to Olympic sports. That is unfair on many sports such as netball, for example, which are national sports. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to follow Senator Michael Baume. All I can conclude is that I hope none of those sports people gets sick, because I want to talk about Fightback and its effect on Medicare and health. I have to pick up on a few of Senator Baume's points, because his contribution certainly fudged the truth. He used a litany of words to suggest that what the Government is saying about the proposals from the Opposition on sport is less than truthful. But that argument is for another place and another time. Of course, I do not accept it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume suggested that if people were paying a 10 per cent sales tax now that would come off. Indeed it might. But if he replaced a 10 per cent tax with a 15 per cent tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —Try 20 per cent on sporting equipment.

—I will come to that. Senator Baume should just bide his time. If he replaces a 10 per cent tax with a 15 per cent tax ordinary humans would know that that is likely to put the cost up. Indeed it will. If he replaces a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax with a 15 per cent GST all honourable and reasonable assessments say that that is about a zero sum game. Senator Baume left those bits out and I think they should really be put in.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume forgot to tell us how much people will be paying for their clothing. I do not think sportspeople go to sporting events nude. They will have to dress. All the sporting gear that they put on will be wearing the GST—the Opposition's 15 per cent tax on clothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —And no import duties of 60 per cent.

—What is more, if they want to be fit enough to run, jump, throw a ball, kick, chase, run around and do whatever those sporting people do, they will have to pay 15 per cent on all the food they eat to keep fit.
—Are you going to be honest or not?
—I am telling the absolute truth, and Senator Baume did not.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I sat here, and so did others, listening to Senator Baume for about half an hour without interjection. I think he should give Senator Crowley the same courtesy.
—I am just asking her to tell the truth.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! I will uphold the point of order. Senator Baume, would you desist from interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point that I was making is that the truth and the whole truth may be two different things. Less than the whole truth was told in Senator Baume's contribution.

PARA.TAB: The most important thing that needs to be said about the GST relates to all those people for whom Senator Baume seemed to have a concern. Those people who are at the lower end of the income scale will spend a very large percentage of their income, if not all of it, on food, clothing and the sorts of services that he mentioned.

If people currently enjoy going to a game of football because that is their weekly entertainment, the Opposition will whack a 15 per cent goods and services tax on that. If they are at the lower end of the income scale that will make a difference to their very tight budget. The Opposition fails to say—this must be recognised by the community—that the Fightback package is massively and wickedly regressive. This means that people on low incomes who spend most of their money on the necessities of life—food and clothing and possibly some modest entertainment—will suffer a 15 per cent increase.

However, people at the top end of the scale, who have a large amount of what is called disposable income—income that they do not have to spend on food and clothing—will enjoy increased amounts of that money because they will have their tax rates reduced and all the benefits of a goods and services tax, that is, income tax reductions, more disposable income and other savings to offset the increase of 15 per cent on food and clothing. But people at the other end of the scale on low and modest incomes, particularly people with fixed incomes, will spend most of their money on services and food and clothing and they will be considerably hurt by the GST.

As I said, the most important thing that I can say after listening to Senator Baume's contribution is that I hope none of the people who play sport get an injury. That would require a massive change because at the moment one of the big concerns I have relates to the number of people who are injured in sport and then have to use our health care services for treatment for those injuries. During a meeting I was at not too long ago evidence was put that the sporting injuries which are often defined as acute or emergency get to queue jump on people waiting for elective surgery, very often properly so because they are emergencies, but they are one of the reasons that contribute to the waiting lists that we have and which seem to be so often misrepresented by the Opposition. I want to come to them in a moment. Under the Opposition, if people get sick they can expect that what is a manageable system now will be replaced by an appalling one.

First, under the GST the Opposition intends to make everybody pay more to go and see the doctor. At the moment the majority of services—something like 70 per cent—are bulkbilled, which means that when a person goes to see the doctor there is no extra outlay. When people see a doctor they do not have the worry about whether or not they can afford that visit to the doctor; the same applies to their families, their children and elderly relatives. The doctor is bulkbilling. Something between 70 to 76 per cent of services are bulkbilled. There is no extra cost when a person goes to see the doctor. Under the Opposition that outlay will be $31, an increase to the AMA's schedule of fees from 20 per cent to 30 per cent on cost. Bulkbilling will be restricted only to pensioners and card holders provided the doctor bulkbills.

The whole pressure that exists in the system at the moment to encourage doctors to bulkbill—we see that they have been encouraged and are bulkbilling in such a large part—will be removed and the visit to the doctor will be increased from 20 per cent to 30 per cent to the AMA's schedule of fees, up from just over $23 to $31. People will have to find that $31 per visit per person when they go to the doctor. That will be the first horrible shock if the Opposition should ever get in and implement its health system.

Secondly, people will be encouraged to take out private insurance. Encouraged is a nice way of saying it; forced is a better way of saying it. If a family is on an income of $50,000 the Opposition will require that if they do not have private health insurance, they will pay the assessed value of the cost of that private health insurance of $800 a year on top of their Medicare levy, and that is for a family with an income of $50,000.

It is hard for me to discover in reading the Fightback package whether, if people's incomes are above $50,000, they will pay even more than that. I understand that they will not. I understand that the cost of $800 for private health insurance, as estimated by the Opposition, will not rise for families with incomes above $50,000. So people on $50,000 will have to pay $800 extra, as will people with an income of $100,000. That is a regressive step. Eight hundred dollars will be paid out of $50,000 and the same $800 extra will be paid if one is on $100,000, $150,000 or $200,000. That is a point that the Opposition is not rushing around telling people, but they are the facts.

Because the Opposition's Fightback package is called `Medicare is hopeless, Medicare does not work, Medicare shows that we are in crisis, our health system is failing all around the country', I ask the Opposition: why is it maintaining Medicare? If Medicare is so bad, why is the Opposition maintaining it? It is maintaining Medicare for three principal reasons. The first reason is that it wants the money. In its health package it is absolutely desperate that it keeps that money as it intends to remove something like $2 billion out of public expenditure on health. It would certainly like to make sure that it got the dollars that come to it from the Medicare levy. I would also like to know whether the Opposition will implement the Medicare levy at 1.25 per cent or whether it will move it up to 1.4 per cent. That is a matter about which it remains silent. It is certainly keeping Medicare because it wants the money.

Secondly, the Opposition knows it has to keep Medicare because it gives universal coverage. That means that every Australian is covered because of the Medicare principles. The Opposition does not dare remove them. It knows that if it removed them we would go back to how it was in the years of the Fraser Government with at least two million people without insurance. It is a situation like the American system. The Opposition knows it dare not go to the people with the prospect of two million people becoming uninsured. We know that is what would happen under its policies because of the cost it will put on people. It has kept Medicare for universal coverage.

Opposition members are a very sly lot. They keep Medicare, which they say is bad, because they want the money, they want universal coverage and they want the goodwill that goes with the name. They do not like to say that but it is true. Medicare is known, liked and dramatically appreciated by Australians around this country, and the Opposition would not dare to remove it. That is why it is keeping the name. It is keeping Medicare for the money, it is keeping Medicare for the insurance it will have with everybody covered universally and it is keeping it because it wants the goodwill from the name. It is very difficult for the Opposition to say out of one side of its mouth that Medicare is in crisis and out of the other side of its mouth that it will keep it.

The Opposition does not like to tell people that under its health policy they will have to pay more to see the doctor. It will be a dramatic increase—up to $31 every time they go to see the doctor. What is more, those opposite will introduce the terrible co-payment. They will say to people, `You will not get insurance for more than 85 per cent of the cost of going to see your doctor'. Under the Fightback package, the arrangements will return to people 75 per cent of the fee from Medicare and allow them to buy private insurance against the gap from 75 to 85 per cent. But then they will pay from 85 per cent to 100 per cent themselves any time, every time.

That is about $5. Sometimes it may be a bit more than that, but Dr Bob Woods, who is the Opposition spokesperson on health, has settled on $5 so I will not dispute it. It is at least $5 which people will be left to pay after they get their bill for $31, after they claim from Medicare to get back their 75 per cent, and after they go to their private insurance company for the gap between 75 and 85 per cent. If they are still hanging in there, trying to recover from the paperwork, they will still have a bill of $5 per head, per time. One would not want to take two or three kids to the doctor at any one time.

Under this system, we will have a return to the awful old days when people made decisions about going to the doctor not in terms of their need for health care but in terms of whether they could afford it. It is an outrage when we have a system in place which is of such benefit to people in general practice that it should be replaced in the way in which the Opposition is proposing.

Why are those opposite proposing to do this? I can assure honourable senators that the Government is not proposing it. They are proposing to do it because, in this case, they are beholden to the AMA. They are also linked very closely to implementing the agenda of the private insurance industry. This means that they have sold out the Australian people in favour of the vested interests they want to support.

We now turn to private insurance. The Opposition says that if one's family income is about $30,000, one will neither benefit nor be disadvantaged. Of course, that really means that people will have to pay for their health insurance themselves, but they will not get any rebate. If one's income is below $30,000, one will get a rebate on a sliding scale under the Opposition's policy. If the family income is $20,000 the Opposition will give a rebate of $200, but people will have to find the other $600 themselves.If one happens to be over 65 years of age and one's family income is below $12,500, the Government will pay the whole $800 itself. The Opposition is planning to rebate people $800, but we now hear Dr Woods saying that the Opposition will probably pay that $800 directly to the private insurance companies on people's behalf. What kind of system is that?

Most people do not realise that with private insurance all they will be getting is a licence for the specialists to charge like wounded bulls. Private insurance is no longer an assurance against medical bills; in fact, it is exactly the opposite. One of the principal reasons why people are leaving private insurance at the moment is that it does not provide that assurance or that comfort, but it does provide the likelihood of a very large bill.

Any number of people have written or spoken to me about their own story. They tell me, `I have been buying private insurance for the last 25 years, 30 years or whatever. I want to make my contribution and I know that if I ever get sick I would like to be able to say that I have private insurance to back up my bills'. What has happened is that these people have had to use it.
