When they have gone into hospital and had an operation under their private insurance, they have found themselves saying, `What am I going to do, Senator, I've got a bill for $3,000 over and above what my insurance paid? I'm on a fixed income; how on earth am I going to find it?'.

That is not a one-off case. Many people, when they finally go to use their private insurance, are shocked to find that they have a big bill. Under the Opposition we can be sure that the bill will be bigger, because the Opposition is moving to the AMA schedule of fees not only for general practice but also across the board. For specialists, that means a 25 to 30 per cent increase in costs. Those opposite say that the insurance will cost $800 per person. That has to be laughable because, at the moment, if people are lucky that would buy basic table cover, which will get them a private bed in a public hospital and nothing else. That is what the Opposition is offering—an $800 outlay and the prospect of a very significant increase in bills as the Opposition moves to the AMA schedule of fees, directly underwriting the specialists with an increase in costs. People will pay more, they will be hurting more and they will be charged more. Where is the money going? It is going straight through to the specialists and the private insurance industry.

In our Budget this year we will move $1.3 billion—I welcome Senator Herron; I thought he might join us—to the public hospital system over six years. The Opposition has a policy which says it will remove that and more from the public hospital system by underwriting private insurance and encouraging people to take the opportunity to go private and cop the bill.

The other thing that those opposite are not telling us is that the impact of the increased charges under the AMA schedule of fees will be directly inflationary. The cost of going to the doctor will get into the basket of goods which contributes to the CPI. Those opposite will raise inflation with a deliberate health policy which will increase the cost of going to the doctor and increase the cost of private insurance. Those opposite are claiming that it may reduce the cost of private insurance, but many more people will be forced to take it out. Bracketing those two things together, this means that the cost of private insurance will rise and it will be directly inflationary.

I think the Opposition's own modest estimates put the inflationary effect at 0.7 per cent. That is a very modest assessment of the inflationary effect of its health policies. It will no doubt be more. What is more, it is only able to be introduced under cover of the GST. It is a very sneaky policy. Those opposite do not want to tell people that while they say we should maintain low inflation they are directly putting it up. They do not want to tell people that. They are saying that the inflationary effect of the GST will wash out very quickly, but the health contribution will stay and stay.

That is what the Opposition would do if it were in government—it would whack up the cost to the individual, whack up the cost of private insurance, benefit the specialist doctors, and make a wonderful inflationary contribution which would maintain forever and make everything more expensive again. As well as the 15 per cent GST, those opposite would add their own little inflationary contribution. This move is particularly regressive and unfair for those people on low and fixed incomes. Those opposite are a sneaky lot—particularly with regard to their health costs.

The important things to remember about the Opposition's health policy are the hidden extra costs in it. This is not obvious when one reads through Fightback! and sees the headlines which make it look as though everything will be much better. As I said at the beginning of my contribution when I followed Senator Michael Baume, we would have to cop the GST on food and on the clothing we would use if we were to take up a sport. But should we be interested in things such as preventive health and promoting health through a better diet, mineral intakes, vitamin intakes, sport and exercise, and self-treatments of that sort, then the GST would be added to all of those things too. Many of the things which are classed as `lifestyle matters' or are part of the contribution to preventive health would have a GST applied to them as well. This lot opposite is pretty good: every time you stick your head up, whack, they will increase the costs.

Having made one sick, the Opposition will then make it impossible for anyone to cope when they have to get into the health system. The Opposition is a tough lot. It has all these clever stories about how 10 per cent will come off, but 15 per cent will be going on. By anybody's equation, that is an increase in costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is zero rated health.
—It is very interesting to hear Senator Kemp say that, but what parts? Not the bits that I have talked about.
—All of it.

—No, we have talked about this before. They should have resisted coming in here. None of the measures under the better health program are outside the GST. This is a sneaky part of the Opposition's policy.
—What about bandaids; what about aspirin?
—They are better off under our policies than yours, Bob.
—They will be too sick to care and they will not be able to pay the bills.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Senator Crowley, I wonder whether you would make your speech and I will listen to you. The others might just give you a hearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am enormously assisted by the Chair. The other point that needs to be spelt out is that currently, under the Medicare arrangement with this Government, Australia spends 8 per cent of its total income, its GDP, on health. That level has been maintained over the years we have been in government, and it compares very well with other countries. In the United States, which is the way the Opposition wants us to go, 12 per cent of GDP is spent on health. That is estimated to rise to 15 or 16 per cent by the year 2000. Indeed, if the United States continues the way it is going now, it will be spending 25 per cent of GDP by the year 2030. I suspect that it is not without relevance that Mr Clinton is doing so well in the US presidential race, because one of the things that he is arguing for is a dramatic change in health care and the way it is funded and insured against. The Americans know that they cannot continue that way.

PARA.TAB: However, in this country we have an Opposition which says, `We will go back and go that way'. The Opposition wants to remove bulkbilling, the constraints of Medicare and bulkbilling that are now in the system, which we see are working at restraining costs and which are so acceptable to the community. If we take the figures, we can see that the medical profession is also accommodating what is required under Medicare. We can see that it is very much liked. Any poll will show that the Australian community is clear in liking Medicare; they want Medicare and they can see no reason for it to change. It is simple and fair, cuts down the cost of going to the doctor or the hospital, and it provides health care for all.

Finally, I want to deal with some of the better fibs told by the Opposition about waiting lists. In this Budget the Government has allocated the expenditure of $70m over the next two years to deal directly with reducing waiting lists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh well, after 10 years that is a great effort.
—That is a good interjection from Senator Kemp because it means that he does not know too much at all. It is only three years ago that we spent $50m between the States and the Commonwealth—
—But you have been in Government for 10 years.

—We have done it before. Senator Kemp is either ignorant or does not know his history; otherwise he is deliberately not knowing his history. The Government, in an arrangement with the States, allocated once before a specific extra funding to reduce waiting lists and it worked.

PARA.TAB: The facts about waiting lists are very hard to assess. We do not have accurate or reliable data. However, we have Peter Shack saying in 1990 that 100,000 people were on waiting lists around the country and the Fightback package last year saying that it was 60,000. That could be because the Labor Government had reduced it by 40,000 in two years, but it is more likely to be that it is just a best guess. The Opposition bid it way up because that is the message that it wants to tell people and the Government is trying to bid it fair. It is trying to obtain the data on waiting lists.

Waiting lists are State matters. It is very difficult to get the States to pass that information over to the Commonwealth. That is one of the things that would be up for negotiation in the current round of Commonwealth-State agreements for Medicare. We cannot go on not having access to that data. If the States want a fair allocation of funding to deal with the health care that they are providing for their citizens—and this Government strongly supports that—then it is also important that the States provide sufficient, accurate, reliable and timely data to enable the Government to assist the States. It is not a matter of being at war; it is a matter of trying to assess, with the help of the data, the best way of providing funding to the States.

The Opposition runs on fear and smear. It is always its tactic—it has done it with waiting lists—because it trades on human misery. It is a disgusting campaign. The stories put around by the Opposition about waiting lists are of no assistance to government or to the people in the community who are dealing with the difficulties that they have to confront. The Opposition has the view that there would be no such thing as waiting lists if it ever got into office because everyone would be forced to take out private health insurance and would retreat to the private hospitals. We know that they will not. I say that for many reasons, particularly clinical reasons—that is, the nature of the illness. People will continue to attend public hospitals because that is where the state-of-the-art health care is.

It is of remarkable relevance to ask where Kerry Packer went after he suffered his heart attack. I do not think he was in too much of a position to say at the time where he went. He went into the public hospital system. He was treated and assisted to recover. After he had made his recovery, he went on to convalesce in the private hospital system. People who suffer heart attacks and have heart problems will continue to go to public hospitals from whatever part of Australia they come and whatever their insurance status. That is where those conditions are best and most often treated.

One does not go to a private hospital to receive acute care for cardiac problems. We do not go to a private hospital for major brain surgery. We do not go to a private hospital for intensive care. One will not under the Opposition's health policy. We will continue, as clinical condition dictates and as the medical profession sees best, to send people into the public hospital system. People will also choose to go into the public hospital system.

What people are facing, coming up to the next election when they consider their health prospects, is the simple, fair, accessible universal system we have at the moment called Medicare which they understand, which they like and which they want to see continue. The alternative is the gobbledegook and mess that the Opposition intends to put in its place. The Opposition will increase individual costs of visits to the doctor, force private health insurance on to people, increase dramatically the cost of treatment in hospitals, increase inflation and blow out the GDP percentage of expenditure allocated to health. It is a very easy debate to take to the public. I am certainly going to do it, as I have been again and again. The Opposition wants people to pay more; we want them to have Medicare, which is fair and universal. There is no way that the health policy of the Opposition can win votes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bills before the Parliament. The few honourable senators who are in this chamber and heard the remarks of Senator Crowley—there may be more who have tuned in to listen—may be interested to be reminded that Senator Crowley used the phrase `fear and smear' about the coalition's policy. I suggest that for half an hour we have had what can only be termed as fear and smear.

PARA.TAB: People who are listening tonight will be interested to know that this is an example—although not a particularly good example—of the sort of scare campaign which the Australian Labor Party will run between now and the next election. Senator Crowley has had her marching orders. Mr Keating has told her, `What we have to do is scare the hell out of people. You go into that Parliament and say anything at all which will cause fear amongst ordinary Australian citizens'. Senator Crowley does not do this all that well, but she came in here and ran the Labor line.

I will just put a few facts on the record for people who may have felt concerned about some of the remarks that Senator Crowley made. I urge people who have further concerns to speak to my colleague Senator Herron who will be speaking in this debate probably tomorrow or the next week that Parliament sits. They will be interested to learn in detail just how wrong Senator Crowley was.

The health system of this country is strained for lack of funds. One only has to ask any health Minister, Labor or Liberal, around the States. That is the reason why we have mounting hospital queues. Senator Crowley conceded in her remarks that she did not have a clue what the hospital queues are. Why would Senator Crowley know what the waiting times are for people to get treatment in hospitals, because the Labor Government simply does not want to find out these facts. The facts are very damaging to the Labor Government. They affect many people in its own constituency.

I suggest that there are many Labor people out there who are waiting for treatment in hospitals, who are surprised that Senator Crowley did not seem to know, or evince any interest in finding out, what are the elementary facts: what are the waiting lists in hospitals—all of us know that they are very substantial; and what can be done about them. Senator Crowley made no commitments to cut back the growing waiting lists which we are seeing in hospitals.

The Medicare levy itself, as we know, only supplies a minor part of the funds which are needed for health care in this country. The vast bulk, of course, comes from taxation—Consolidated Revenue. The Government's answer to the health crisis is what economists term rationing. Rationing essentially means that if you will not provide enough services, the queues form, and that is precisely what we are now seeing in the hospital system.

We have set out in great detail an excellent health policy in the Fightback program which will take the pressure off the public health system by subsidising, and this is the point that the Labor Party really detests. Under the John Hewson plan we will be subsidising lower income earners to take out private health insurance. These are the very people, often members of the Labor constituency, who are at the end of the queue. The only freedom they have at the moment is to join the queue. If the particular treatment they require is not acute, they have the freedom now to join the queue. This is another of these lengthening queues which has expanded under the Labor Government. We have the expanding health queues and the expanding dole queues. As I said, Senator Herron will be explaining in detail the excellent health policy that the Liberal and National parties have put together.

Often, when I go around and speak to people and they raise the scare tactics that Senator Crowley has raised today—and Senator McMullan occasionally gets up here and fulfils his marching orders and tries to raise a few shock horrors—I find the most effective thing to say when they repeat what Labor people have been saying to me is, `Why would you believe anything that Mr Keating says?'. Why would they? The man has an incredible, I suspect absolutely unparalleled, record of breaking his commitments to the Australian people.

Mr Keating, we know, believes in the shock horror politics, the politics of the big scare, the politics of the big lie. We probably have not had a Prime Minister like that in this country, certainly not in my own memory. These Appropriation Bills before us clearly outline an important part of the election strategy of the Labor Government which Mr Keating has laid down.

On reflecting on the debates in this Parliament today and previously, it is clear that Mr Keating has managed to convince at least enough of the Labor Party to overthrow their elected leader, Mr Hawke, and put him in office in the hope that somehow he can, shall I say, save the Labor bacon. In recent months we have seen a somewhat unique man in terms of what we have seen in Australian politics before. Many Prime Ministers have led this country, but Mr Keating in many ways has unique characteristics which I happen to believe make him somewhat ill-suited to lead this country—certainly to lead this country in a time of great crisis.

I have set down seven features of Mr Keating which I believe the public will want to focus on as we go to the next election. Firstly, he is, arguably, probably the richest Prime Minister in Australian history.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party gets embarrassed by that. There is nothing wrong with being rich, but it is a bit difficult to play the class war line if you are a multi-millionaire like Mr Keating. He is arguably the richest Prime Minister in Australian history. Secondly, he is the only Prime Minister in our history who is not proud to fly our flag. John Curtin certainly was very proud to fly our flag, as was the greatly esteemed Ben Chifley. These men were not embarrassed about flying our flag and Dr Evatt, of course, is on the record as describing our flag as the most beautiful flag in the world. There are not many things that I agree with Dr Evatt on, but I think he was absolutely spot on on that issue. As I said, one of the characteristics of Mr Keating is that he is the only Prime Minister who is not proud of our flag and will not fly it.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly—and I think this cannot be argued against—he is the only Prime Minister who has ever attacked our national institutions while overseas. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, would undoubtedly have felt the horror that many Australians felt about the trip to Jakarta where Mr Keating felt it was appropriate to bag our Constitution in a foreign country. I think that marks him off as having another unique characteristic.

Fourthly, I believe that Mr Keating holds the record for demeaning Parliament and lowering parliamentary standards. Many tens of thousands of people watch our Question Time, and Question Time in the House of Representatives, and can see day after day the accuracy of that statement. The fifth characteristic that I believe makes Mr Keating somewhat unique is that he has probably chalked up a record second to none in terms of broken promises and policy failures. This will be an issue that I will be expanding on later in my remarks.

The sixth characteristic of Mr Keating is that he is, I suspect—and there will be debates on this—the most cynical of Prime Ministers. He will do anything, say anything and attack any institution to advance his own narrow interests and those of the Labor Party. The seventh characteristic that I think is worth bringing to the attention of the public is that he has certainly led the country to its worst recession since the 1930s. I put all of those characteristics down on the record. There may be other ones which people might like to highlight, but it is interesting that this Prime Minister has marked himself out as a unique Prime Minister in a number of ways.

In regard to Senator Crowley's remarks, I raise the issue: who would believe Mr Keating after what he has said? I remind people that in the period before the last election quite a number of issues were debated. I think the most memorable was the promise by Mr Keating—made almost on a daily basis—that there would not be a recession in this country. All of us can recall that Mr Keating, being constantly pressed on this matter, assured the Australian public time and time again that there would not be a recession. Of course, as we know, not only did we have a recession but we had the worst recession in 60 years.

When Parliament resumed after the March election in 1990, Mr Keating continued to pretend that there was no recession in this country, despite the mounting evidence and the concerns of people in big business and small business alike. Mr Acting Deputy President, you may remember the headlines on 29 November when the Prime Minister was finally embarrassed into admitting what everybody else knew and what Senator Button knew and had already made comments on: that the accounts did show that Australia was in recession. He then went on to say a phrase which has certainly gone down in Australian history and which continues to vex members on the Labor side because it shows a harshness and a cynicism which I do not think we have seen in Australian politics. Mr Keating not only admitted that we were in a recession—and that was certainly an important concession—he then went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The most important thing about it is, this is the recession that Australia had to have.
In other words, the man who was not going to let there be a recession, the man who denied that there was a recession, conceded in November 1990 that this was the recession we had to have.

PARA.TAB: I suspect that people in the community have long asked: if that was the case, why did Mr Keating not level with us at that time? As recently as last week, our Prime Minister was up to his old tricks; his old habits of overstatement and saying anything at any time if he perceives some political advantage. Last week in the Parliament, Mr Keating, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We were out of the recession long ago.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not know whether you read the Australian, but you will find on either page 2 or 3 of that paper this morning that Mr Keating conceded in Caucus that that remark had damaged not only his own standing—which I find a bit hard to believe because I would not have thought his own standing could be damaged further—but also that of the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: It is important to remember that as we go to the next election we are going to get these complaints and these scare tactics from the Labor Party, and that we are getting them from a man who simply has shown that he will say anything, do anything and break any promise, provided that he can perceive some narrow political advantage.

The other issue that came forth in that election which I wish to raise in this chamber is the great concern in the election campaign about whether Mr Hawke was going to stay on as Prime Minister. Undoubtedly during that election period, Senator McMullan and Senator West were asked by constituents whether Mr Hawke was going to run his full term. It was a very big issue and I suspect that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, can recall that issue being raised. How often did Mr Hawke say that, yes, he was going to serve his full term? It came out many months later that, in November of the previous year, an agreement had been reached between Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, witnessed by the two other leaders of the corporate state in Australia, Mr Bill Kelty and Sir Peter Abeles, that during the term of the next Hawke Government, if it was elected, there would be a transfer of power to Mr Keating.

While this grubby deal was transacted, with witnesses Bill Kelty and Sir Peter Abeles, Mr Hawke had no compunction about saying that he would be serving his full term—and neither did Mr Keating, because he was being pressed by the newspapers to say whether it was true that a deal had been done with Mr Hawke to transfer the Prime Ministership to him if Labor was re-elected to office.

I do not know whether we could use the term `the much loved Senator Button' on the Labor side of politics because Senator Button does seem to have a habit of raising interesting issues, sometimes in relation to Labor policy—rather like blowing the whistle. On 6 February, Senator Button said in an interview in the Herald:

SPEECH.PARA: What I think I said was that Hawke and Keating ought to reach some agreement about this; that Keating had been around for a long time and that I would have hoped Hawke and Keating would have reached some agreement about it. I suspect, incidentally, that they have.

That is what Senator Button said on 6 February. Having raised the issue he then said, `I don't know'. This was a fundamental issue. We were in an election period and the issue before the Australian people was: `If we vote Labor, are we electing Hawke or are we really electing Mr Keating?'. It was a very big issue and it was raised.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating, our current Prime Minister, told the Melbourne Sun News-Pictorial on 7 February 1990 that he had not made a deal with Mr Hawke on the leadership. He then went on to say that he wished to stay on as Treasurer. That was very big of him. Of course, he tried to hose down the issue that some grubby deal had been reached. Mr Keating had no compunction whatsoever, one would have to say, in telling a—

TALK.START.PARA: —Porky pie.

—A porky pie, says Senator O'Chee. Mr Keating had no compunction in misleading, in a disgraceful manner, the Australian public in this vital election period. It was in the famous National Press Club speech on 7 February 1991 that Mr Keating likened himself to Placido Domingo and implied to the press that Mr Hawke was not a great leader. Some months later he confessed that a deal had been struck which Mr Hawke had dishonoured.

PARA.TAB: I put it to honourable senators that these were the two major issues for the people at the last election: would there be a recession; and did the Labor Party have the policies to pull the country out of recession if it got into it, or did it have the policies to avoid the recession? Mr Keating promised day after day that there would be no recession. In other words, he was trying to build up confidence again and retain confidence in the Government. That has a striking similarity to the current situation. The other issue was whether the public was electing Mr Hawke or Mr Keating to be Prime Minister.

As I said, Mr Keating misled the Australian public on those two critical issues. He has never, to my mind, apologised to the Australian people for those two grossly misleading statements—the statement on the recession and the statement on whether there had been a deal with Mr Hawke. I suggest to members of the Australian public that when they hear their Labor members of parliament and their Labor senators going around trying to scare them, remember that they are working from the marching orders of Mr Keating, a man who has a completely unenviable record in misleading the Australian public. I mentioned seven of Mr Keating's characteristics. I suppose I could mention an eighth one.

TALK.START.PARA: —The seven deadly sins.

—I think that is an appropriate comment. There is an eighth one which is relevant to the debate before this chamber: not only whether Mr Keating has any plan to lead Australia out of the recession but whether he has the policy prescriptions which can lead Australia towards a full employment economy and solve the economic crisis that we are now facing.

PARA.TAB: I have to say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the incredible range of policy flips and policy changes which have occurred since Mr Keating assumed the office of Prime Minister have been absolutely amazing. We have had the One Nation statement which, within a matter of months, certainly seemed to have failed; it was conceded widely by people on the Labor side of the Parliament to have failed. That is why some further radical changes were brought down in Mr Keating's latest Budget.

I ask Senator McMullan whether he can remember the amazing way in which policy was being developed by this Government. I wonder whether he can recall, as I recall, the really quite famous interview on the Sunday program with Laurie Oakes in May. This was Mr Keating grabbing the initiative. He announced that there would be major changes in relation to the privatisation of Qantas. The first of the many pay TV policies was announced. There was going to be this great national scheme with TAFE. The Labor Caucus was excited by this stunning performance of Mr Keating, who was able to appear on Laurie Oakes's show and announce three major policy initiatives in one hit.

It is interesting when we look back at all this to see how many of those great policy initiatives have remained. The States certainly gave Mr Keating his marching orders on the so-called national TAFE scheme—that collapsed. It was a headline which probably lasted for a day or so. Then there was the issue of pay TV. We have had the fourth change of policy since then, or the fifth—I do not know. Senator McMullan may enlighten us in his remarks. Probably, by the time Senator McMullan sums up this debate, we will have had a few more policy changes. This interview was Mr Keating's stunning performance in bringing down these new policies. Of course, there is now considerable doubt whether the privatisation plans for Qantas will succeed. There are serious problems in relation to that policy.

Here we have a classic case of policy on the run, policy poorly conceived, policy poorly thought through, policy designed merely to grab the headlines and to re-grab the initiative. As always with Mr Keating, there is policy failure. Has our Prime Minister learned, Mr Acting Deputy President? The answer must surely be no. I remind you of Mr Keating's recent trip to Japan. I guess, like many Australians, we really would prefer Mr Keating and his Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, to stay at home, because every time they go overseas there seems to be a further series of crises and problems.

My colleagues in this chamber and I believe it is the role of our political leaders to advance the interests of our country. But given the experience of Senator Evans' recent trips and Mr Keating's two well-covered trips, one hardly feels that our country's interests have been advanced. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, of the lead story in one of the newspapers today about Mr Keating's trip to Japan. The lead story stated, `Mr Keating back-pedals on trade attacks'.
No wonder that occurred; Mr Keating's remarks in Japan have probably led to the deepest rift in US-Australian relations in a generation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator McMullan laughs. But I guess a lot of Australians are concerned to advance the interests of our country. We wonder at the wisdom of a man who goes to Tokyo and spends a considerable amount of his time bagging our major ally and attacking the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). We wonder at the sorts of standards of a Prime Minister who goes overseas and conducts himself in that way—and, I might say, who encourages people in Japan to attack the Opposition Leader. What sort of Prime Minister do we have who conducts himself in that way? What sort of national pride is it when he tries to rev up the foreign owned multinationals in the boardrooms of Detroit and Tokyo and comes out and attacks John Hewson? I wonder what sort of man, what sort of leader of our country, does that?

PARA.TAB: I know that the so-called psycho-history is an interesting trend in the writing of history at the moment. We have recently had a book written on the late Sir Robert Menzies—arguably one of Australia's great political leaders. He was a man who, above all, I suggest, had great standards of propriety; he was certainly a man who concentrated all his attention on trying to run this country rather than trying to run a pig farm; and he was a man who had little interest in making money but had a great love and passion for our country. I would suggest that there is a great contrast between the current actions and values embodied by Mr Keating and those of Sir Robert Menzies.

When we look at the psycho-history of Mr Keating and his behaviour, I wonder whether the question could be posed: what possesses a man really to show no capacity for consistency; what possesses a man shamelessly to go out and constantly mislead the country about the real nature of the problems that must be solved; what possess a man to so ceaselessly change his mind on his policies?

I ask honourable senators to remember that Mr Keating, the man Senator McMullan wanted to be Prime Minister, was in 1985 the greatest advocate of a goods and services tax—and I can give Senator McMullan and any other Labor person probably 10 to 20 pages of quotes from Mr Keating arguing vehemently that one of the major tax reforms this country needed was a goods and services tax.

Why was it wrong in the mid 1980s for the Liberal and National parties to be proposing policies for the privatisation of Qantas, the Commonwealth Bank and Australian Airlines—and, of course, at that time Mr Keating was out there attacking them—yet they are now the policy directions that Mr Keating has picked up? I might say that he has picked them up very imperfectly and is probably privatising major government assets at the very worst possible time. But in the mid 1980s Mr Keating saw that there was a political advantage in having these scare tactics. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp's fine words on Paul Keating remind me actually of a line from the Bible. He does not often remind me of things from the Bible, but tonight he reminds me of a line from the Bible which says, `There came into the land a prophet who could not see'. That is the problem this nation has at the moment. We have as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) a man who purports to be a prophet but who has no clear vision for the future direction of this nation. At a time when we are in as perilous an economic state as we are now, there can be nothing more dangerous to the future of Australia than a Prime Minister who cannot see the way forward.

PARA.TAB: Here we have a Prime Minister who told this nation, shortly after he was appointed, that he would make Australia more independent. Here we have a Prime Minister who said that we should take away a portion of our flag to make it different from the one we have at the moment to stress our independence. Then what does that Prime Minister do when he goes to Japan? He says to the Japanese that he gives them his solemn undertaking that he will not enter into any trade agreement that could be detrimental to Japan. This is the man who preached greater independence for Australia: the man who goes to Japan, who goes to Tokyo and says, `I won't do anything that might be detrimental to the interests of Japan'—not detrimental to the interests of Australia but detrimental to the interests of Japan. So much for greater Australian independence; so much for a brave new vision.

This is the man who, just before he knifed Prime Minister Hawke in the back, was running around every media outlet in the country giving them every day a different version of his vision for the future of Australia. Yet here is the man, a Prime Minister for 10 months now, who has been wholly incapable of delivering this nation from the economic morass into which he pitched it.

Here is the man who, when I entered parliament 2 1/2 years ago, was preaching the virtues of micro-economic reform. Where is that micro-economic reform? Where are the reforms in communications? Where are the reforms in the workplace? And where are the reforms in the taxation system that will do what Australia really needs—that is, provide some incentive once again to all the hard working men and women in this country who are forced to battle, day after day, because that Government and the former Treasurer, the man who is now Prime Minister, got it wrong? There are no reforms because there is no vision and because this Government and this Prime Minister are wholly incapable of doing anything at all to change our economic situation.

What we need now is a fundamental change in the direction of this nation. We seem to have a Prime Minister who embodies what Senator Kemp referred to as `Paul Keating's seven deadly sins'. What I advocate we must do instead is put in place what I consider to be four fairly important temporal virtues—and which four temporal virtues are they? They are the four economic temporal virtues which are simply these: less tax, less government, more wealth, and more opportunity for ordinary working Australians.

Under this Government we have an enormous taxation burden: an enormous burden of personal taxation; an enormous burden of indirect taxation. We have payroll tax at 5 or 6 per cent which is putting Australian workers out of jobs in droves. Lest anybody think that 5 per cent payroll tax is a small imposition on an employer, just consider this: in Rockhampton, where we have two major meatworks, each of which employs about 400 people, the payroll in each of those meatworks is something in excess of $12m; the 5 per cent payroll tax applicable in Queensland means that each of those meatworks pays, in government taxation for employing meat workers, over $600,000 a year.

If we look at the desperate situation of the meat industry in Australia, at abattoirs that have closed down from one end of Australia to the other, at meat workers who have been thrown on the unemployment queue by this Government's taxation policies and by this Government's industrial relations policies, we are forced to ask ourselves: how many more abattoirs would have stayed open if they could have had $600,000 more profit every year? But they will not get it under Labor; they will not get it under Paul Keating; they will not get it under this Government because this Government believes in more rather than less taxation.

At a time when we need less government, what do we get but a burgeoning public sector. The reason why we get a burgeoning public sector is that that is the only way that this Government can engineer any sort of growth at all in the economy. We on this side of the chamber say that not only should there be less taxation, but also less government, meaning less debt and many more opportunities for people out there in the private sector to generate real wealth. And more wealth is the third of the economic temporal virtues which we on this side of the chamber espouse today.

There should be more wealth, and not just for the wealthy, as has happened under Paul Keating and Bob Hawke—because under that pair of Prime Ministers we have seen a growing gap between rich and poor—but more wealth for all Australians through a policy that will reward those people who wish to make an effort. There will be more wealth for people who wish to work longer or harder or smarter. That is how this nation was built—on hard work, endeavour and achievement. They are the very qualities and characteristics that this Government, through its taxation policy, is destroying in this nation today.

Of course, the fourth economic temporal virtue—and it flows from the other three—is more opportunity, by reforming the industrial relations system, for example. If somebody wants to choose to work outside the award or work different hours and start at 8 o'clock instead of 9 o'clock and finish at 4 o'clock instead of 5 o'clock, that person and his or her employer should not be penalised for doing so. If somebody wants to work three 12-hour days in a week and have four days off and their employer is happy for them to do so, for example, at the Oral-B factory in Goulburn, why should they not be allowed to do it?

Why should we have a system where the people in suits in the Industrial Relations Commission can tell a panel-beater on the Sunshine Coast, a steel-worker in Cairns or a miner in Mount Isa that they know more about their job than the worker themselves?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ridiculous.

—As Senator Bjelke-Petersen says quite rightly, it is ridiculous. And more than that; it is an insult to the workers of this country. The workers are highly educated people who are capable of making their own decisions for themselves. Gone are the days at the turn of the century when the late Billy Hughes set up the Waterside Workers Federation and when unions had an important role to play because workers were poorly educated. We have some of the best educated workers in the world. The only problem seems to be that they have a government which professes to be a Labor Party government but which derides their intelligence and treats them as though they are incapable of making proper decisions for themselves. The fourth economic temporal virtue of more opportunity is what this nation so desperately requires here today.

PARA.TAB: At this point, I know, the time is fast approaching 7.30 p.m. and I understand there is other business of the Senate to be dealt with before we bring on the adjournment debate. Therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today at Question Time both Senator Hill and I asked questions of Senator Button, and I must say that in regard to the matter I raise, the Senate cannot have any confidence in what Senator Button has said over a period of three months.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of Government in the Senate (Senator Button) have given contradictory information to the Australian public and the Senate about ministerial discussions in relation to the pig industry. Mr Keating was reported in the Age on 16 September as saying that the joint venture in which he has a shareholding has not been the subject of any ministerial talks. However, information provided by one of his Ministers, Senator Cook, to an Estimates committee hearing the day after, 17 September, stated that Mr Crean, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, said he was pleased with the progress evident in pork joint ventures. This statement is in a ministerial recall note of a meeting held between Mr Crean and the Danish Minister for Agriculture, Mr Tornaes, on 8 April 1992.

Also, an Australian Quarantine Inspection Service ministerial briefing refers to the joint venture between Danpork (Denmark) and Brown and Hatton and the possible use of Danish pig genetic material. The same AQIS document refers to the Danish Minister for Agriculture raising the matter of access for pig semen during discussions with Mr Crean in April 1992.

The joint venture between Danpork and the Brown and Hatton group—the group in which Mr Keating has an interest—was registered on 28 November 1991. The information provided by Mr Keating to the Age clearly contradicts the actions of his own primary industry Minister.

Senator Button has said that there have been no discussions between Australia and Danish Ministers on the issue of the importation of Danish genetic material. However, this claim is contradicted by the AQIS ministerial briefing, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Danish Minister for Agriculture raised the matter of access for uncooked Danish pigmeat and pig semen during discussions with Mr Crean in April 1992.
Pig semen clearly qualifies as genetic material.

PARA.TAB: In Question Time, Senator Button tried to deflect attention from the central issue which we sought to address: that is, that he mislead the Senate on several occasions by asserting that there had not been ministerial discussions about the importation of genetic material.

His use of a paragraph on another page of the AQIS document which states that there had been no `requests or directions from any Minister, the Prime Minister or their staff' has no connection with the central issue. The paragraph is irrelevant because it has nothing to do with whether there has been any ministerial discussion on the importation of Danish genetic material.

Senator Button's comments about the issue reflect his overall approach to Question Time this week. He misled the Senate on the issues of growth rates in the Australian economy, and tariff levels on four-wheel drive vehicles, and now he has been caught out on the issue of pigs. I know that my colleague Senator Hill will join me in condemnation of the answers that Senator Button has given to the Senate over the past two or three months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week I met Vessa Burchett, who is now an Australian citizen living in Sydney. She is seeking a widow's pension under the Social Security Act, but so far unsuccessfully as she does not meet the residential qualification provided for in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The requirement that a person should live in Australia for a specified period before being entitled to payments from the public purse is in general a reasonable proposition. But does it hold good when a series of Australian governments have unfairly prejudiced a person's opportunity of meeting the requirement?

For a number of years the ability of Mrs Burchett to come to Australia was frustrated by successive Federal governments. This had to do with the view they formed of her husband, Wilfred Burchett. They saw him as a figure of evil given to the Communist cause in times of awesome tension between East and West. Because of this, they refused him a passport and effectively kept him in exile for many years. They made sure that his wife and children did not become Australian citizens and were kept abroad.

The most learned of people have debated the issue of whether Wilfred Burchett did great good or great evil or both during his lifetime. The relevant knowledge I have is limited and in this speech I do not address it. Rather, I will talk of the injustice governments did to the man and his family by effectively keeping him offshore for over a decade and a half without telling him in specific terms what they held against him and denying him an opportunity to put his case to a court, or even to an administrative authority.

Just government requires that people accused of wrongdoing not be punished until after a fair hearing. It requires that this be afforded not only to the supposedly innocent, the beautiful, the young and the gracious, but to the supposedly guilty, the old, the ugly and the boorish.

In speaking of the want of proper process in the way Federal governments dealt with Wilfred Burchett, I do not imply that the substance of his case lacked merit. He maintained throughout his life that his actions were honourable and in keeping with his obligations as an Australian. No court has ever held to the contrary. According to our common law tradition, he is entitled to his good name. Exile is a fearful penalty, whether applied with or without a hearing.

Wilfred Burchett was a fourth generation Australian born on 16 September 1911 at Poowong in Victoria and he grew up in that State. He is the only person in Federal history with that kind of background to be denied his birthright. That denial has cost his wife and children much. Deuteronomy says:

SPEECH.PARA: Fathers shall not be put to death for the sins of their sons. Neither shall sons be killed for the sins of their fathers. Every man worthy of death shall die for his own crime.

The concept behind this saying is that people should be punished only for their own actions, not for those of others no matter how closely related. It has much relevance to the case of Vessa Burchett and her children, particularly for those who consider her husband did great wrong.

PARA.TAB: Great bitterness was engendered during the Cold War. It became particularly virulent during the conflicts in Korea and Vietnam. Mercifully, it is ebbing away with the reconciliation between East and West. The giving of a widow's pension to Vessa Burchett would symbolise the coming of the new era.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few comments about the very important answer of Senator Robert Ray to a dorothy dix question today in which he advised the Australian Parliament of the Government's decision to contribute Australian military personnel to the UN force in Somalia. Before doing that, I will take up for a moment or two the matter that Senator Boswell raised on the adjournment.

PARA.TAB: I endorse the concerns that are being expressed by Senator Boswell in this matter. It is particularly confusing and there are many unanswered questions. The interjections that we have been receiving in Question Time in relation to these matters are clearly designed to put Senator Boswell and others off, but I can tell you, Mr Deputy President, that we are not going to be put off. We are going to get to the bottom of this matter.
The first mystery I observe is the letter from Mr Landos, the director of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service dated 3 June 1992. In that letter he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Danes first raised the possibility of access for live pigs in the mid 1980s. This request was not formally followed-up until 1990 when it re-emerged as an issue at Prime Ministerial level in the context of proposals for a joint venture between Danish and Australian pig breeding and processing interests.
We know that Mr Landos said he was mistaken in including those words because, in a letter of 21 July, he said:

I must correct an error in my previous advice to you at Page 2, Paragraph 4 of my 3 June 1992 letter regarding the status of proposals for importation of live pigs from Denmark. This letter incorrectly advised that the issue of possible live pigs from Denmark re-emerged at Prime Ministerial level in April 1990.
He was asked about this error on Country Hour on 15 September 1992. He was asked why he had retracted what he stated in the first letter. He said:

Because it was wrong. The original letter was a slip up. The words in that letter were wrong and it should have made it quite clear that there was no involvement by either the Prime Minister or any Ministers.

He was pressed a little with the question: `But that's a very serious mistake' and his answer was, `Yes, it was one of those slips'. But as I observed the Estimates committee before which Mr Landos appeared, it seemed that the first letter was actually the product of a drafting committee, you might say, of three officials and that the words were specifically included. They were not in the earlier drafts; they were specifically added by Mr Landos, who was the senior member of that drafting group. Yet now he says that it was a mistake. I cannot understand why one would specifically add those words to the draft by a slip. It just does not make sense to me. If that were just a one-off, perhaps one would forget it, but it does not seem to be just a one-off.

PARA.TAB: I have come to this matter obviously later than Senator Boswell. I have come to it really out of the fact that it was clear that Senator Boswell was not getting proper answers in this place from Senator Button. I raised with Senator Button the fact that twice he had denied that the issue of importing pig semen had been raised at ministerial level when there was another memo from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service dated 23 June 1992, again signed by the same Mr Landos, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Danish Minister for Agriculture raised the matter of access for uncooked Danish pigmeat and pig semen during discussions with Mr Crean in April 1992.

As I said, twice Senator Button had said that that did not occur. On the face of it, that obviously requires an answer because what he has put to us was inconsistent with what was on the face of this memorandum. Finally today, in answer to a supplementary, if I interpret him correctly, what Senator Button said was, `I have not been misleading you because the memo is wrong'. So it seems that today, the Minister is saying that this memorandum of Mr Landos, which specifically says that these issues of the import of pig semen were raised with Mr Crean, is wrong. I wonder whether that is the view of Mr Landos as well.

PARA.TAB: The matter is complicated even further by the involvement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It seems that the Prime Minister applied the heavy to the Age newspaper back on 16 September 1992. The Age, apparently in early editions the previous day, had reported that a family company of the Prime Minister was an investor in Danpork Australia, which planned to import live pigs from Denmark as part of a joint venture operation with a Danish company. The Age in its correction said that that was wrong. The correction stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The joint venture in which Mr Keating has an interest will use local stock. It has no intention of importing any pigs or breeding material from anywhere, and has not applied to do so. The mistake was made by a reporter.
It goes on to say:
Mr Keating says the joint venture has not been the subject of any ministerial talks, nor has it been involved in contact with the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service.
Yet, the same memorandum that I referred to a moment ago of Mr Landos, dated 23 June 1992, says elsewhere:

A joint venture between Danpork (Denmark) and the Australian company Brown and Hatton has recently been announced to establish an integrated industry in Australia based on Danish processing technology, Australian pig genetics and, ultimately, with inclusion of Danish pig genetic material if possible.
There appears to be an inconsistency between what is in this memorandum and what apparently Mr Keating told the Age which it published on 16 September 1992.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to press the matter further tonight because it seems to me that there are many unanswered questions that are going to require answers before one can come to final conclusions on this matter. But, as I said at the outset, we are not going to let the matter rest at this stage. We are going to continue to press for the answers to those questions until we find out what the true picture is and whatever consequences might flow from that will so flow.

I regret in some ways that it has been necessary to raise that issue, because I really wanted to deal with the question of Somalia. But I thought that Senator Boswell deserved support on what he has been seeking to do, particularly considering the way in which he has been dismissed by Senator Button, who has not made any real attempt to properly answer those questions.

The commitment of Australian forces to Somalia was a very major decision of the Australian Government. We also said that in relation to the commitment of Australian forces to Cambodia. However, in some ways, the environment in Somalia is even more dangerous. That does not mean that the decision to commit forces should not be made. In fact, the Opposition today said that we support the decision of the Government. In other words, we support the international community in trying to help the Somali people in the resolution of their awful situation. As such, we have certain specialist skills which have been called upon by the United Nations. As a responsible member of the international community, we endorse the Government's decision to accept that invitation from the UN to enable our skills to be used in this way.

As in the case of Cambodia, we said that in a situation where such a serious decision is made, the Australian Parliament and the Australian people really deserve a full statement of the background situation; the conflict that is occurring; the role that the United Nations is seeking to play in helping the local people overcome their conflict; the particular function that the Australian personnel will play within the UN force; and the risk assessment into which they are being placed, and matters of that nature.

Without wanting to be unduly critical of the Minister's using Question Time and a brief answer to announce that, I really think that today the Government should have put down such a statement. It is not too late to do that because, although the Minister has committed Australian forces to this mission, he said in his answer that the timing of the deployment of Australian personnel will be discussed with the United Nations.

The Prime Minister ultimately has to accept responsibility for these grave decisions. I would like to see him come back to this Parliament, if not tomorrow at least at the beginning of the next sitting fortnight, and put down a detailed statement in the terms I have just outlined. That is the very least that the Australian Parliament is entitled to have. It is entitled to have the opportunity to properly debate the decision of the Government.

My only visit to Somalia was also at a sad time—a time of conflict between states, in that instance between Somalia and Ethiopia. I visited the Ogaden area where fighting was occurring and saw very similar circumstances to the tragedy that we are now seeing except that this tragedy of the starvation and the pain and suffering is not arising out of a conflict between states but a conflict within a state. However, the consequences for those who suffer are exactly the same.

For the United Nations to look to assume a role in that environment is really to accept a very challenging mission. I can recall no instance where the UN has sought such a role in a circumstance where there has been a total breakdown of authority with no governmental function. It raises all sorts of interesting questions as to what might be the role of the UN in the internal affairs of states in circumstances of the breakdown of authority in the future. To some extent it therefore sets a precedent.

However, the whole international community is so appalled at what is occurring in Somalia that there is this desperate feeling that we as a community as a whole cannot let it continue without taking some action in an attempt to alleviate the suffering. Thus the UN, in an unprecedented act on 28 August 1992, unanimously passed resolution 775 authorising the increase in strength of the United Nations operation in Somalia known as UNOSOM.

It was to increase the total force from the original few observers that had been sent to Mogadishu to a force of 3,500, which comprised four battalions of 750 each that were provided by Canada, Austria, Egypt and Belgium. They were to be deployed at Bossasso in the north-east, and in the south-west near the Kenyan border. Two other places that the Secretary-General wished to deploy such forces were Berbera and Kismayu in the south-east. However, we understand that Mohamed Sahsoun, the UN special envoy to Somalia, is still waiting for the local war lords to agree to their deployment in those two places.

I was privileged to have been briefed on this matter at the United Nations in New York the week before last, not only for humanitarian reasons but because I had heard rumours that Australia was going to be asked to contribute to these movement control forces to the Somali mission. I raised with UN authorities this notion that the UN has to seek the authority of local war lords before it can assume its task. Regrettably, the answer was simply that the law and order position is so desperate in Somalia that the UN would not be able to carry out its function without the authority and support of local war lords—something that one must find appalling. Nevertheless, the mandate, which we endorse, was for the protection of the convoys that transport the supplies from the port or the airport to warehouses and distribution centres, the protection of those stores and centres and the protection of the distribution process.

Many brave aid officials, both from the United Nations and NGOs, have been and now are in Somalia seeking to benefit those who are suffering. At the very least it seems that the UN, our international body that is utilising the strength of the international community, should be prepared to offer them some support to protect the food chain that is going to those who are starving as a result of the conflict. I use this opportunity to register my credit to those brave individuals who are at the moment in a very dangerous environment. We read in the Australian press this morning about certain officials from the CARE organisation. We should admire their work and give them due credit.

I understand that there is a totally unstable situation on the ground. As I indicated, there is no semblance of normal law and order. On the one hand, there is clan rivalry, with each clan supporting these distinctive war lords, and on the other there is a wider situation of law and order breakdown, usually with the result of young thugs taking the law into their own hands and extorting people, including, sadly, these aid workers. It will not be an easy task to bring that situation to some form of order.

I am advised that more than 10,000 people have already died from the combined effects of war and drought and another two million are threatened, which gives us some idea of the extent of the tragedy. What has been left in the country of the health infrastructure is at best rudimentary. According to the UN Secretary-General, as many as 4.5 million people are in desperate need of food and other assistance.

In the past six weeks the UN world food program has been able to airlift some 210 tonnes of supplies to this environment each day. But for that supply of food, the figures for deaths that I mentioned would be even much greater. However, they are suffering from a shortage of trucks and spare parts, poor roads, high security costs and the widespread looting of which we have heard a great deal.

On the political end, the UN is struggling. It is under the mandate of the Secretary-General in the resolution I mentioned, with some support from the OAU and the League of Arab States, to try to bring these war lords together to see whether some form of comprehensive political solution might be found. Until such a solution is found, sadly, all that we and the UN will be doing is providing a bandaid. Nevertheless, a bandaid is of benefit to those who are suffering, rather than nothing at all.

I make that brief contribution tonight, putting before the Senate some detail of the environment in which our forces will be placed. I regret that it has not been put before the Parliament by the Government, as is its responsibility. I guess we should be pleased that the professionalism of our forces has again been recognised. A similar movement control unit was, as you would know, Mr Deputy President, put into Cambodia at the request of the UN. Apparently its work has been internationally accepted as being of an excellent standard, and it played a very major part in allowing the improved coordination of the work of UNTAC in Cambodia. There is no doubt that as a result of that record Australia has again been asked to assist. We should recognise that we are assisting in a very difficult environment. There are risks that our forces will be taking and the Australian Government should be properly putting before the Parliament a full and detailed statement of all relevant matters in order that the issues might be properly debated.

In conclusion, I reiterate that, on the basis of the very scant evidence that we have to date, we nevertheless support in principle the decision that the Australian Government has made. We simply ask for that statement to be put down in order that it might be properly debated as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to draw attention to the fact that a fortnight ago one of Australia's most distinguished corporate people, certainly one of Australia's most distinguished businessmen and a totally decent and honourable bloke, retired from the board of the Reserve Bank. I refer to Mr Jack Davenport, A.C., D.S.O., D.F.C. and Bar, G.M., and fellow of the Australian Institute of Management.

PARA.TAB: Jack Davenport was the last of the Fraser Government appointees to the Reserve Bank. He served three five-year terms and retired on 29 December 1992, leaving a large gap of experience on the Reserve Bank board, experience he generated over many years as a distinguished businessman. He is still Chairman of the Australian Gas Light Company and Volvo Australia Pty Ltd and a Director of Alcoa Australia Ltd, Colinta Holdings Pty Ltd, Dalgety Farmers Ltd and the Munich Reinsurance Company of Australia Ltd, Deputy Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Heart Research Institute and Chairman of the Development Council of the Heart Research Institute.

I have known Jack Davenport for a long time. When he was with Monier Ltd, which he joined in 1946, I was a journalist on the Australian Financial Review. At that time Monier was having a great deal of difficulty with the Americans, curiously enough over the funding of and payment for the North-West Cape telecommunications facility. Monier strongly contested that it had not been adequately paid because of specific difficulties in erecting that facility.

Over many years I dealt very directly with Jack Davenport and I found him to be a man of outstanding integrity and directness, apart from being a decent and honourable fellow. He became managing director of Monier in 1970 and continued in that job until 1982.

There were many other companies with which Jack Davenport was involved. He was a director of Mt Isa Mines, through its MIM Holdings Ltd, until his retirement from that in 1990. He was a Director of Qantas Ltd, from which he retired in 1990. He was also on the Australian Council of Science and Technology, the Australian War Memorial Council, a member of the Board of Review of the Independent Commission Against Corruption, Governor of the National Institute for Labour Studies Ian Clunies Ross Foundation, Federal Vice-President of the Air Force Association, Member of the Federal Council and Chairman of the New South Wales division of the Institute of Directors. He was a RAAF wing commander. Apart from all those other decorations he was mentioned in dispatches in 1943 and he had been in the Army from 1937 to 1940. He was awarded the Sir John Storey Medal in 1982 at the Australian Institute of Management. I also saw a great deal of him in that role because I was on the Institute of Management's annual report award committee, with which he was closely involved.
Senator Button was very gracious in making some remarks about Mr Davenport, which should be stated in this chamber. Senator Button said:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout his long association, Mr Davenport has epitomised the model board member,—
this is of the Reserve Bank—
always well-prepared, and reflecting a national perspective, he brought informed comments and commonsense judgements to the board's deliberations.

I must say amen to all that. I think it is unfortunate that perhaps there is not some more significant way that Australia could honour Jack Davenport. He has been a loyal, outstanding servant of his nation, an outstanding businessman and has been a distinguished member of the Reserve Bank for 15 years. I do not know of any other outside director who has had such a long and distinguished record of support. I hope that in his retirement, at least from the Reserve Bank board and not from all his other boards, he has greater time to participate in the golf, gardening, bridge and stud cattle breeding that I know he enjoys.

PARA.TAB: I would like very briefly to move to another matter. I simply wish to underline and strengthen a couple of points I made today when Senator Button very foolishly made a totally wrong statement about whether other directors were entitled to any of the $8.4m of shareholders' equity that now exists in Euphron Pty Ltd—at least it existed on 30 June 1991—a company half owned by the Prime Minister, Mr Paul Keating.

As the Senate is aware, I have long been expressing interest in the fact that Mr Keating and his family managed to buy for $430,000 in mid-June 1991 an asset which was reported by the company itself to be worth $4.2m—half of $8.4m—by 30 June, which was just six weeks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the net assets?

—That is the shareholders' equity as reported in the documents I tabled—if the honourable senator had been interested enough to look at them—after Question Time. According to the ASC return forms, that is what the company says is the value of its shareholders' equity. And, yes, that is the net of all borrowings—if that is the burden of the honourable senator's inquiry. It is the shareholders' equity as described by the company.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button was foolish enough to say, `Ah, but there were other shareholders in the company at that time'. Of course, Senator Button was right. There were two other shareholders according to the company's return. They were the holders of redeemable preference shares. They had no right to be holders of redeemable preference shares, and I will deal with that in passing because it is yet another example of this group's total incompetence or else its determination to mislead. I do not know which it is because it seems to me to be impossible that anyone could be as incompetent as this group.

But let us acknowledge the fact that, yes, two people held J-class redeemable preference shares which were not redeemed until 10 August 1991, according to the return to the Australian Securities Commission which I tabled today in the Senate. However, when I look at the articles of association of the company, in section 125B I see the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to the provisions of Section 120 of the Companies Code the next issue of shares of any class or classes after the issue of the subscribers' shares and payment up in full thereof shall be deemed to have been issued for the purposes of redeeming the subscribers' shares provided that the number of shares so issued is at least equal to the number of subscribers' shares on issue. Upon the issue of such shares the subscribers' shares shall ipso facto be redeemed at par and the issued capital of the company shall then stand at an amount equal to the par value of the total number of shares which comprise the next issue of shares.

In other words, those shares should have been totally redeemed, and I understand that they were. But what interests me is why the J shares still appeared on 10 August. I guess that is a matter which the company itself can establish. The fact is that in relation to these J shares the company states:

The `J' class redeemable preference shares shall carry no voting rights whatsoever. The said `J' class redeemable preference shares shall confer upon the holders thereof the right to payment of such non-cumulative dividends—
none were paid—

as the directors of the company may from time to time recommend and as the company may pursuant to these articles declare and shall in respect to payments of any dividends so declared rank pari passu with all other classes of shares in the capital of the company on which dividends may be declared.
It continues:

Subject to the provisions of Section 120 of the Code, the company reserves the right at any time or from time to time to redeem at par such of the said redeemable preference shares as it may from time to time determine.

I underline this, because it means that what Senator Button was telling us was that somehow some other shareholders were entitled to some slice of this $8.4m, which is really in effect shared between Mr Keating's family company and another company called Sephrenia Pty Ltd, and in which Mr Keating's share is $4.2m.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Button was saying that there were other shareholders, he was trying to put to us that there were other shareholders with some significant—or at least meaningful, otherwise he would not have mentioned it—interest in this $4.2m that really relates to Mr Keating's interest. In fact, we find those J shares redeemable at par—a total of $200.

All I suggest to Senator Button is that before he makes a fool of himself again he goes and has a good look at the details. If he wants a quick coaching course on how to read annual accounts, I will give it to him, but it is ludicrous that he should suggest that this diminishes in any way the reality that Mr Keating magically was able to buy for $430,000 a half interest in a company which says its shareholders' equity is $8.4m—in other words, giving him an entitlement to shareholders' equity stated by the company to be worth $4.2m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have previously raised both in the Senate and in the Estimates Committees questions concerning the desperate plight of thousands of Christian hill tribespeople who have been forcibly relocated to camps in Dimawso and Pruso on the plains in northern central Burma. There are thousands and thousands of these people. After they have been shifted out and relocated from the hills to the plains, their homes and villages have been burned, their crops destroyed and they are virtually friendless. They are in a desperate plight.

PARA.TAB: Today I noted a Reuters report entitled `Slaves of new Burma railway . . . dying one a day'. It reported that these hills tribesmen have been forced to work as virtual slave labourers on the new railway and have been dying from malnutrition and disease. The report indicates that at least 90 people have died—mainly elderly people and children—since they have been relocated over the past six months. There is a lot of malnutrition and ill-health in the camps. But the interesting part about this is that Lieutenant Colonel Than Han of the Burmese Government's Border Areas Development Committee defended the SLORC policy of using this type of labour and he said that in return for their work the labourers were given medical treatment. In fact they are slave labourers. He says, `No, they are given medical treatment'.

I believe that we really do have to do something urgently about this situation. At the Estimates Committee hearing I asked whether our Ambassador was able to go to these areas and look at the problem. The Government is being advised by the Ambassador and, of course, its policies are considered having regard to the ambassadorial reports. The Ambassador in fact had requested to go on an inspection of the area, but his request was refused by the SLORC on the ground that the trip would be dangerous because of rebel activity.

That can be taken with a pinch of salt. This is an area which is policed by heavily armed troops of the SLORC, which is forcing persons to work on the railway, and it has the audacity to suggest that our Ambassador cannot go to the area because of rebel activity. Is it not able to protect our Ambassador? What will the Australian Minister for Foreign

SPEECH.PARA: Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) do about that? The Minister and, indeed, the Government, the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and the Independents are all most concerned about this issue.

PARA.TAB: I feel that a statement should be made to the Parliament by the Minister about the situation in Burma. Strong action is required in conjunction with other countries so as to bring SLORC to heel. I appeal to the Government to bring in a statement which will strongly condemn the woeful violations of human rights in Burma and which will propose strong action by the world community against the SLORC Government.

Unfortunately, people are being lulled into a sense of unrealism because the statements that seem to be emanating from government circles indicate that there may be some improvement in the human rights situation. The problem is that people and diplomats, by and large, do not get out of Rangoon. There may be some improvements around the edges in Rangoon, but the reverse clearly is the case in the provinces and outlying areas where thousands and thousands of ordinary Burmese citizens are suffering dreadfully at the hands of this brutal regime currently in charge of Burma which should be ostracised by our Government and by governments of similar mind. I urge the Government to bring forward such a statement which will show very strong resolve in this area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that 1993 has been designated by the United Nations as International Year of Indigenous People, with an official launch scheduled in New York on 10 December 1992.
(2) What activities have been planned to mark this year which focuses on human rights and social justice for all indigenous people.
(3) Has a Departmental officer been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and co-ordinating activities for International Year of Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) During 1993, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) will release a national statistical report on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (ATSI) population, based on data collected in the 1991 census. It also plans to include a special article in the 1993 Year Book in recognition of the International Year of Indigenous People (IYIP).
(b) The Royal Australian Mint proposes to produce a medallion mid way through 1993 to commemorate the IYIP.
(c) Treasury has developed an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Recruitment and Career Development Strategy which highlights recruitment options for ATSI as economic policy advisors through:
the Treasury Graduate Recruitment Campaign;
the Aboriginal Cadetship Program; and
a secondment program for non-economics graduates working with ATSIC.
An SES officer has been nominated to oversight this activity.

(d) Similarly, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) recognises the IYIP through its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Career Development Strategy. The Strategy covers career development, recruitment and promotion activities and will also include special internal and external activities to celebrate National Aboriginal and Islander Day.

(3) (a) Through its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Statistical Unit, the ABS has regular contact with ATSIC on a range of statistical work, including the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Survey planned for early 1994. ABS statistical work relevant to IYIP will be coordinated through that unit.

(b) The Royal Australian Mint has already made contact with ATSIC to discuss the proposed medallion to obtain expert advice on the design theme and reference material. Liaison will continue through the design and marketing phase.
(c) A Treasury officer is to be nominated as the ATSI student needs coordinator.
(d) Similarly, an ATO officer is to be nominated to liaise.
