TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) What would be the estimated 1992-93 net cost to the Commonwealth of extending eligibility for the Service Pension Benefits Card to Commonwealth and Allied veterans; (b) on what basis has this estimate been established; and (c) how many of these veterans would qualify for the card.

(2)(a) What would be the estimated 1992-93 net cost to the Commonwealth of exempting veterans from the nursing home patient contribution where they have been institutionalised due to war-caused injury or disease; (b) on what basis has this estimate been established; and (c) how many veterans would qualify for such an exemption.

(3)(a) What would be the estimated 1992-93 net cost to the Commonwealth of including ex-British Commonwealth Occupation Force (BCOF) personnel as veterans under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986; (b) on what basis has this estimate been established; and (c) how many ex-BCOF personnel would be affected by being granted such status.

(4)(a) What would be the estimated 1992-93 net cost to the Commonwealth of automatically granting war widows or widowers pension to partners of deceased at: (i) 100 per cent of the General Rate, and (ii) Intermediate Rate disability pensioners; (b) on what basis have these estimates been established; and (c) how many partners of such disability pensioners would be affected.

(5)(a) What would be the estimated 1992-93 net cost to the Commonwealth of including Australian merchant mariners of World War I and II as veterans under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986; (b) on what basis has this estimate been established; and (c) how many mariners and dependants would be affected by such an inclusion.

(6)(a) What would be the estimated 1992-93 net cost to the Commonwealth of paying service pension at the single rate to service pension widows; (b) on what basis has this estimate been established; and (c) how many widows would be affected by payment at this rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) The 1992-93 full year estimated net cost to the Commonwealth of extending eligibility for the Service Pensioner Benefits Card (SPBC) to Commonwealth and allied veterans is $54.5m;
(b) The estimate is based on the following assumptions:
Commonwealth and allied mariners have been included with Commonwealth and allied veterans for the purpose of this costing as the SPBC was extended to Australian mariners from 1 December 1991;
there are 32,114 Commonwealth and allied veterans and mariners in receipt of service pension of whom approximately 85% are eligible for fringe benefits and would be entitled to a SPBC;

my Department's treatment cost has been estimated to be $68m with an offset of $13.5m against Department of Health, Housing and Community Services expenditure (because of the nature of the Commonwealth/State hospital agreements there would be no realisable savings to the Commonwealth for hospital services); and
the treatment costs include expenditure on health services but do not include salaries and administrative costs associated with the arrangement and the provision of health services.
(c) Approximately 27,300 Commonwealth and allied veterans and mariners would qualify for the issue of a SPBC.

(2)(a) My Department does not have information concerning the reason for a veteran's admission to a nursing home. I am therefore unable to provide the estimated cost of exempting veterans from the nursing home patient contribution where they have been institutionalised due to war-caused injury or disease.
Consequently, I am also unable to provide answers to parts (b) and (c) of this question.

(3)(a) Australian members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces (BCOF) who served in Japan in the initial period of occupation are covered under the Veterans' Entitlements Act (VEA). This includes those veterans who enlisted in the Australian Imperial Forces (AIF) prior to 1 July 1947, who were members of the Interim Forces or who enlisted in the permanent Defence Force before 3 January 1949.

There is no distinction in respect of disability benefits between those members of the BCOF who enlisted prior to 1 July 1947 and any other member of the Australian Defence Force who enlisted during World War II. These members are entitled to the same disability benefits under the same conditions as any other member serving during World War II including free treatment for malignant cancers, irrespective of the cause.

Only those who enlisted after 3 January 1949 in the permanent Defence Force are not covered under the VEA for their service in Japan. However, they are eligible to claim compensation benefits under the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act.

Australian members of the BCOF did not arrive in Japan until February 1946, some five months after hostilities with Japan ceased. Members of the BCOF have not rendered qualifying service in respect of that service and are therefore not eligible for service pension unless eligible in respect of other service.

The 1992-93 full year estimated net cost to the Commonwealth of extending service pension eligibility to former members of the BCOF (Japan) is $25.4m. This figure does not include the associated salaries and administrative costs.
(b) The estimate has been based on the following assumptions:
in 1992-93 there would be approximately 11,100 former members of the BCOF who do not have qualifying service;

41% of those survivors who are aged 65 years or more will transfer to the service pension from the Department of Social Security (i.e. those in receipt of a disability pension) to qualify for the more generous income test assessment arrangements;
the age-specific service pension participation rates for survivors will be the same as that for other veterans with qualifying service—an additional 2,400 veterans would receive service pension;
the average fortnightly rate of service pension at 30 June 1992 will apply, i.e. $231.96 per fortnight (each) for a married veteran and spouse and $286.53 per fortnight for a single veteran; and
there is a treatment cost in providing Personal Treatment Entitlement Cards (PTECs) and Service Pensioner Benefits Cards (SPBCs) to some former members of BCOF.
(c) Approximately 2,400 former members would receive a service pension.

(4)(a) The 1992-93 full year estimated net cost to the Commonwealth of automatically granting war widows' or widowers' pensions to partners of deceased veterans who were receiving disability pension at:
(i)100% of the general rate would be $1.323m; and
(ii)intermediate rate would be $0.210m.
These estimates do not allow for salary and administrative costs.
(b) The estimates are based on the following assumptions:
the proposal would apply only to future deaths of veterans; it would not apply to widows of veterans who died before the date of introduction;
approximately 75% of veterans have a spouse;
payments would be made from the date of the veteran's death or the date of introduction of the change, whichever is later;
the expected number of additional widow/ widower grants under this proposal are expected to be 150 in respect of 100% general rate pensioners and 20 in respect of intermediate rate pensioners;
these numbers relate to those widows/widowers who would not have a claim for war widow's/widower's pension accepted under the current system;

the current proportion of widows in receipt of a Social Security age pension is approximately 73% and the proportion of widows whose age pensions would be paid at the frozen rate under this proposal would be 66%;
the net cost to the Commonwealth would comprise:

TAB.TAB: additional costs to my Department of paying war widows'/widowers' pensions and providing treatment cover;
savings to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services through Medicare and nursing home costs;
costs to the Department of Social Security of additional age pension for some widows; and
savings to the Department of Social Security based on the average rate of standard-rate age pension payments.

PARA.TAB: (c) A total of 170 partners would be affected (this figure includes 150 partners of 100% general rate pensioners and 20 partners of intermediate rate pensioners).

(5)(a) The 1992-93 full year estimated net cost to the Commonwealth of including Australian merchant mariners of World War I and II as veterans under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 would be $4.4m.
(b) The estimate has been based on the following assumptions:
3,760 surviving mariners at a claim rate of 22% and 63% success rate will result in 520 successful disability claims from mariners;
1,370 estimated surviving widows and widowers of mariners at a claim rate of 22% and success rate of 52% will result in 160 widows and widowers being granted war widows'/ widowers' pensions;

the costing takes into account Veterans' Affairs pension costs for these mariners (at an average of 40% of the general rate) and widows and Department of Social Security offsets in respect of the widows;

there is a treatment component for some mariners becoming eligible for a Specific Treatment Entitlement Card (STEC) or Personal Treatment Entitlement Card (PTEC) for the first time with the grant or increase in disability pension and for war widows and widowers becoming eligible for a Dependant Treatment Entitlement Card (DTEC) (because of the nature of the Commonwealth/State hospitals agreements there would be no realisable savings to the Commonwealth for hospital services).
(c) Approximately 680 mariners and their widows/widowers.
(6)(a) In 1992-93 the estimated net cost to the Commonwealth of paying service pension at the single rate to service pension widows would be $2.3m.
(b) The estimate has been based on the following assumptions:
that the eligible number of service pension widows, i.e. those aged 55 years and over, is 1,628; and

that the increase in the pension paid would be the difference between the maximum married rate of $255.30 per fortnight and the maximum standard (single) rate of $306.10 per fortnight plus $5 being half the increase in the income free area available between a married person and a single person.
(c) Approximately 1,628 widows.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 9 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of Resolution 43(13) of the London Dumping Convention which requires the cessation of the ocean dumping of toxic industrial waste by 31 December 1995.
(2) Does the Convention apply to the Pasminco-EZ smelter at Risdon, meaning that by 31 December 1995 the dumping of jarosite waste at sea must cease.
(3) Have assurances been sought from the company that this deadline will be met; if so, what commitments have been made; if not, why not.

(4) Has a subsidiary of Pasminco-EZ, Budelco of the Netherlands, been involved over several years in a research and development joint venture with Noranda of Canada and others to design a process to manage Jarosite.
(5) Has this project developed the "Oxysmelt" process which effectively contains any leaching from land based storage of jarosite.
(6) Has the Government of the Netherlands assessed and endorsed this process as the appropriate means to manage jarosite.
(7) Has Risdon's sister-smelter at Budel in the Netherlands, owned jointly by Shell and Pasminco Metals, ever been permitted to dump jarosite in the ocean.
(8) Has all jarosite produced from this smelter been stored on land since the early 1970s.

(9) Did Budelco announce in January 1991 that it had perfected a new process designed to contain and isolate methal processing effluent from its tailing ponds which increases the ore recovery rate as well as protects the ground water.

(10) Given these developments which effectively provide viable alternatives to dumping jarosite at sea, is the Government prepared to fully endorse and implement the 1995 London Dumping Convention deadline.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The dumping at sea of jarosite waste falls within the terms of resolution 43(13) of the London Dumping Convention. The resolution is not binding under international law, but as Australia supported it, there is a moral obligation upon Australia to abide by it.

(3) Pasminco is already on notice with respect to the 1995 deadline for the disposal of industrial wastes at sea. Clearly, however, there will be a range of issues which the Government and the company will need to address to meet this deadline. The only current alternative, landfill of jarosite, presents its own set of environmental problems and the Government sees no benefit merely by transferring the problem from the sea to the land. Consequently, the Government with the cooperation of Pasminco, is seeking a long term solution that minimises overall environmental impact. It is a condition of the sea dumping permit that Pasminco investigate alternative technologies with a view to phasing out the sea dumping of jarosite. It is worth noting, however, that monitoring of the dumping operation has not, in fact, been able to ascertain any adverse effects on the marine environment.

(4) I understand that Budelco has for some years been a member of a consortium of zinc producers which has conducted research into methods of processing jarosite, and that no real progress has been made as a result of this collaborative effort.

(5) No. Independent of the work of the consortium, Budelco has investigated oxygen-enriched flash smelting for processing jarosite. I understand, however, that the economics of this process are still being studied by Budelco.
(6) No. It is still under consideration.
(7) I understand that Budelco has never applied for a sea dumping permit; the issue has never arisen as the plant is well inland, and has road access to land disposal.
(8) Yes. I am advised, however, that problems with leaching of metals into groundwater have led the Netherlands' authorities to require the company to cease further land disposal.

(9) The announcement in January 1991 referred to a groundwater containment scheme to recover leachate mainly from historical process residues (some dating from the turn of the century) but including jarosite. The scheme has no effect on the recovery of metal from present operations.
(10) The Government will continue to abide by its international obligations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Torres Strait Staff

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 10 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many staff are based in Torres Strait.
(2) How many staff are indigenous.
(3) What strategies are being implemented to ensure more Torres Strait Island staff move into senior positions.
(4) How is housing allocated to prevent discrimination against Torres Strait Islanders.
(5) What processes are in place to ensure regular communication and liaison between departments and with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Island Coordinating Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Two. Both are located on Thursday Island.
(2) One.

(3) In accordance with the Government's commitment to the promotion of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (ATSI) employment throughout the Australian Public Service, and recent directives to all Commonwealth Departments and Agencies, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has developed an ATSI Recruitment and Career Development Strategy which aims to increase the recruitment and retention of ATSI officers at all levels of the Department's operations. Initiatives that will facilitate the movement of ATSI officers generally into senior positions are outlined in the Strategy.

In addition to encouraging ATSI officers to pursue mainstream career development and training opportunities through the use of the Department's Development Diary and the Individual Career Path Planning Program, the Department also actively encourages participation in specific programs such as the ATSI Graduate Administrative Assistant program, the Department's Graduate and Associate Diploma courses, DFAT ATSI Scholarship program and in programs coordinated by the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Public Service Commission (eg. Senior Women in Management, Executive Development Scheme, National ATSI Middle Managers Program etc.). The Department will also be incorporating into its organisational structure support measures aimed at retaining more ATSI officers at these levels.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department also employs one Torres Strait Islander at the SOG C level who is presently studying full time for a Master of Arts in International Relations at the University of Wollongong under Aboriginal Undergraduate Study Award Scheme conditions. An ATSI consultant at the SOG C level was engaged earlier in the year to formulate the Department's ATSI recruitment and career development strategy, and an executive officer will be recruited to an identified position at this level to carry out its implementation.

PARA.TAB: The Torres Strait Islander currently located in the Department's Torres Strait Liaison Office on Thursday Island was recently successful in obtaining an overseas posting which will enhance her opportunities for advancement within the Department. Her replacement is being recruited locally.
(4) The Department owns one house on Thursday Island which is allocated to officers who are temporarily transferred to that location.

(5) The Department's Torres Strait Treaty Liaison Officer (TSTLO), based on Thursday Island, consults regularly with the ATSIC regional office and with members of the Island Coordinating Council. ATSIC representatives attend meetings, held roughly on a quarterly basis, of the DFAT-coordinated IDC on the Torres Strait Treaty, and DFAT is represented on the ATSIC-coordinated Torres Strait Tripartite Forum, held annually in Cairns.

ATSIC representatives normally attend Treaty consultative meetings attended by Papua New Guinea, including the Treaty Liaison Meeting and the Joint Advisory Council (JAC). Treaty Liaison Meetings are usually held annually while the JAC normally meets biennially.

Departmental officers in Canberra who are responsible for the Treaty Liaison Office maintain regular contact with the Office of Torres Strait Islander Affairs on Treaty developments. When visiting Thursday Island they also consult with the Chairman of the Island Coordinating Council.

More generally, the Department consults closely with ATSIC as the need arises on particular ATSI related issues. For example, the Department recently contributed (for the first time) to an ATSIC coordinated Budget-related paper (No. 7 "Social Justice for Indigenous Australians 1992-93"). This publication provides details of the activities of the Department's International Organisations Branch, Cultural Relations Branch and Overseas Information Branch relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues and activities. There is also continuing consultation between DFAT and ATSIC concerning activities planned for the International Year of the World's Indigenous Peoples (IYWIP) in 1993. The Department is a member of the ATSIC-coordinated IDC responsible for developing Australia's activities for the Year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 23 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Were environmental impact studies undertaken from the 1940s onwards to ascertain the effect on Dalgety and the surrounding country of the diversion of the Snowy River into the Murray River.
(2) What meetings, if any, were advertised and called to inform the people of Dalgety or Jindabyne of the impact that the proposed scheme would have on them and their properties.
(3) What are the full names and occupations of the Snowy Mountains Council.

(4) The Snowy Mountains Authority (SMA) is supposed to release at least 25 megalitres of water per day into the Snowy River from Lake Jindabyne; is the flow rate set by regulation, law or outside authority; if not, how is the figure set.
(5) Do any records exist showing any flood compensation paid by the SMA to farmers adjoining Swampy Plains River between Khancoban and the Murray River.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1&2) As the relevant body, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority (SMA) advises that it did not carry out any environmental impact studies on the effect of the diversion of the Snowy River into the Murray River. The SMA is not aware of any such studies being done before July 1949 when the SMA was established.

The SMA can find no record of any meetings organised by it to inform the people of Dalgety or Jindabyne of the impact of the Scheme on the Snowy River. However, there were meetings with the people of Jindabyne on the question of relocating the town.

There were discussions with property owners between Jindabyne and Dalgety on the question of containment of stock on land adjoining the Snowy River after the construction of Jindabyne Dam. In a number of cases, where necessary, the SMA fenced the river to contain stock.
The SMA is not aware of any such meetings that occurred before July 1949.
